From rajanvn at gmail.com  Wed Nov  1 09:55:37 2006
From: rajanvn at gmail.com (Natarajan V)
Date: Wed Nov  1 09:55:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Video chat in linux?
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0610311143s4e849134ya0becda606c6d8d5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0610311143s4e849134ya0becda606c6d8d5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <e977d4310610312025u8c84209y52d2cfc0d9e1e0ec@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/1/06, Shrinivasan T <tshrinivasan@gmail.com> wrote:
> I got a web camera today.
> It works well with linux.

Good !!!

> How can i use this web cam to
> video chat with yahoo chat friends?
> Do anyone achieved that?

There is a tool called Gyach. I wasn't able to get it working because,
Gyach doesn't support ALSA. You need eSound. I don't have the patience
to get a wrapper for it(if at all it exists). So I discarded the idea.

> Or which tool both of the chatters
> should use to video chat via internet?

As of now, I use aMSN (http://amsn.sf.net) for Video ( 2x half duplex)
and I use Skype/Jamin for Voice.

And yes, I have tried to use GnomeMeeting from my home to connect to a
WinXP-> M$ Net Meeting, and was quite successful with Voice and Video,
but no text chat. The advantage is that you can see how much of band
width is in use. The flip side was that the Video and Voice quality
was very pathetic over my internet connection. Gnome Meeting/Net
meeting uses the regular GSM compression algorithms for voice
compression. It is no where near the voice quality of Skype. But if
you have a very good bandwidth every tool is the same.


HTH.
Natarajan.

I think Gyach! does support WebCam
(http://www.phrozensmoke.com/projects/pyvoicechat/)
Their mission statement:
<quote>
A full-featured Yahoo client for LINUX with voice chat and
***WEBCAM*** support. Mission: To focus
on thorough Y! support on Linux only. Philosophy: Trying to do
multi-protocol / cross-platform clients slows progress and results in
half-baked support - One protocol, one OS...done well.
</quote>

????????,
? . ???? ???????

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and 
the Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP 
comes with a Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not 
download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to 
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 
6, Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the 
default font for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts 
may be downloaded from here. <http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf>

From niraj at efyindia.com  Wed Nov  1 10:16:46 2006
From: niraj at efyindia.com (Niraj Sahay)
Date: Wed Nov  1 10:15:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Commercial]Share Your Views With LFY
Message-ID: <454826B6.5060003@efyindia.com>

Hello All,

Greetings from the LINUX For You magazine team!

As you all know, we run a section called 'Opinions' in LFY where we
pose a question to the community and industry and publish the top five
responses (selected by our technical editors) in the magazine. Thanks
to all those who responded to the last month's question. The best
among the responses received have been published in the November 2006
issue of LFY.

The forthcoming issue of LFY would carry a story on LUGs. The article
would focus on what constitutes a perfect LUG. We want to pick up the
best practices that every LUG should carry out to evolve into an ideal
and perfect LUG. This would not just ensure scope for improvement for
the LUGs by getting a direct feedback from the community itself, but
would also help others to understand the value of LUGs better.

We value your suggestions and comments. So, any idea you would like to
share with us is most welcome.
Please write to us at sujata.banerjee@efyindia.com 
<mailto:sujata.banerjee%40efyindia.com> with a CC to
atul@efyindia.com <mailto:atul%40efyindia.com>, before 10th November,2006.

The top five responses will be published in the December 2006 issue of
LINUX for You.

Look forward to your responses.

Thanks,

Sujata Banerjee, Editorial Coordinator, LFY
Atul Goel, Asst. Associate Editor, LFY

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Nov  1 13:03:36 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Nov  1 13:03:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Video chat in linux?
In-Reply-To: <e977d4310610312025u8c84209y52d2cfc0d9e1e0ec@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0610311143s4e849134ya0becda606c6d8d5@mail.gmail.com>
	<e977d4310610312025u8c84209y52d2cfc0d9e1e0ec@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061101073336.GB20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Nov 01, 2006 at 09:55:37AM +0530, Natarajan V wrote:
> As of now, I use aMSN (http://amsn.sf.net) for Video ( 2x half duplex)
> and I use Skype/Jamin for Voice.
> 
> And yes, I have tried to use GnomeMeeting from my home to connect to a
> WinXP-> M$ Net Meeting, and was quite successful with Voice and Video,
> but no text chat. The advantage is that you can see how much of band
> width is in use. The flip side was that the Video and Voice quality
> was very pathetic over my internet connection. Gnome Meeting/Net
> meeting uses the regular GSM compression algorithms for voice
> compression. It is no where near the voice quality of Skype. But if
> you have a very good bandwidth every tool is the same.

I am talking theory so I am bound to be mistaken. :-)

CMIIW

<Begin textbook theory>

Even the worst ever vocodec G.711 needs not more than 64 kilo bits per second.

And I am guessing that every single broadband user has at least that much uplink speed available.

This explains quite well whey even dialup users get good performance with VoIP.

G.711 is very good of course and if you CELP(Code Excited Linear Prediction) then you could even make do with just 8 kilobits per second but the voice quality may not be great of course.

I have no idea what codec is used by Skype. I know for sure they also encrypt and compress, so I am guessing it is something proprietary based on one of the various codecs out there. Perhaps some speex hacker can help?

<End of textbook theory>

Now, how do you explain your problem?

Does M$ do something stupid as usual to goof things up? :-)

regards,
Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Nov  1 13:11:14 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Nov  1 13:11:37 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good coding style
Message-ID: <20061101074114.GC20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>

Hi,

	I have converted the OpenBSD style(9) man page for you with the
	command.

	$groff -Tps -mandoc /usr/src/man/man9/style.9 | ps2pdf14 style.pdf


	and uploaded it to 

	http://girish1729.googlepages.com/style.pdf

	I have often found proprietary C code to be really ugly and badly indented, formatted with all sorts of funny variable naming conventions.

	And people get so pedantic about useless topics like beginning every function with a Capital letter and using huge function names.

	Really it is not important beyond a point.

	C is an extremely expressive beautiful language almost like the grammar of Panini.

	So write beautiful code. Writing readable and maintainable code is much more important than proper commenting.

	Anyway read it and digest it. And internalize it and start using these techniques right away.

	Don't waste time discussing K & R style, some other style etc...

	Give it the importance this topic deserves and move on.

	No time to waste beating these topics to death.

	Cosmetics don't have value if you overdo it...

	My idea is not to start a vim emacs war.

	I use gg=G to indent and :se cindent and :sy on and :se nu in vim.

	All the best!

regards,
Girish
From prasannadavid at gmail.com  Wed Nov  1 02:53:20 2006
From: prasannadavid at gmail.com (Prasanna David G)
Date: Wed Nov  1 13:23:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: [ANN] Tamil Tagset released
In-Reply-To: <EE3FF189-DE40-4FF1-BE1C-C24851407DEE@thenilgiris.com>
References: <EE3FF189-DE40-4FF1-BE1C-C24851407DEE@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <5ff65e910610312353x1d1a33a8of248d3023bc27d7c@mail.gmail.com>

On 10/25/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> the tagset is also available in tamil font,
> and will be released shortly. The roman font release was done first
> as some people wanted to use it, and were pressing for an early release

Good.  It will be really helpful for many.

But, the roman encoding used is also something that not everyone
knows.  For example, not many knows that "w" stands for the Tamil
letter "tha",  "nY" stands for the dravidian "na" , etc.  Only people
in AU-KBC and related places like UoH, IITK, IIIT, etc. will know.
So, it will be a good idea to give a table of that encoding also.  It
will be really helpful.

regards,
Prasanna David

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Wed Nov  1 14:27:35 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Wed Nov  1 14:20:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] setting up virtual ethernet interfaces
Message-ID: <129AB497-5E69-474C-9D29-20F6E0CCEE78@thenilgiris.com>

hi,

my debian server has one IP and the /etc/network/interfaces is like  
this:

<snip>


# Loopback device:
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# device: eth0
auto eth0
iface eth0 inet static
address 85.10.199.207
broadcast 85.10.199.223
netmask 255.255.255.224
gateway 85.10.199.193

# default route to access subnet:
up route add -net 85.10.199.192 netmask 255.255.255.224 gw  
85.10.199.193 eth0
  </snip>

I have now been allotted 5 additional ips which are to be configured  
as virtual ethernet interaces. The help file they have given me reads  
like this:

<snip>

auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

## Main-IP
auto eth0
iface eth0 inet static
address xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
broadcast xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
netmask 255.255.255.224
gateway xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
dns-nameservers xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx

## first additional-IP
auto eth0:1
iface eth0:1 inet static
address yyy.yyy.yyy.yyy
broadcast yyy.yyy.yyy.yyy
netmask 255.255.255.248

## Zweite Zusatz-IP
auto eth0:2
iface eth0:2 inet static
address zzz.zzz.zzz.zzz
broadcast zzz.zzz.zzz.zzz
netmask 255.255.255.248

</snip>

In their mail allotting the ips they have given this:

<snip>
IP: 88.198.154.216
Gateway: 88.198.154.217
Mask: 255.255.255.248


additional IP-Adressen:
88.198.154.218 bis 88.198.154.222

</snip>

it will be noted that the 'subnet' of the additional 5 ips is  
different  from the main IP of my machine. So what do i do with the  
line in the original file that reads like this:

# default route to access subnet:
up route add -net 85.10.199.192 netmask 255.255.255.224 gw  
85.10.199.193 eth0

what do i change it to?

-- 

regards
kg

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

Hi Raju,

> This is working fine in RHWS 3. When i click the startup.jar file it opens
> as a directory in Ubuntu.
I thought eclipse in linux had a linked executable. there will be a
eclipse file that can be executed from the shell. If you had java
installed and path set correctly, eclipse should start from this
executable.

http://help.eclipse.org/help21/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.user/tasks/running_eclipse.htm

I hope that answered it.

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Wed Nov  1 16:38:59 2006
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Chandrashekar=20Babu?=)
Date: Wed Nov  1 16:46:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good coding style
Message-ID: <20061101110859.16752.qmail@server301.com>

Hi,

>  I have often found proprietary C code to be really ugly 
> and badly indented, formatted with all sorts of funny 
> variable naming conventions.

[snip]

>  Anyway read it and digest it. 

I strongly recommend the book - "The Practice of Programming" 
by Brian W. Kernighan and Rob Pike [ISBN: 981-235-904-4]
to all brave souls who call themselves a 'computer programmer'.
If you are a programmer, this book (according to me) should be
the second book that you should own, and read from cover to 
cover - its concise and easy and grasp.

For Perl mongers, "Perl Best Practices" by Damian Conway 
[ISBN: 81-7366-828-0] is a must-read/must-have.

As a freelance programmer before, I've been a victim of code
like:
      int sachin = 0; // sachin equals 0.
and the most horrendous like the one below:
     $rhtdm = mysql_connect(....); 
where $rhtdm according to the author meant -  "Rehna Hai 
Tere Dil Mein" !

It is essential for every programmer to treat his program/script 
as a poem and give enough importance to its readability, 
maintainability, presentability and elegance than merely getting 
it to work.

--
Chandrashekar Babu.,
FOSS Technologist,
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

Dear Readers,

With the Fedora team, as usual, pushing the release date of FC6 again 
and again (before finally releasing it on 24th and it getting available 
for download on 25th), we were left with no option but to go for the 
next most requested distro on the bulletinn board - Mandriva Linux 2007. 
This distro is a treat for users who like to work on multi-architecture 
platforms (32-bit and 64-bit).

Coming to the editorial highlights, we have a mega interview with Javed 
Tapia, founder Red Hat India, who speaks to the media for the first time 
after stepping down from his position of director - India. In the trends 
section, this month we discuss about the use of Linux in tghe 
supercomputing world.

We have two very interesting case studies this month, one that discusses 
the first mover advantage taken by Samsung by incorporating the 
'Linux-compatible' logo in their printer advertisement and the other 
about Bombay high court adopting Linux/OSS.

In our opinions section, this month, the community opines on how whether 
IPR is a boon or a bane. Also, in the 'Down Memory Lane' series, we look 
at the history of the KDE project.

FOR YOU & ME

* KDE: Kudos All the Way!
* Mandriva Linux 2007: The Ia Ora Magic Casts a New Spell
* Enigmatise Youe E-mail

River India

* FreedomYug: Steal This Film

ON LFY DVD

* Mandriva Linux 2007 (Free Edition)

The latest distribution from the Mandriva stable, Mandriva Linux 2007 
(free edition) is simply fabulous. A highly versatile distribution, this 
DVD is readily installable on both 32-bit and 64-bit architectures.

ON LFY CD

1.1, Art of Illusion, myStudio - Free/Open source 3D software, JPatch, 
K-3D, screenhack, Aqsis, Ayam, gSculpt, Aztec 3D Modeller,

Ripper, GNU FreeIPMI

Dream, SolarWolf, LinCity-NG, Extended Death Match, Danger from the Deep

lfyedit@efyindia.com

From akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in  Wed Nov  1 17:41:08 2006
From: akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in (Kumar Appaiah)
Date: Wed Nov  1 17:41:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Intex ethernet card driver
Message-ID: <a0c4f6270611010411t67287647jf9bce7c126fad168@mail.gmail.com>

Dear ILUGC,

One of my friends has the Intex (cheap) LAN card Silan sc92031. Now,
that doesn't work at all in most distributions. However, the CD
provided with it ahs Linux drivers, albeit for kernels 2.4/2.5.

Now, an ILUGC member (Mr.Kumaraguru) has modified this for working
with kernel 2.6, and it is at
http://gurukumara.googlepages.com/

However, it doesn't compile under newer 2.6 kernels because of the
deprecation of some functions/macros used. In particular, MODULE_PARM
and a function called synchonize_irq.

I read up a bit and made some minimal changes which made the driver
compile under kernel 2.6.17:

http://www.ee.iitm.ac.in/~ee03b091/sc92031.c

It compiles, loads and works fine for about five minutes, following which I get:

kernel: [some numbers]: Disabled IRQ #201 (or something similar).

Despite my best attempts and googling, I could not solve this problem.
I'd appreciate it if someone could point it out and suggest the right
modification in the driver, as it will be useful to many.

Thanks.

Kumar

P.S. Right now, my friend is still enjoying internet, as his card
(with WinXP drivers) is recognized as a Wireless LAN card by
ndiswrapper, and as wlan0, works like a charm!
-- 
Kumar Appaiah,
462, Jamuna Hostel,
Indian Insititute of Technology Madras,
Chennai - 600036
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Nov  1 18:18:52 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Nov  1 18:22:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] setting up virtual ethernet interfaces
In-Reply-To: <129AB497-5E69-474C-9D29-20F6E0CCEE78@thenilgiris.com>
References: <129AB497-5E69-474C-9D29-20F6E0CCEE78@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <20061101124852.GA19522@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Nov 01, 2006 at 02:27:35PM +0530, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

 [snip]

> <snip>
> IP: 88.198.154.216
> Gateway: 88.198.154.217
> Mask: 255.255.255.248
> 
> 
> additional IP-Adressen:
> 88.198.154.218 bis 88.198.154.222
> 
> </snip>
> 
> it will be noted that the 'subnet' of the additional 5 ips is  
> different  from the main IP of my machine. So what do i do with the  
> line in the original file that reads like this:
> 
> # default route to access subnet:
> up route add -net 85.10.199.192 netmask 255.255.255.224 gw  
> 85.10.199.193 eth0
> 
> what do i change it to?

Kenneth,

 If I were you I would replace the line to read
 up route add -net 85.10.199.192 netmask 255.255.255.0 gw 85.10.199.193 eth0

 Or your line itself should work.

 Remember though going by the book you should set the subnet mask to the exact value, due to VLSM and other funny things, such hacks actually work.

 Now, this is of course not the right way to do things.

 No guarantees.

 regards,
 Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Nov  1 18:57:51 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Nov  1 18:58:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Good coding style [OT]
In-Reply-To: <20061101074114.GC20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061101074114.GC20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <20061101132751.GA233@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Nov 01, 2006 at 01:11:14PM +0530, Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> 
> 	C is an extremely expressive beautiful language almost like the grammar of Panini.
> 


This is way off topic.

Quite frankly I heard about Panini again in a NetBSD mailing list few days ago in relation with some not very technical discussion.

Of course NetBSD folks are not humans... they are machines only talking some OS theory,algo or some such thing that never enters my brain...

But Panini struck me as odd.

Now that Roshan sent a mail I searched for Panini again and got to know that the modern Augmented Backur Naur Form (ABNF) was actually derived from Panini's grammer.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P%C4%81%E1%B9%87ini

The article evens claims that Noam Chomsky derived his grammer from Panini and that Panini is the father of modern computing in a way. Read it.

What to talk of ancient Indian genius?

Even Shrodinger is supposed to owe his uncertainty theory and quantum mechanics to Upanishads and the Vedas.

Talking of linguistics, I am not exactly a linguist though I am a polyglot.

And of late I have been thinking of this.

That English really falls short when I want to express something, especially certain philosophical concepts or especially idioms.

(For examples please contact me off list, I have at least five)

I find that languages like Tamil have nearly everything I want though you have to resort to English or Sanskit at times...

In particular I love these Tamil idiomatic phrases.

(Non Tamilians please excuse)

	a) Veraluketha veekam ( Swelling proportional to finger)
	b) Kaaka ukkanthuthan panankai vizunthathan(crow sits and palm falls)
	c) Uuran vetu neiyan pondati kaiyan( wife is generous with someone's ghee)
	d) Aarina kanji pazhan kanji (cooled barley water is old stuff)

Ok, very sorry , I never meant to hurt list members who don't understand Tamil. I am sure you can ask someone. That is why I have also provided translations to the best of my ability.

Can anybody give me equally expressive and beautiful equivalents in English?

It is said that language is indicative of the intellectual culture of a race and the fact that India has both Tamil and Sanskrit is a matter of immense pride to us.

It is in our hands to prove to the world that even today we are no worse than our great forefathers.

Are you game? 

regards,
Girish

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Nov  1 08:54:40 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Nov  1 22:25:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mailing list guidelines: monthly reminder
Message-ID: <20061101165440.47021.qmail@web50207.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

This is a monthly reminder on the mailing list
guidelines. Please don't reply to this e-mail. If you
would like to update the same, do it here:

  http://chennailug.org/guidelines

1. Use a proper subject line.

2. Do not troll in the mailing list

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll

3. Use [OT] for off-topic, non-technical discussions.
But, don't misuse this to start flame wars or to troll
in the mailing list.

4. Do not top-post:

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top-posting

Example of a top-post:

Because it messes up the order in which
people normally read text.
> > Why is top-posting
> > such a bad thing?
Top-posting.
> > What is the most
> > annoying thing in e-mail?

Always use bottom-posting.

> What is your name ?
My name is ILUGC.

5. Do not over-quote:

Example of an over-quote:

>>> On Friday you said
>>> blah blah blah
>> On Saturday you said
>> foo foo foo
> On Sunday you said
> foobar

6. Do not post HTML messages

7. Do not recycle messages

8. Do not send attachments

9. Do not attach obnoxious, nonsensical legal
disclaimers. If your company uses disclaimers, don't
use your company ID for the mailing list.

10. Do not reply to a digest. (If you are in digest
mode and want to reply to a post use ILUGC Gmane blog
interface.

Link:
http://blog.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

11. Search for answers for your questions/problems in
google.com or any other search engine before posting
your query to the mailing list.

If any of the above are not clear to you, Please read
the detailed list guidelines:

Link:
http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

12. Do not post messages in all capital letters. Mails
in CAPS is considered rude and is similar to shouting
during a conversation.

13. If you or your company is into GNU/Linux
migration, or you want help into GNU/Linux migration,
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/GNU_Linux_migration

14. If you are looking for GNU/Linux distro CDs please
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab

15. Following these guidelines could be helpful
http://people.debian.org/~enrico/dcg/

16. Don't send season's greetings or birthday invites
to the group. Its not mailing list etiquette.

We must use the above guidelines to maintain better
readability, proper archives, efficient bandwidth
usage, etc.


 
____________________________________________________________________________________
Get your email and see which of your friends are online - Right on the New Yahoo.com 
(http://www.yahoo.com/preview) 

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Nov  1 09:08:20 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Nov  1 22:38:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Intex ethernet card driver
In-Reply-To: <a0c4f6270611010411t67287647jf9bce7c126fad168@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061101170820.32224.qmail@web50204.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Kumar,

--- Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> In
> particular, MODULE_PARM

It has been replaced with module_param() since 2.5.

  http://lwn.net/Articles/107303/

synchronize_irq() has been changed in 2.6:

  http://lwn.net/Articles/23625/

> kernel: [some numbers]: Disabled IRQ #201 (or
> something similar).

Try passing "noirqdebug" to the kernel command line
when booting, and see if the problem persists.

SK

Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

mode. Still IBM Thinkpads offer a very good support for Linux.

From rhariharan at gmail.com  Thu Nov  2 10:14:27 2006
From: rhariharan at gmail.com (hari)
Date: Thu Nov  2 10:14:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Good coding style [OT]
In-Reply-To: <20061101132751.GA233@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061101074114.GC20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<20061101132751.GA233@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <895952550611012044l700447aaw50a4fa98ddd4485d@mail.gmail.com>

>
> >Even Shrodinger is supposed to owe his uncertainty theory and quantum
> mechanics to Upanishads and the Vedas.
>

OOPs...surely a mute point..but Werner Heisenberg proposed the Uncertainty
Principle.
P.A.M. Dirac and Schrodinger both developed Q.M. though in different ways,
independently.

Applying Heisenberg's uncertainty principls, good code and good coding style
may not be do-able at the same time. :))
So maybe, software firms need 2 people: one for good coding..other to make
it presentable.

I have seen people far advanced in coding logic, write horribly
incomprehensible code. I guess some people are really good at logic rather
than the style.

Like Gandhiji was supposed to have commented:
Teach your child to draw before he/she can write.

--hari

From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Thu Nov  2 06:18:21 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (sriram)
Date: Thu Nov  2 11:48:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: setting up virtual ethernet interfaces
References: <129AB497-5E69-474C-9D29-20F6E0CCEE78@thenilgiris.com>
	<20061101124852.GA19522@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <loom.20061102T061829-644@post.gmane.org>

Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@...> writes:

> On Wed, Nov 01, 2006 at 02:27:35PM +0530, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> > <snip>
> > IP: 88.198.154.216
> > Gateway: 88.198.154.217
> > Mask: 255.255.255.248
> > 
> > 
> > additional IP-Adressen:
> > 88.198.154.218 bis 88.198.154.222
> > 
> > </snip>
> > 
> > it will be noted that the 'subnet' of the additional 5 ips is  
> > different  from the main IP of my machine. So what do i do with the  
> > line in the original file that reads like this:
> > 
> > # default route to access subnet:
> > up route add -net 85.10.199.192 netmask 255.255.255.224 gw  
> > 85.10.199.193 eth0
> > 
> > what do i change it to?
> 
> Kenneth,
> 
>  If I were you I would replace the line to read
>  up route add -net 85.10.199.192 netmask 255.255.255.0 gw 85.10.199.193 eth0

which may not be the right thing to do. this appears to be a uncommon setup
(which may have a valid application, nevertheless) where the ifconfig is setting
up the local network on the host (lets call this kghost) to be 85.10.199.192/27
but the route statement routes packets to this very same subnet through the
gateway at 85.10.199.193. it would appear that this gateway at 85.10.199.193 is
connected to the host 85.10.199.207 through this interface, but other hosts in
the 85.10.199.192/27 connect to this gateway through some other means, so said
kghost has to forward packets to these other hosts to the gateway. presumably,
hosts in 85.10.199.x that are not part of 85.10.199.192/27 have some other
routing setup on kghost, perhaps the default route. doing the replacement above
would force kghost to route those also through the gateway at 85.10.199.192
which may or may not be the right thing to do. it would probably we the wrong
thing to do - cannot say for sure unless we know what the existing route on
kghost is for these hosts.

>  Remember though going by the book you should set the subnet mask to the exact
> value, due to VLSM and other funny things, such hacks actually work.

what hack? cidr (vlsm) has been around and is specified in rfc's that are more
than ten years old.

it would appear that the responder had missed the op's point about the new
addresses being in a different subnet. the old local addresses are
85.10.199.192/27 whereas the new addresses are 88.198.154.216/29. in fact, on
the basis of information given by the op, no answer can be provided. the
original route statement is there for a purpose as outlined in my above
paragraph. a similar route statement would be needed for the additional ip's if
a similar functionality is required, not otherwise. since this information is
not there in the posting, no valid advice can be given. any advice will need
full information about the existing routing to all destinations.

sriram

From brucemathew at gmail.com  Thu Nov  2 12:03:36 2006
From: brucemathew at gmail.com (Bruce Mathew)
Date: Thu Nov  2 12:03:52 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Conference on FOSS in SCIENCE
Message-ID: <1c81e6720611012233w6b0e0318xed6ff5c681fb0cb7@mail.gmail.com>

Dear and Respected Friends

Union Christian College,Alwaye, Kerala is organising a 3-day
Conference on FOSS in Science which focus on the concept of FOSS and
its relevance in Science Subjects. The college has started a FOSS Cell
to make aware about FOSS and its Potentials to the academia. This is a
new venture of our College.

The Conference on FOSS in SCIENCE covers aspects like
1. Knowledge management & Free Software
2. Scientific Computing and Data Visualisation using Python
3. Advanced Modelling
4. Experimental Physics with Phoenix
5. Scientific Research with LaTex
6. Free Software Tools
7. Colloborative development, Social Networking and Informal education
8. Colloborative development with CVS
9. Free Software for Mathematics.


Eminent Resource Persons like Dr Nagarjuna [ TIFR, Mumbai ], Dr.
Prabhu Ramachandran [ IIT Bombay], Dr. Manoj Warrier [ Institute of
Plasma Research, Gandhinagar] Dr. E Krishnan [ Kerala University ],
Dr. V Sasikumar [ CESS ]
etc has confirmed their participation.

Dr. S Sadagopan [ IIIT B ] will deliver a key note address.

Those interested to participate in this workshop, please feel free to
contact me.
 Hope this will be a succesfull venture

-- 
Mr. Bruce Mathew
Lecturer - Placement Officer
MCA Dept.
Union Christian College
Aluva 683102
www.mcaucc.org

> (which may have a valid application, nevertheless) where the ifconfig is setting

> but the route statement routes packets to this very same subnet through the

> connected to the host 85.10.199.207 through this interface, but other hosts in
> the 85.10.199.192/27 connect to this gateway through some other means, so said

> >  Remember though going by the book you should set the subnet mask to the exact
> > value, due to VLSM and other funny things, such hacks actually work.

> what hack? cidr (vlsm) has been around and is specified in rfc's that are more
> than ten years old.

Thanks. I did not know that.

> 
> it would appear that the responder had missed the op's point about the new
> addresses being in a different subnet. the old local addresses are
> 85.10.199.192/27 whereas the new addresses are 88.198.154.216/29. in fact, on
> the basis of information given by the op, no answer can be provided. the
> original route statement is there for a purpose as outlined in my above
> paragraph. a similar route statement would be needed for the additional ip's if
> a similar functionality is required, not otherwise. since this information is
> not there in the posting, no valid advice can be given. any advice will need
> full information about the existing routing to all destinations.

Sorry I don't follow you. I have been able to make multiple subnets talk to each other using a 255.255.0.0 mask wherein the actual subnets had more restrictive masks say 255.255.255.0 or something.

I kind of get your reasoning but I have more doubts than clarity.

Anyway I think this is not too big an issue to worry about.

AFAIK routers actually use longest prefix match to shove packets into the right interface. So I am guessing it might just work.

Hope Kenneth gets his computers talk to each other. 

regards,
Girish

From b.ghose at gnu.org  Thu Nov  2 14:54:37 2006
From: b.ghose at gnu.org (Baishampayan Ghose)
Date: Thu Nov  2 14:54:37 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good coding style
In-Reply-To: <20061101074114.GC20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061101074114.GC20033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <4549B955.1060001@gnu.org>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Wednesday 01 November 2006 01:11 PM, Girish Venkatachalam cobbled
together some glyphs to say:
Girish,
> 	I have often found proprietary C code to be really ugly and badly indented, formatted with all sorts of funny variable naming conventions.
> 
> 	And people get so pedantic about useless topics like beginning every function with a Capital letter and using huge function names.
> 
> 	Really it is not important beyond a point.
> 
> 	C is an extremely expressive beautiful language almost like the grammar of Panini.
> 
> 	So write beautiful code. Writing readable and maintainable code is much more important than proper commenting.

That's true. These days I see people (mostly students) who don't care
about properly indenting their code at all. They think that ``if it
runs, then it must be ok''. It's hard to explain the issues of code
maintainability to them. Personally I believe using any sane programming
editor (like GNU Emacs or ViM) solves most of the problem. Sometimes you
 may also need to beautify code written by other people, and in those
situations `indent` comes handy. I use `indent` with the following
switches --
indent -npro -sc -br -ce -cli2 -cbi0 -bap -psl -bad -i8 -nut -sob -l75
- -ss -ncs -nlp

That is my own style which is a hybrid of K&R & the GNU style. I hope it
is useful ...

Regards,
BG

- --
Baishampayan Ghose <b.ghose@gnu.org>
The GNU Project
http://www.gnu.org/

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Sun Nov  5 16:15:22 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sun Nov  5 16:15:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Gentoo Linux, NetBSD,
	OpenBSD and FreeBSD on the same SATA hard disk
Message-ID: <20061105104522.GA26070@lakshmi.susmita.org>

Hello Guys,

      I wonder if you guys remember; long time ago there was a conclusion that since an i386 MBR partition table can hold only 4 primary partitions and since most common OSes can only boot from an active primary partition the practical limit for multi boot is 4. 4 per hard disk.

      This is what I did. I have a 160 GB SATA disk with a spanking new Celeron processor and some M5VM800 motherboard. Anyway I give details to emphasize the fact that this is brand new BIOS.

      Now, restrictions on booting beyond a certain cylinder limit is imposed mostly by BIOS though some OSes also have/had this issue.

      And remember that whatever you read about this from anywhere on Internet is not trustworthy. As always a healthy dose of skepticism is your best friend...

      Anyway coming back to the point, I installed gentoo on the first 40 GB of the disk. Then I installed NetBSD on the second 40 GB. OpenBSD on the third and finally FreeBSD on the remaining 40 GB.

      Now, by no means is this non trivial. Please don't think you can try this without understanding how the hard disk is partitioned, what is the meaning of cylinders,tracks,head and sectors and the nuances and differences between how various OSes report these values.

      Also you should thoroughly understand BSD disklabels and how this differs from traditional linux or Windoze partitions.

      Quite simply disklabeling happens inside fdisk partitions. i.e., each of the FreeBSD,NetBSD and OpenBSD fdisk partitions you see below contain individual /, /usr, /home mount points inside each respective fdisk partitions using BSD disklabeling partitioning.

      IOW I am trying my level best to tell you that it is not humanly possible to explain everything to you. There are several corner cases and dark corners that I have not run into.

      Prior familiarity with installing each of the individual OSes does help but it is not mandatory as long as you understand the CHS partitioning, disklableling etc.

      Of course I installed grub on the MBR of the disk and I used gentoo grub. Grub is shipped with BSDs also but I used gentoo grub.

      Here is my grub.conf.

<<<<grub.conf>>>>
      
default 0
timeout 10

splashimage=(hd0,0)/grub/splash.xpm.gz

title Gentoo Linux
root (hd0,0)
kernel /boot/kernel root=/dev/sda1

title NetBSD
root (hd0,1)
chainloader +1
makeactive

title OpenBSD
root (hd0,2)
chainloader +1
makeactive

title FreeBSD
root (hd0,3)
chainloader +1
makeactive

<<<<grub.conf>>>>

     As you can see it is really easy to interpret it. I found that FreeBSD boot manager also can boot all OSes except linux. So I just reverted back to grub. Remember things will go wrong but make sure that you know what you are doing.

     Always be prepared to boot into the disk with a liveCD or gentoo bootCD(which itself is a liveCD) and then mount the appropriate partition, chroot into it and diddle around with grub...

     One thing that you should take especial care of is the fact that each o f the four primary partitions don't overlap and that they begin on cylinder boundaries.

     I am trying my level best to explain but as you can see this is not something that can easily be done. Experience is the only way.

     But prepare yourself well by arming yourself with good theoretical clarity.

     I shall endeavor to do exactly that.

     A hard disk is nothing but a bunch of vertically stacked rings or platters sitting on a spindle. Each platter has two heads on either sides. And each ring is split into multiple concentric circles called tracks.

     Each track is split into multiple sectors, yes same geometric concept. It is an arc.

     And tracks are aggregated into cylinders.

     It took me a very long time to understand this clearly. So please be patient. But once you understand it it is all very simple. :-)

     Each sector holds exactly 512 bytes.

     Another confusing aspect is that no modern BIOS cares about CHS translation as it is always LBA and it is also true that real geometry has very little to do with the geometry reported by various partitioning software. And each OS displays the same info in a different way.

     But it is not as complicated as I make it sound. Really.

     There is a certain consistency and the numbers match in a near about manner. Exact match doesn't always happen. For instance my NetBSD installer showed the disk capacity as 157 GB instead of 164 GB inside disklabel though at other places it showed the right value.

      Here is my linux fdisk output.

#fdisk -lu /dev/sda ( Remember it is SATA disk, for you it might be /dev/hda)

Disk /dev/sda: 164.6 GB, 164695473664 bytes
255 heads, 63 sectors/track, 20023 cylinders, total 321670847 sectors
Units = sectors of 1 * 512 = 512 bytes

   Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
/dev/sda1              63    78124094    39062016   83  Linux
/dev/sda2        78124095   160055594    40965750   a9  NetBSD
/dev/sda3       160055595   242308394    41126400   a6  OpenBSD
/dev/sda4   *   242308395   321669494    39680550   a5  FreeBSD


#fdisk -l /dev/sda



Disk /dev/sda: 164.6 GB, 164695473664 bytes
255 heads, 63 sectors/track, 20023 cylinders
Units = cylinders of 16065 * 512 = 8225280 bytes

   Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
/dev/sda1               1        4863    39062016   83  Linux
/dev/sda2            4864        9963    40965750   a9  NetBSD
/dev/sda3            9964       15083    41126400   a6  OpenBSD
/dev/sda4   *       15084       20023    39680550   a5  FreeBSD

If you notice you will find that each of the four primary partitions don't actually overlap in any way and that each partition starts at a cylinder boundary.

Already it has got really technical and too intellectually stressful, so I will stop here.

One technical tip is that it is very easy to edit the fdisk and disklabels using raw sectors since that way you can easily figure out which partition you are dealing with.

For instance, if you know that the OpenBSD region on the disk is between sectors 25000000 and 3500000 then you know that each of the disklabel partitions should lie within this limit.

I have found excellent correlation between the raw sectors reported by each OS's fdisk output. And pay particular attention to the partition type. Linux is 0x83,NetBSD type is A9 (It used to be A5 before), FreeBSD partition type is A5 and OpenBSD's is A6.

Disk labeling is for BSD mount points and operate on a particular partition type, say A5 or A6. Since disklabels sit inside fdisk primary partitions.


Not talking of swap space and accessing each other's file systems, it is really not an issue once you get this right. I shall talk about it in the article.

I will write a detailed easy to understand article on this in a little while.

Wish you best of luck!

Best,
Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] Mouse Configuration in X
Message-ID: <9bdf087b0611050452q2bdf01bdm9d392b42889501fc@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

I have a MS comfort optical mouse 3000 which has a tilt wheel (scroll
left and right, up and down) and a thumb button in addition to the
left and right buttons. Right now in my Ubuntu install, the mouse is
working with these options - left click, right click, up/down scroll
and the thumb button works as left click. I want to configure the
mouse to enable the tilt function and use the thumb button as middle
click.

My current xorg.conf entry for mouse:

Section "InputDevice"
    Identifier     "Configured Mouse"
    Driver         "mouse"
    Option         "CorePointer"
    Option         "Device" "/dev/input/mice"
    Option         "Protocol" "ExplorerPS/2"
    Option         "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
EndSection

Can anyone give me some pointers on how to enable the tilt wheel and
the thumb button?

-- 
Regards,
Satish

On Sun, Nov 05, 2006 at 03:34:45AM -0800, ???.????????????????????? wrote:
> 1) What is GTK? How is GTK related with GNOME?
> 2) What is QT? How is it related with KDE?

Localization folks are most well versed in these things.

Anyway I shall contribute my mite.

Usually applications are layered on top of libraries that expose an API. This makes stuff well layered, well organized and clean.

And nearly 75% of the logic and code rests with the library. This library may be statically or dynamically linked(two types of dyn linking), and can be shared blah blah blah

So QT library implements the bulk of the infrastructure that KDE uses.

GTK library does the same thing for GNOME.

On Sunday 05 November 2006 05:04 PM, ?.??????? cobbled together some
glyphs to say:
> 1) What is GTK? How is GTK related with GNOME?

GTk+ is a high-level, cross platform GUI toolkit using which GUI
applications can be written. GTk+ itself is written in C but it provides
bindings for other languages as well like C++ (gtkmm), Python (PyGTk),
Java (java-gnome), Perl (gtk-perl), etc.
GTk+ was created for writing the GIMP, and then it was adopted and
enhanced by the GNOME team for creating GNOME. The GNOME project uses
GTk+ almost exclusively (in addition to some GNOME specific libs) to
write all GNOME applications. All GNOME apps are written in GTk+ no
matter which language is used to write the actual application. That
renders the distinct look and feel to all GNOME applications.
URL - http://gtk.org and http://gnome.org/

> 2) What is QT? How is it related with KDE?

Qt is yet another high-level, cross platform GUI toolkit created by a
Norwegian company Trolltech. Qt is mainly written in C++ but it has
bindings for different languages too. The KDE project uses Qt
exclusively for writing all KDE applications (again, no matter which
language is used for a specific app).
URL - http://www.trolltech.com/products/qt/ and http://kde.org/

Hope that helps,
Regards,
BG

- --
Baishampayan Ghose <b.ghose@gnu.org>
The GNU Project
http://www.gnu.org/

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Sun Nov  5 20:54:28 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sun Nov  5 20:54:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] renaming folders
In-Reply-To: <op.tijrc0n64o0vlx@ubuntu>
References: <op.tijrc0n64o0vlx@ubuntu>
Message-ID: <20061105152428.GA15186@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sun, Nov 05, 2006 at 07:48:26PM +0530, baluk wrote:
> I have about 99 subfolders within another folder .The subfolders start  
> with the prefix 01 and continues to 99.Now I need to rename them as 001 to  
> 099.I tried reading about it  but got confused. How do i go about it..any  
> help will be appreciatated.
> some numbers are also missing.. like after 03 it jumps to 07.

This should help.

#!/usr/bin/perl

use File::Glob ':glob';

for $i  (1 .. 99) {

	local ($cur,$new) = ();
	$cur = sprintf( "%02d", $i);
	$new = sprintf("%03d",$i);
	$curname = bsd_glob ("$cur*");

	if ( $curname == "" ) {
		next;   
	}

	$curname =~ /\d+(.*)/;
	$cursuffix = $1;
	$newname = "$new . $cursuffix"; 
	` mv $curname $newname `;

}


regards,
Girish

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Sun Nov  5 20:56:04 2006
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Chandrashekar=20Babu?=)
Date: Sun Nov  5 21:03:30 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] renaming folders
Message-ID: <20061105152605.7927.qmail@server301.com>

Hi,
 
>  I have about 99 subfolders within another folder .The subfolders start  
>  with the prefix 01 and continues to 99.Now I need to rename them as 001 to  
>  099.I tried reading about it  but got confused. How do i go about it..

Assuming that you're using Bourne-compatible shell, the 
following command should do:

   for i in [0-9][0-9]; do mv $i 0$i; done

Cheers!

Chandrashekar Babu.,
FOSS Technologist,
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Sun Nov  5 21:07:14 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (R.Ramkumar)
Date: Sun Nov  5 21:07:56 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] renaming folders
In-Reply-To: <op.tijrc0n64o0vlx@ubuntu>
References: <op.tijrc0n64o0vlx@ubuntu>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170611050737t173228e1lb23e719752a966ec@mail.gmail.com>

> I have about 99 subfolders within another folder .The subfolders start
> with the prefix 01 and continues to 99.Now I need to rename them as 001 to
> 099.I tried reading about it  but got confused. How do i go about it..any
> help will be appreciatated.
> some numbers are also missing.. like after 03 it jumps to 07.
> balu

rename 's/(.*)([0-9][0-9])/\10\2/' *

(this is on Debian, I remember one more version on Redhat which used
to use glob patterns... don't remember the syntax exactly)

or on zsh: zmv -W '*[0-9][0-9]' '*0**'

it moves on...

-- 
One of the main causes of the fall of the Roman Empire
was that, lacking zero, they had no way to indicate
successful termination of their C programs.
                             -- Robert Firth
From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Sun Nov  5 21:11:38 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (R.Ramkumar)
Date: Sun Nov  5 21:11:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] renaming folders
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170611050737t173228e1lb23e719752a966ec@mail.gmail.com>

oops.. thought it was suffixes... here's the change..

> rename 's/(.*)([0-9][0-9])/\10\2/' *

rename 's/([0-9][0-9])(.*)/0\1\2/' *

> or on zsh: zmv -W '*[0-9][0-9]' '*0**'

zmv -W '[0-9][0-9]*' '0***'

anyway, if its a prefix, a simple for loop should do...

for i in [0-9][0-9]*; do mv $i 0$i; done

it moves on...

Are you sure you want to use C for backend? There are some very good 
bindings for gtk (this is what I prefer) in both Python and Ruby. Though 
PyGTK seems very popular, I haven't tried it. But I did try Ruby-Gnome2

to get started. If you're on Ubuntu, the bindings install is as simple 
as sudo apt-get install ruby-gnome2 and you're on:

http://ruby-gnome2.sourceforge.jp/

Gambas of course, is the point-and-click way of doing the same thing 
(and using basic-like language to tie it all together - eww).

From: akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in (Kumar Appaiah)
Date: Mon Nov  6 08:31:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Doubt in GPL licence
In-Reply-To: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

On 06/11/06, Anandh G <anandhg02@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Redhat has developed the Redhat Directory Service(RDS)
> based on openLDAP. Redhat would used the source code
> from OpenLDAP for RDS, but is RDS under GPL. If so
> will they give the source code of RDS free for use,
> modify and redistribute.

If I understand your question correctly:
If RDS is under the GPL, that means Red Hat is bound to give you the
source code if you ask them. Similarly, if you modify the source and
redistribute the program, I guess you must also release the modified
source under the same (GPL) license.

> Also one more example is Redhat Application stack
> which has RHEL,JBoss,Apache,Mysql or Postgresql. But
> in this package Apache, Mysql,etc are under GPL
> licence and available free for use,modify and
> redistribute. But how about the Redhat Application
> stack package itself. IS this package also same as the others.

Apache is certainly not GPLed. MySQL is available under a non-GPL
license as well, which may not require you to disclose modified
source; but I don't know too much about these legal issues.

Kumar

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 08:50:00 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Mon Nov  6 08:53:48 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Doubt in GPL licence
In-Reply-To: <a0c4f6270611051900sea3386bieba420bc788a7b9f@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<a0c4f6270611051900sea3386bieba420bc788a7b9f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <454EA9E0.3080601@gmail.com>

Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> On 06/11/06, Anandh G <anandhg02@yahoo.com> wrote:
>> Redhat has developed the Redhat Directory Service(RDS)
>> based on openLDAP. Redhat would used the source code
>> from OpenLDAP for RDS, but is RDS under GPL. If so
>> will they give the source code of RDS free for use,
>> modify and redistribute.
> 
> If I understand your question correctly:
> If RDS is under the GPL, that means Red Hat is bound to give you the
> source code if you ask them. Similarly, if you modify the source and
> redistribute the program, I guess you must also release the modified
> source under the same (GPL) license.
> 
++1. Any modification done to a GPLed software make it necessary to 
release the source code of the modified software with it.

>> Also one more example is Redhat Application stack
>> which has RHEL,JBoss,Apache,Mysql or Postgresql. But
>> in this package Apache, Mysql,etc are under GPL
>> licence and available free for use,modify and
>> redistribute. But how about the Redhat Application
>> stack package itself. IS this package also same as the others.
> 
> Apache is certainly not GPLed. MySQL is available under a non-GPL
> license as well, which may not require you to disclose modified
> source; but I don't know too much about these legal issues.

This is something I learnt some time back. When you create a new 
software using GPLed softwares, say MySQL, then it depends on whether 
you modified the MySQL's code whether you have to release the modified 
source code or not. What I mean to say is,

[1] if you use a GPLed software for your/within your software as it is, 
without any modifications, then you need not provide the source code of 
*that* software (not *yours* software).

[2] Instead, if you going to modify the GPLed software, then it is 
mandatory to release the modified source code of the GPLed software you 
use.

[3] But, this doesn't mean you *have* to release the source code of your 
software, even when you are using GPLed softwares as a part of the 
overall software.

[4] It entirely depends on the license of your software, that you need 
to/need not give away the source code.

The reason for [1] is mainly because, if your are using a GPLed software 
then its source code is freely available from the corresponding 
software's web site / repos, that you need not provide it with your 
software. But, if your going to modify a GPLed software, then the 
license makes it necessary for you to release the modified source code, 
but only of the software you modified.

This is behind a lot of softwares, which are not Open Source rather 
closed, using other FOSS/GPLed softwares in them and still remain closed.

I may have been wrong in some points, but as a whole think my 
understanding is right ?! :)


-- 
With Regards

Parthan (TechnoFreak)

.   A Proud GNU/Linux User and Ubuntero
.0.

000 [Blog]http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com
From rajagopal.n at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 09:26:07 2006
From: rajagopal.n at gmail.com (Rajagopal Natarajan)
Date: Mon Nov  6 09:26:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to create Daemons
In-Reply-To: <20061106030354.38816.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061106030354.38816.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <e0900f3e0611051956mf496d37te833e923485a1532@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/6/06, Amit Dey <eamitdey@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> I have never used Daemons before. But I think they are the Linux
> equivalent of Windows Servies.


Yes.

Services in Windows are analogous to daemons in Linux/UNIX. When running
Linux daemons, the system admin chooses the user the daemon runs as. Admins
that are focused on security tend to create separate user accounts for every
daemon that's run. Each of these user accounts has its permisions in the
filesystem set so the daemon only has access to files and directories that
are absolutely required.

In the diagram below, the named daemon is runing as a user called *named*.
The ntpd daemon runs as user *ntpd* and the httpd daemon runs as user *httpd
*. User named only has permissions to access the /var/lib/named directory.
It cannot access any of the other two directories. A successful attack
against daemon named does not affect the /var/lib/ntpd or /var/lib/httpd
directories - or any other directory on the system.
[image: Linux daemons]

A successful attack against a vulnerable daemon tends to only impact that
daemon and its corresponding parts of the filesystem. Other parts of the
system are insulated from the attack.

Windows services often run as priviledged users with access to most or all
of the rest of the system. Successful attacks result in the entire computer
being compromised.

Source: http://www.biznix.org/articles/winlinsecure.html

Google keyword for the page "linux daemons vs windows services"


    More importantly how do we create daemons(Is there any library/API) and
> how do we install them. It would be great if you could suggest me some
> links.
>

Again, a simple Googling gives you the answer. Keyword "Creating Daemons"
 http://www.linuxprofilm.com/articles/linux-daemon-howto.html


Welcome to ILUGC :)


-- 
N. Rajagopal,
Visit me at http://www.rajagopal.tk
From vamlists at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 09:39:49 2006
From: vamlists at gmail.com (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Mon Nov  6 09:40:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: GUI on Linux
In-Reply-To: <1162802379.5474.4.camel@localhost>
References: <20061106020540.87EC21DB27A@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<1162802379.5474.4.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <454EB58D.90205@gmail.com>

amit saha wrote:
> The backend development is almost finished in C and we are doing some
> low-level networking stuff. That is why i would prefer the backend to
> remain C. So can i mix up C backend and Python or Ruby - frontend ?
>
>   

Certainly - you can use mkmf to tie up c code with Ruby. You might find 
this article helpful:

http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2004/11/18/extending_ruby.html

You might also want to get a copy of the 'Pickaxe book' - the first 
edition is available free online. Here's the relevant chapter:

http://www.rubycentral.com/book/ext_ruby.html



Vamsee.

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 09:46:23 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Mon Nov  6 09:49:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to create Daemons
In-Reply-To: <20061106030354.38816.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061106030354.38816.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061106041623.GA9449@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sun, Nov 05, 2006 at 07:03:54PM -0800, Amit Dey wrote:
> I have never used Daemons before. But I think they are the Linux equivalent of Windows Servies.
>    
>   So does an installed daemon start automatically at startup. How can we change the settings for a daemon.
>    
>   More importantly how do we create daemons(Is there any library/API) and how do we install them. It would be great if you could suggest me some links.

Hi Amit,

   Daemons are an integral part of UNIX culture and the BSD logo itself is derived from the BSD "demon" which sounds like daemon.

   It is thought of as black magic or sorcery since it silently sits in the background and does all the work for you. 

   It used to be a standard interview question "How to create  a daemon in UNIX?"

   But today you have the daemon(3) library call that does it automatically for you.

   It is a concept very easy to imagine and understand.

   Take the simple case of a web server.

   It is supposed to serve web pages and handle requests that arrive at port 80 in http or port 443 for https.

   There is no need for the web server to interact with the user or run on a terminal right?

   It is just like a sentry waiting at a port and services users.

   The fact that most of the users are remotely accessing services using TCP/IP is significant. 

   If you understand the concept underlying it, then details are only details and nothing more. :-)

   Without daemons UNIX systems are more or less useless. So the very idea of daemons are central to the UNIX philosophy whereas in Windoze I am sure services came as an afterthought...

   Anyway Rajagopal gave a nice explanation and I learnt lot of new details.

   Hope this helps.

   Should you have any more questions you are of course welcome to ask.

   But your best bet would be to study some good book say "UNIX network programming" by Richard L Stevens or some simpler book. That book is far too geeky for basics.

   You may be able to get some good website. Ask a UNIX guru whom you respect.

   I don't think mailing lists can clear fundamental doubts so easily.

   All the best!

   And of course welcome to the beautiful world of UNIX. :)

   regards,
   Girish
From girihastha at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 09:57:30 2006

V.V.Giri

Hi Raju,
> "Problems opening perspective 'org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaPerspective'
More possible that the extraction was not proper, especially if the
file was not executable in the first place! I am guessing that.

Java perspective is built into eclipse, so cannot be a separate
plugin. Just check the plugins directory for any directory named
org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaPerspective. If it is there, open the
plugin.xml in it and see if there are any path references, (must not
be).
> If i try to open .java file i get this error
> "Unable to create this part due to an internal error. Reason for the
> failure: The editor class could not be instantiated. This usually indicates
> that the editor's class name was mistyped in plugin.xml."
Exactly, more or less a typo in the plugin.xml. Where did you get this
eclipse anyway?
I ll probably give the issue dates of lfy where eclipse was bundled
in. I use it and it works like magic. Moreover, if it is too early a
version of eclipse (maybe 3.0 and less) and you are not using java
1.4, you could end up with instantiation errors. But, I am not sure of
this case either.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Nov  6 10:30:43 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon Nov  6 10:31:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to create Daemons
In-Reply-To: <20061106041623.GA9449@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061106030354.38816.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20061106041623.GA9449@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <454EC17B.1010702@frodo.hserus.net>

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
>    Daemons are an integral part of UNIX culture and the BSD logo itself is derived from the BSD "demon" which sounds like daemon.
> 
>    It is thought of as black magic or sorcery since it silently sits in the background and does all the work for you. 

He is probably asking that to prepare for an interview .. but the name
"Daemon" is not because of black magic or sorcery.  Think physics /
thermodynamics.

It is a reference to James Clerk Maxwell's 1867 proposition of Maxwell's
Daemon, which seemed to violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics.  [and
that's an old spelling for the word demon].

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell's_demon

http://www.multicians.org/thvv/7094.html?1

http://mail.computerhistory.org/pipermail/inforoots/2005-November/000979.html

Back during the 1960s, Prof Fernando Corbato and his team at MIT ran
"PROJECT MAC" on an IBM 7094 mainframe - which was more or less where
MULTICS originated.

The MIT people got that machine  on one condition .. the CEO of IBM at
that time (probably Vin Learson, who followed Tom Watson Jr. as CEO)
used to take part in yacht races, and had a program, or rather a job
deck (a set of punched cards), that'd calculate handicaps for various
yachts in a race.

Whenever that guy asked, Prof Corbato's team had to stop everything
running on that machine [which was running a timesharing system called
CTSS for job scheduling], and immediately load that handicap calculating
program deck.

That was basically the reason they developed the concept of a "daemon"
to put a job in the background and keep running it, rather than to kill
the currently running job in order to run that yacht program deck.

	suresh

In-Reply-To: <454EC17B.1010702@frodo.hserus.net>

On Mon, Nov 06, 2006 at 10:30:43AM +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
> He is probably asking that to prepare for an interview .. but the name
> "Daemon" is not because of black magic or sorcery.  Think physics /
> thermodynamics.
[snip]

Suresh,

	Thanks for the colorful history. 

	What I meant by black magic is that it is something difficult for newbies to understand. There was a time when kernel programming, kernel compilation, even sockets programming, nearly every single non trivial technical topic was looked upon as the handiwork of the devil...

	That is what I meant. Nothing with reference to daemon in particular.

	I wanted to emphasize the power and magic involved in this. 

	If P C Sorcar makes a train disappear we think of that as magic.

	Same way when Houdini escaped from the milk can everyone thought of it as magic.

	Now we know that it was Houdini's exceptionally strong shoulders and ability to open locks that accounted for this apparent "magic."

	Similarly until one learns C programming in the true sense everything appears incomprehensible and magical.

	What to talk of C? 

	My goodness, I have been programming in C for so many years now and I don't think I understand even 80% of it.

regards,
Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 12:51:34 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Mon Nov  6 12:51:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Request for assistance
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0611052050o424de4f8xa52e7c1daf97ebe3@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0611052050o424de4f8xa52e7c1daf97ebe3@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061106072134.GB13861@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Mon, Nov 06, 2006 at 10:20:34AM +0530, Shrinivasan T wrote:
> Hi
> 
> >Please guide me on where and how to go about learning
> >it and becoming developement worthy.
> 
> I did google search and got this link.
> http://lwn.net/Kernel/LDD3/
> 
> Linux Device Drivers, Third Edition
> by Jonathan Corbet, Alessandro Rubini, and Greg Kroah-Hartman

Quite frankly I found the device driver book to be somewhat advanced or rather not easy to relate to.

Having come from 8051 background I suggest you just take up a small hardware interfacing project either using the serial or parallel port or if you feel  ambitious enough the USB port.

Learn x86 assembly if you feel like. It is not reqd but coming from uC background this might be something you can relate to easily. Then there are some low level C I/O routines in linux inb(2) ,outb(2) and so on(man inb). Of course you can embed assembly code into your normal C program. I am assuming that you know C quite well since many embedded systems are programmed in C.

Then focus on character drivers and character devices first.

Just learn the serial protocol and interface something really simple like an LED array or something. 

Going from practice to theory may be faster in your case since you already have enough experience and an appreciation of hardware interfacing.

Once you get your hands dirty then pick up the book and read. It should make far more sense then.

Hope this helps.

Please post questions to the list so we can know how you are doing. :)

Wish you best of luck! 

regards,
Girish

 Hi
 
 I am Sudhakar BOSS GNU/Liunx developer,NRCFOSS,Chennai.hereby find the
 Link where I have uploaded SCIM related packages modified for BOSS
 GNU/Linux .... with newly added Remington (Pure Typewriter ) Keyboard
 layout for Tamil,Hindi,Punjabi and Marathi languages.It installs and works
 fine over Debian sarge and etch also.
 
 1.Type of Keyboard Layout in Tamil
 
     a.Remington Keyboard *****(Newly Added)
 
 2.Type of Keyboard Layout in Hindi
 
     a.Remington Keyboard *****(Newly Added)
 
 3.Type of Keyboard Layout in Punjabi
 
     a.Remington Keyboard *****(Newly Added)
 
 4.Type of Keyboard Layout in Marathi
 
     a.Remington Keyboard *****(Newly Added)
 
 
 Download scim 
 
 http://203.129.255.181/BOSS/Localisation/
 
 Follow the below steps for install and working with scim
 
 How to Install scim:
 
 1.Download SCIM Related packages and a file "75custom-scim_init" from the
 link given above
 2. copy the file "75custom-scim_init" downloaded into the path
vi "/etc/X11/Xsession.d"
 2.Install scim packages 
      $ dpkg -i scim*
 3.Logout and login 
 
 How to Work with SCIM:
 
 1. open any graphical editor (Gedit or Openoffice)
 2. press ctrl+space ( you will get SCIM toggling panel at the right bottom
 of your desktop)
 3.select the language  and work with that (Input will the langauge you
 have selected)
 
 ** Make sure you have the corressponding langauage font you need installed
 in you system
 
 
 BOSS GNU/Linux is available for BETA testing .. Download BOSS
     
     1.Install CD
     2.Live CD
     3.Utility CD
     
 from    
     http://203.129.255.181/BOSS/

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

From sbharathi at midascomm.com  Mon Nov  6 17:38:37 2006
From: sbharathi at midascomm.com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Mon Nov  6 17:39:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [JOB] Fwd: PHP Programmers
Message-ID: <36855.203.199.213.67.1162814917.squirrel@203.199.213.67>

E-Nova Technologies, a small IT company based in Tamil Nadu, Madras,
is currently looking for at least two experienced PHP programmers to
work on challenging and rewarding projects. Apply at
job@enova-tech.net.

Job Description:
We are looking for serious and talented individuals willing to work
in an informal environment  (E-Nova is an equal opportunities
employer). This position will be especially interesting for those
who value freedom, enjoy responsabilities and wants to take
activepart in the decision process. We are looking for fresh and
experienced
programmers, ideally active on the free software scene, however this
experience doesn't have to be necessarely professional -  personal
and student projects will be given due credit. This position can
lead to higher responsibility on demonstration of compentence.

Salary starts at 8k/month but open to negotiation depending on
experience and competencies. Please note that fluency in spoken
English is not a major criteria as long as the candidate can make
her/himself understood.

Minimum competency required:
Php programming (version 4 and 5).
MVC paradigm & Design Pattern understanding.
SQL.
HTML.
Basic knowledge of linux.

Optional competencies (would be rewarded with valuable bonus):
Postgresql or PL/SQL.
AJAX.
XHTML & CSS.
Experience with a template engine (smarty).
Subversion (SVN)
UML / Merise (or any analysis and design method).
Proven graphic design skills.
Spoken and/or written French.

Advantages:
5 working days per week, no strict timetable (as long as the
objectives are fullfilled). Paid leave of absence upto 20 working
days in a year Free French language courses (if desired) and more

About E-Nova Technologies,
E-Nova Technologies is a young and promising structure working
closely with the open-source community, producing multimedia
software (like educative videogames)  dubbing software, e-learning
solutions (see. www.clickonfrench.com) and new generation e-business
websites.

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

transactions to take place less risk as we know each other as a community.

this list become the official mailing list of Ritchie Street.

this list under the [COMMERCIAL] tag saying their CPU's/MOBO's deals
are LINUX compatible.

Python-twisted. Best and easiest way to learn network programming. If
you are a python newbie, you will even pickup some py-skills.

website: twistedmatrix.com
A free book is available on the topic.

On Mon, Nov 06, 2006 at 06:55:35PM +0530, Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
> On 11/6/06, Amit Dey <eamitdey@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >No, I am not asking the question for an interview. I am still a third year 
> >engineering student and inteviews are atleast an year away.
> >
> >  Anyway, I wanted to know about daemons because I was wondering about how 
> >  SAMBA works ? Actually I was thinking whether i could make something 
> >  like SAMBA but with a lot of extra features.
> >
> >  But thanks to all of you guys, I have gained a basic understanding of 
> >  what a daemon is.
> 
> Python-twisted. Best and easiest way to learn network programming. If
> you are a python newbie, you will even pickup some py-skills.
> 
> website: twistedmatrix.com
> A free book is available on the topic.

No, python would be too slow for this sort of thing.

Anyway Amit, 
       There is a saying I am sure you have head.

       "Don't bite off more than what you can chew."

       You can only eat one meal at a time. If you want to build strong muscles, you can't do it in a day. It takes months.

       Samba was written by Andrew Tridgell after substantial hard work, sacrifice and technical plumbing and what not. In fact he quite frankly admits how hard a time he had when both he and his wife were doing a Phd while he was working on rsync.

       He is a physics graduate nothing to do with computers. But he has also done hardware hacking with Tivo.

       If you think you can do better than him please think twice.

       Nothing wrong in aiming for the moon, but one baby step at a time.

       I definitely do not mean to discourage you or anyone else in the list.
       But for heaven's sake be practical.

       If not anything else at least know yourself properly.

       What you can do , your energy levels, interest coefficient, where you stand with respect to the other smart folks on earth etc...

       That is why I love open source. Because in corporates it is very very easy to imagine that you are the smartest guy on earth since mostly it is politics and individual charisma and hierarchy that dictates technical respect.

       Whereas in the wild Internet marketplace, though there is politics you cannot in general get away with substandard code.

       So my advice to you Amit would be to wait and learn things. Don't jump into anything just because you find it cool.

       Try out simple projects first. You can start with answering questions on ilugc for instance.

       That will give you some confidence. Or if you are still unsure you can browse the archives for the simple students projects mail that I had sent to ilugc.

       Ppl mutilated me without understanding that I gave simple projects that students could do. Not some high sounding stuff to show my knowledge! :)

       You could pick one. Or do open ended learning and spend time with yourself thinking and try out various open source software that are simple to use and understand.

       Anyway enough said.

       Best of luck!

       If you really end up doing better than Tridge no one will be happier than us because someone from India doing such a great thing is no doubt a matter of immense pride.

       But at the same time let us be realistic.

regards,
Girish

On 11/5/06, Baishampayan Ghose <b.ghose@gnu.org> wrote:
>
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
>
> On Sunday 05 November 2006 05:04 PM, ?.??????? cobbled together some
> glyphs to say:
> > 1) What is GTK? How is GTK related with GNOME?
>
> GTk+ is a high-level, cross platform GUI toolkit using which GUI
> applications can be written. GTk+ itself is written in C but it provides
> bindings for other languages as well like C++ (gtkmm), Python (PyGTk),
> Java (java-gnome), Perl (gtk-perl), etc.
> GTk+ was created for writing the GIMP, and then it was adopted and
> enhanced by the GNOME team for creating GNOME. The GNOME project uses
> GTk+ almost exclusively (in addition to some GNOME specific libs) to
> write all GNOME applications. All GNOME apps are written in GTk+ no
> matter which language is used to write the actual application. That
> renders the distinct look and feel to all GNOME applications.
> URL - http://gtk.org and http://gnome.org/
>
> > 2) What is QT? How is it related with KDE?
>
> Qt is yet another high-level, cross platform GUI toolkit created by a
> Norwegian company Trolltech. Qt is mainly written in C++ but it has
> bindings for different languages too. The KDE project uses Qt
> exclusively for writing all KDE applications (again, no matter which
> language is used for a specific app).
> URL - http://www.trolltech.com/products/qt/ and http://kde.org/
>
> Hope that helps,
> Regards,
> BG
>
> - --
> Baishampayan Ghose <b.ghose@gnu.org>
> The GNU Project
> http://www.gnu.org/
>

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

From binand at gmail.com  Mon Nov  6 22:46:28 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Nov  6 22:46:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Doubt in GPL licence
In-Reply-To: <454EA9E0.3080601@gmail.com>
References: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<a0c4f6270611051900sea3386bieba420bc788a7b9f@mail.gmail.com>
	<454EA9E0.3080601@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611060916t58379bbfl492e83943fd0e7b6@mail.gmail.com>

On 06/11/06, Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
> ++1. Any modification done to a GPLed software make it necessary to
> release the source code of the modified software with it.

This is not correct, or is misleading as it is written. Nobody forces
anyone to release sources of his/her own modifications to any GPL'ed
software. I use several customized builds of various GPL'ed software
at my employer's, but I don't always release my patches. Secondly,
even if one distributes modified GPL'ed software, one certainly
doesn't have to release one's patches (ie, make them available for the
general public).

Binand

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> OMG I don't know TeX and I think it is too difficult to pick up easily and quickly.
>
> Can't one make do with scribus,inkscape,gimp,blender etc.?
>

Sorry if I'm beating the Ruby horse too much around here - I'm sure 
there are equally good tools in other languages too, but this is what I 
know best, so I have to point out Austin Zeigler's PDF::Writer library:

http://ruby-pdf.rubyforge.org/pdf-writer/

And, it has excellent documentation too:

http://ruby-pdf.rubyforge.org/pdf-writer/manual/manual.pdf

 From what I heard, iText in Java isn't too bad, if you're more familiar 
with that language.


Vamsee.

Hi,

On 11/6/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 06/11/06, Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
> > ++1. Any modification done to a GPLed software make it necessary to
> > release the source code of the modified software with it.
>
> This is not correct, or is misleading as it is written. Nobody forces
> anyone to release sources of his/her own modifications to any GPL'ed
> software.

GPL does force you to release the modified GPLed source code if you
are releasing
only binary of the modified source code publically.

http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#GPLRequireSourcePostedPublic

Regards
Nikhil Prabhakar
From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Tue Nov  7 03:53:59 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul Sundaram)
Date: Tue Nov  7 03:54:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Doubt in GPL licence
In-Reply-To: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <454FB5FF.8030301@fedoraproject.org>

Anandh G wrote:
> I have a doubt in the way the software is licenced
> under GNU GPL. I will directly come to the point where
> my doubt is with an example.
> 
> Redhat has developed the Redhat Directory Service(RDS)
> based on openLDAP. Redhat would used the source code
> from OpenLDAP for RDS, but is RDS under GPL. If so
> will they give the source code of RDS free for use,
> modify and redistribute.

Red Hat Directory Server was formerly Netscape Directory Server and was 
sold as a proprietary product. Red Hat bought this out and it is now 
under the GPL license with a exceptions clause. This is available as 
Fedora Directory Server with the complete binaries and under the same 
source license terms.

http://directory.fedora.redhat.com/

> Also one more example is Redhat Application stack
> which has RHEL,JBoss,Apache,Mysql or Postgresql. But
> in this package Apache, Mysql,etc are under GPL
> licence and available free for use,modify and
> redistribute. 

Apache is under the Apache license. Not GPL.

But how about the Redhat Application
> stack package itself. IS this package also same as the others.

Thought some of the packages are not under GPL, all of the SRPMS are 
published under http://ftp.redhat.com/pub/redhat/linux/enterprise.

Rahul
