From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Nov  7 07:52:46 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Nov  7 07:53:06 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] About SAMBA
In-Reply-To: <20061106184413.32477.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061106184413.32477.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061107022246.GA22656@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Mon, Nov 06, 2006 at 10:44:13AM -0800, Amit Dey wrote:
> OK My mistake.
>    
>   I just discovered that SAMBA is a lot bigger than what i thought. I had assumed that it's only job is to share directories across the network. This feature is what interests me and I was wondering whether it would be feasible for me to develop something which allows easy sharing of directories accross network and the facility to search for specific files in the network ( just like we search in a single system ). I hope atleast this is not very far fledged.

The other day Bharathi asked me suddenly,

    ' Do you know something called dc++?'

    I asked him, 'What is that?'

    'Oh that is what people use in IIT to do file sharing'

I then came home and googled for it. Apparently it is some Windoze based p2p file sharing protocol. There are others Ares p2p and friends. 

Why don't you decode the wire protocol using tcpdump and develop a Samba like tool for linux? :)

Anyway if you are interested in doing research in file sharing you can start with bittorrent and learn what all people have done subsequently.

Samba had the specific goal of decoding the braindead Windoze file sharing mechanism. The equivalent in the UNIX world is NFS. AFS also can do the same.

NFS is from SUN. PAM is also from SUN. They both stink big time.

Unfortunately no one came up with a robust solution. There are various other remote file access mechanisms in the UNIX world I am sure list members can tell you.

Using FUSE you can export sshfs,davfs... OMG my brain is paining already. :)

Google for these terms and read about them. Down the line you can easily figure out what tingles your bones. 

Work on it and do something useful for yourself and the world. :)

Best,
Girish

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Nov  7 10:25:07 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Nov  7 10:25:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] About SAMBA
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610611062028o3e492021ka13a31ee14a1754@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061106184413.32477.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20061107022246.GA22656@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611062028o3e492021ka13a31ee14a1754@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061107045507.GA25896@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 05:28:35AM +0100, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> On 07/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> >NFS is from SUN. PAM is also from SUN. They both stink big time.
> 
> Care to explain why? Just because they are from SUN or you have other,
> technical reasons for making such a statement?

Very very sorry man. I don't mean to offend anyone. 

But I end up doing the same.

I had the dubious distinction of working with the innards of PAM long long ago in my first job. My goodness, it used to be so complex and the stupidity of the design hit me big time.

Of course that time I was not competent enough to guess that the problem was with the design of PAM...

The keywords "sufficient","required" etc. used to drive me mad. I could never correlate their intended meanings with the real English meaning.

I think ppl will agree with me that PAM is a necessary evil...

But talking of NFS. It is so ubiquitous that you even stop thinking of it as  evil. :)

And I am not really sure if one could do better. Since if one could there is no anecdote for me to quote.

I am sure with the newer versions a lot of bugs have been fixed and plenty of problems worked around but I have neither been tracking these changes nor have I actively used NFS.

Call it prejudice. I think it is just that. I make no bones about it. I am simply prejudiced against NFS.

I want to get rid of that of course. If you can help me it will be great.

Now, to answer your real question.

One big shot in SUN once told me that SUN actually is an "infrastructure" company. They make excellent hardware. Their sparc architecture and BLADE servers and what not are supposed to be one of the best hardware designs. SUN monitors are also top class. And really well integrated software solutions that run atop their top of the end hardware.

I am not talking about costs and affordability. I know that I can't even dream of owning one...

But several other SUN initiatives to succeed in the marketplace bombed as we all know. Anyway I am no biz guy and I don't know enough.

Now, it is a "favorite pastime" of open source folks, especially OpenBSD geniuses to flay all commercial organizations no matter how charismatic and huge they be in market share and mind share.

For instance if you read the slides of Henning Brauer on OpenBGPD http://unduli.bsws.de/papers/21c3/ you will see that he minces no words in flaying Cisco.

>From my own experience Cisco's IPsec implementation is a piece of ****.

Now, the best way to piss off everyone in ILUGC is to make this statement,

	"That Cisco routers are junk."

Juniper however seems to have got certain things right.

Since many of you believe that commercial alternatives and especially hugely successful and charismatic companies like google and Cisco actually have better products than competing open source alternatives are in for a huge shock/surprise.

That it simply isn't true. At least not always.

This goes to prove that open source culture breeds more competence,creativity and intellectual super stardom than the thick  confines of highly paying corporate jobs. :)

(Sounds like the cathedral and the bazaar by ESR, doesn't it? :)

However I think this is good news for most of us since we are open source folks. 

In a way none of the open source developers are much different from us since they also work for companies that make proprietary software.

So need to feel bad that in India we are poor and hence can't work on open source full time. :)

Only the really lucky folks have that leeway even in economically progressive nations...

regards,
Girish

On 06/11/06, nipra <prabhakar.nikhil@gmail.com> wrote:
> > > ++1. Any modification done to a GPLed software make it necessary to
> > > release the source code of the modified software with it.
> >
> > This is not correct, or is misleading as it is written. Nobody forces
> > anyone to release sources of his/her own modifications to any GPL'ed
> > software.
>
> GPL does force you to release the modified GPLed source code if you
> are releasing only binary of the modified source code publically.

ONLY if you distribute your modified version of the GPL'ed software. I
can modify GPL'ed software as much as I want, and the GPL allows me to
keep my modifications to myself so long as I don't distribute my
modified version to others.

Even if I do, I just have to provide my modifications to these others
and not to the general public.

Binand
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Nov  7 10:43:32 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Nov  7 10:43:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazines
In-Reply-To: <1162893421.5282.11.camel@localhost>
References: <20061106155818.9778A1DB264@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<1162893421.5282.11.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <20061107051332.GB25896@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 03:27:00PM +0530, amit saha wrote:
> It makes me wonder if you are thinking of bringing out such a magazine.
> Well if it is then I share some similar ideas. You can just check out
> this link http://www.geocities.com/dandolls/lprogs-journal/nov06/
> This is a journal i have been taking out for the past 3 months. Well If
> you think alike and think Big , may be we can do something better.

After the hopelessly bitter, shocking experience I had with the best linux magazine in India I was determined to start a competing magazine and show that technical excellence will win end of the day.

It is similar to the statement that movie directors make.

 " We make such movies since the audience wants that."

Well, this is only an excuse. Not a fact. 

Similarly the stance that "we are number one" and India does not need high quality articles and hence this will do is the attitude that drove me mad for nearly a fortnight after my negotiations failed with that magazine.

I know at least 15 names in ILUGC at the top of my head right now who can write much better articles than any magazine anywhere on earth can produce.

However at least to begin with, we should have only an online PDF version.

That obviously implies that we get paid only thro' ads. 

Fighting against the  #1 magazine in India is by no means an easy task and we  have to do it slowly. Step by step.

As to the advantages of writing articles. Well I don't have to explain. 

 a) It clarifies your thought process

 b) You are forced to learn several new things

 c) You are forced to try out new things to write about them

 d) name and fame and glory and what not. :)

 How many of you find this idea attractive?

 We will see how it works for a month or two. Down the line if things work out really well(which it will), then we can even release print versions and convert it into a financial venture.

 No, I don't have time for that. 

 I will tell you how easy it is to get started on the magazine. We can use several of the questions and answers that are archived in the list and that come up each day to feed the magazine. NBD.

 It needs more structure than that but at least it is a good starting point.

 It is very essential to get the art part right. How many of you are good artists?

 Students? Anyone?

 It will be preferrable to do computer art directly but if you can draw well on paper that is also fine.

 English of course is not at all a problem since I have never seen a single mail in ILUGC with grammar or spelling errors.

 Then what are you waiting for?

 Let us start. :)

regards,
Girish

PS:- If the idea of "fighting" sounds childish to you let me tell you that this is the attitude that West has towards everything they do. Only in India we stupidly believe that "fighting spirit" is a bad attitude. To do good we fight evil; What can possibly be wrong with that?

	<454EA9E0.3080601@gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610611060916t58379bbfl492e83943fd0e7b6@mail.gmail.com>
	<884c455a0611061320k4c14f5deid8cec628524da0fb@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610611062108j2df136a9i2c9ef30ab2546621@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <139e14f00611062116x4a50e28k19bcd61e8e4515c5@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/7/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On 06/11/06, nipra <prabhakar.nikhil@gmail.com> wrote:
> > > > ++1. Any modification done to a GPLed software make it necessary to
> > > > release the source code of the modified software with it.
> > >
> > > This is not correct, or is misleading as it is written. Nobody forces
> > > anyone to release sources of his/her own modifications to any GPL'ed
> > > software.
> >
> > GPL does force you to release the modified GPLed source code if you
> > are releasing only binary of the modified source code publically.
>
> ONLY if you distribute your modified version of the GPL'ed software. I
> can modify GPL'ed software as much as I want, and the GPL allows me to
> keep my modifications to myself so long as I don't distribute my
> modified version to others.
>
> Even if I do, I just have to provide my modifications to these others
> and not to the general public.


Yes, I also understand it this way.

1. You can take GPLed software and modify it for internal purposes  without
any obligations
2. Only when you distribute the modified version to others and the other
person asks for the source code you are required to provide the modified
source code.

GPL does not mean that you have to put up your code on the internet for
everyone to download. If you have a closed group of clients who have no
interest to compete with you or release the source code to the outside
world, you can even have a business similar to closed source companies.

All the open source companies provide sources for download for goodwill of
the developer community to my understanding.

Ramanraj might know better.

Best regards,

Ma Sivaumar


-- 
Ma Sivakumar,
BSG LeatherLink Pvt Limited,
Chennai.
http://www.leatherlink.net

On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 10:20:26AM +0530, Mano wrote:
> A quote of Mary Kay Ash would be appropriate here:
> 
> According to aerodynamic principles a bumble bee cannot fly. But the bumble
> bee does not know this... so it keeps flying anyway.
> 
> When pakistan won the world cup, a reporter asked Imran Khan how even
> debutant pakistani bowlers dont get overawed when they bowl to the likes of
> Greenidge, Richards and company! Imran said most of them cannot read so they
> probably dont even know who these guys are!
> 
> Would we have had linux if Linus allowed himself to be overawed by
> Tannenbaum's reputation?

Mano,

	Hmmm, Very interesting perspective. In fact a very highly respectable, knowledgeable friend once told me this.

	"Sometimes ignorance is bliss. That is why I like freshers."


	I could see that maybe he has a point. But I really think that ignorance is darkness. How can it ever be bliss?

	Perhaps for people who like a life of delusion.

	For instance children are so happy because they are ignorant.

	I don't think we can apply this all the time.

	You are talking about Pakistani bowlers who need "brute force" more than intellect.

	Even in the intellectual area Larry Wall said, " I did not know that it was impossible. Otherwise I would not even have tried it."

	So it is of course good to have confidence. But I would rather have true confidence that comes out of hard work and experience than some imaginary one.


	Btw, I never meant to say that you should get overawed by someone's charisma. 

	Before fighting, build your army. That is all.

	Don't underestimate the strength of your adversary.

	Anyway it is futile to talk about these subjective things.

	Just prove it in action. :)

	Simple. No need to talk then.

regards,
Girish

>
> On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 03:27:00PM +0530, amit saha wrote:
> > It makes me wonder if you are thinking of bringing out such a magazine.
> > Well if it is then I share some similar ideas. You can just check out
> > this link http://www.geocities.com/dandolls/lprogs-journal/nov06/
> > This is a journal i have been taking out for the past 3 months. Well If
> > you think alike and think Big , may be we can do something better.
>
> After the hopelessly bitter, shocking experience I had with the best linux
> magazine in India I was determined to start a competing magazine and show
> that technical excellence will win end of the day.
>
> It is similar to the statement that movie directors make.
>
> " We make such movies since the audience wants that."
>
> Well, this is only an excuse. Not a fact.
>
> Similarly the stance that "we are number one" and India does not need high
> quality articles and hence this will do is the attitude that drove me mad
> for nearly a fortnight after my negotiations failed with that magazine.
>
> I know at least 15 names in ILUGC at the top of my head right now who can
> write much better articles than any magazine anywhere on earth can produce.
>
> However at least to begin with, we should have only an online PDF version.
>
> That obviously implies that we get paid only thro' ads.
>
> Fighting against the  #1 magazine in India is by no means an easy task and
> we  have to do it slowly. Step by step.
>
> As to the advantages of writing articles. Well I don't have to explain.
>
> a) It clarifies your thought process
>
> b) You are forced to learn several new things
>
> c) You are forced to try out new things to write about them
>
> d) name and fame and glory and what not. :)
>
> How many of you find this idea attractive?
>
> We will see how it works for a month or two. Down the line if things work
> out really well(which it will), then we can even release print versions and
> convert it into a financial venture.
>
> No, I don't have time for that.
>
> I will tell you how easy it is to get started on the magazine. We can use
> several of the questions and answers that are archived in the list and that
> come up each day to feed the magazine. NBD.
>
> It needs more structure than that but at least it is a good starting
> point.
>
> It is very essential to get the art part right. How many of you are good
> artists?
>
> Students? Anyone?
>
> It will be preferrable to do computer art directly but if you can draw
> well on paper that is also fine.
>
> English of course is not at all a problem since I have never seen a single
> mail in ILUGC with grammar or spelling errors.
>
> Then what are you waiting for?
>
> Let us start. :)
>
> regards,
> Girish
>
> PS:- If the idea of "fighting" sounds childish to you let me tell you that
> this is the attitude that West has towards everything they do. Only in India
> we stupidly believe that "fighting spirit" is a bad attitude. To do good we
> fight evil; What can possibly be wrong with that?

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

My Tamil is not good enough for technical writing. I will submit articles in English.

Can't you get it translated? I think it should be possible.

I am not sure if everything can be expressed in Tamil.

Not easy.

Even Germans and Japanese cannot escape from learning English if they are in the technical field.

We can help beginners, but going forward they have to learn English.

There is no other way. Or this can help folks who are weak in English.

I love Tamil more than English. I have clearly expressed my love and respect  for the greatness of the language.

But UNIX commands are not in Tamil. Man pages are not in Tamil...

So I think a good mix is what is needed without getting too religious about either.

On 07/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> I think I should learn Tex if I have to do something serious.
>
It's TeX.  From tau-epsilon-chi, pronounced so that it rhymes with
"blecch" according to Knuth in "the Name of the Game" chapter in The
TeXbook.  On the other hand, I think Lamport says you can pronounce
LaTeX any which way in "the Game of the Name" in LaTex (the book).

:)

Roshan Mathews

technology. Rather the few lakh who know both english and tamil should
contribute. Off course in other languages too...

Nothing too religious here. Give access to technology to people through
their own language. So simple isn't it?

Hi;
It is actually pretty easy to learn latex. or you can use tools like
lyx, klyx to make your job easier. google has answers to every
problem that you may face with latex.
you would definitely need xfig along with latex as you may need to
create drawings and export it as an eps file which can then be used
in side latex.
K.Shyam
PS: after having used some serious latex for the past two years, once
you see the output you can produce with it, you would trash any other
documentation system (that includes openoffice)

http://shyamk.blogspot.com

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

From chandu_ssit1982 at yahoo.com  Tue Nov  7 14:45:46 2006
From: chandu_ssit1982 at yahoo.com (chandan chandu)
Date: Tue Nov  7 14:45:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to setup SCIM in Debian etch testing?
Message-ID: <20061107091546.51046.qmail@web33315.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

> Any idea how to enable localized fonts on the console? With vim for instance? I think > vim supports localization.
> 
> Will UTF-8 fonts work?

Hi Girsih,

Enabling SCIM is same in vim as you will do for either gedit or openoffice ... Once you installed SCIM , it will be enabled to gedit , openoffice and vim ( all graphical and text editors ) ... 
You can input different langauge in vim as below ... 

Open Terminal-->vi <fileName> -> press enter (Enter into insert mode) --> press ctrl+space to slect langauges --> Select the langauge you need  --> type with the language you have selected. 

If any doubts let me know ... 

Regards
Chandu

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Tue Nov  7 15:22:49 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (R.Ramkumar)
Date: Tue Nov  7 15:22:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] About SAMBA
In-Reply-To: <20061107022246.GA22656@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061106184413.32477.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20061107022246.GA22656@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170611070152u1004fb4did44b939e9256e517@mail.gmail.com>

> I then came home and googled for it. Apparently it is some Windoze based p2p file sharing protocol. There are others Ares p2p and friends.

I don't know what you mean by a Windows based protocol. The details of
the protocol are well known and there are many clients for Direct
Connect protocol in Linux as well... linuxdcpp, dcgui2, rccp, valknut,
microdc etc. In fact, some of them (like microdc) outperform their
windows counterparts in terms of performance. As a matter of fact,
dc++, the primary client for Windows (there are others which have
forked off it) is Free Software and linuxdcpp is its Linux port.

My personal opinion... DC is one of the better p2p protocols existing
today... You can look at the website for the features :)

it moves on...

-- 
One of the main causes of the fall of the Roman Empire
was that, lacking zero, they had no way to indicate
successful termination of their C programs.

Hi,

> >>Can't one make do with scribus,inkscape,gimp,blender etc.?
> >I don't know what these are, but I doubt these are typesetting  
> >programs.
 
> scribus is a dtp application - doing well, but a long way from  
> pagemaker or quarkXpress. Typesetting became obsolete long ago.

I dont agree that typesetting has become obsolete. its defacto standard even now  for many scientific journals which ask for latex files. ofcourse users realizethe superior quality of the output too :)

If u need to start with latex in a day with basics:
http://ctan.org/tex-archive/info/lshort/english

for further command index refer to:
info latex

Then u can see the usage of other sophisticated latex packages @ CTAN according to ur requirement.

HTH,
KM

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text

1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape 6,
Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default font
for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be downloaded
from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf

> After the hopelessly bitter, shocking experience I had with the best linux magazine in India I was determined to start a competing magazine and show that technical excellence will win end of the day.
> 
> It is similar to the statement that movie directors make.
> 
>  " We make such movies since the audience wants that."
> 
> Well, this is only an excuse. Not a fact. 
> 
> Similarly the stance that "we are number one" and India does not need high quality articles and hence this will do is the attitude that drove me mad for nearly a fortnight after my negotiations failed with that magazine.
> 
> I know at least 15 names in ILUGC at the top of my head right now who can write much better articles than any magazine anywhere on earth can produce.
> 
> However at least to begin with, we should have only an online PDF version.
> 
> That obviously implies that we get paid only thro' ads. 
> 
> Fighting against the  #1 magazine in India is by no means an easy task and we  have to do it slowly. Step by step.
> 
> As to the advantages of writing articles. Well I don't have to explain. 
> 
>  a) It clarifies your thought process
> 
>  b) You are forced to learn several new things
> 
>  c) You are forced to try out new things to write about them
> 
>  d) name and fame and glory and what not. :)
> 
>  How many of you find this idea attractive?
> 
>  We will see how it works for a month or two. Down the line if things work out really well(which it will), then we can even release print versions and convert it into a financial venture.
> 
>  No, I don't have time for that. 
> 



>  I will tell you how easy it is to get started on the magazine. We can use several of the questions and answers that are archived in
>  the list and that come up each day to feed the magazine. NBD.

(http://www.geocities.com/dandolls/lprogs-journal/nov06/).
It is actually a compilation of the various group posts . This is indeed
a good idea and so we really wont need to go for article "hunting" at
least for a part of the content.I have written articles mainly for
LinuxGazette. And for my own blog / site. So i am in for the venture as
a technical writer mainly.

Who is willing to be the in-charge ? Some one needs to be in charge to
co-ordinate and synchronize the whole thing. 

We can primarily start off with a online PDF/HTML version as suggested
by you. And then may be venture off to the unconquered PAPER
territories.

What do you think ?

Need your view.
 
Thanks.

>
> Stepwise instructions - to view Unicode Tamil text
>
> 1. You need to have Unicode Tamil fonts installed on your computer and the
> Operating System capable of rendering Tamil Scripts. Windows XP comes with a
> Unicode Tamil Font (Latha) and you need not download/install a unicode font.
>
> 2. In the Control Panel, in Regional/Languages Options you will need to
> ensure that Indic/Asian Language option is checked.
> 3. Use a browser that is capable of handling UTF-8 based pages (Netscape
> 6, Internet Explorer 5) with the Unicode Tamil font chosen as the default
> font for the UTF-8 char-set/encoding view. Unicode Tamil Fonts may be
> downloaded from http://www.tamilnation.org/fonts/latha.ttf
>

Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310611071021o11f4d0b5gac4640ffb532a0dc@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/7/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Guys,
>         I  hear quite a lot about digital signatures in India. That you will require that for credit card purchases and tax filing.
>
>         I am told that some company in Blore provides solutions for this.
>
>         What exactly is going on?

I remember to have read in newspapers that the digital signatures will
be used in corporate tax filings. It's especially important because
starting this year online filing has been made compulsory. Corporates
will be provided with some sort of certificates (possibly X.509) that
they will maintain on some devices (Secure USB key, TPM, smartcard) -
This certificate will later be used in filing.

-- 
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Wed Nov  8 05:37:05 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Wed Nov  8 05:37:21 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Doubt in GPL licence
In-Reply-To: <139e14f00611062116x4a50e28k19bcd61e8e4515c5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061106012444.65491.qmail@web36705.mail.mud.yahoo.com>	<a0c4f6270611051900sea3386bieba420bc788a7b9f@mail.gmail.com>	<454EA9E0.3080601@gmail.com>	<d2a92d610611060916t58379bbfl492e83943fd0e7b6@mail.gmail.com>	<884c455a0611061320k4c14f5deid8cec628524da0fb@mail.gmail.com>	<d2a92d610611062108j2df136a9i2c9ef30ab2546621@mail.gmail.com>
	<139e14f00611062116x4a50e28k19bcd61e8e4515c5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45511FA9.3070707@gmail.com>

Sivakumar Ma wrote:
> 1. You can take GPLed software and modify it for internal purposes  
> without
> any obligations
> 2. Only when you distribute the modified version to others and the other
> person asks for the source code you are required to provide the modified
> source code.
>
> GPL does not mean that you have to put up your code on the internet for
> everyone to download. If you have a closed group of clients who have no
> interest to compete with you or release the source code to the outside
> world, you can even have a business similar to closed source companies.
>
> All the open source companies provide sources for download for 
> goodwill of
> the developer community to my understanding.
The GPLv3 draft includes new conditions that may change that. I wrote 
about the concerns there to the  fsf-friends list at 
http://mm.gnu.org.in/pipermail/fsf-friends/2006-August/004230.html :

Freedom 0, "the freedom to run the program, for any purpose", seems to
be twisted out of shape by the draft GPLv3.

GPLv2 says: "The act of running the Program is not restricted, and the
output from the  Program is covered only if  its contents constitute a
work based on the Program  (independent of having been made by running
the Program)."

GPLv3  draft rewrites:  "This  License  permits you  to  make and  run
privately modified  versions of the  Program, or have others  make and
run them on your behalf."

The attempt to maintain distinction between "private" and "public" use
of the  program licensed is  not easy and anyway  only discriminatory.
Is it that  non-internet users can use free  software for any purpose,
but internet  users who connect to  the world wide web,  have to loose
that freedom? 

Freedom 2  can easily  be wiped out  with additional terms  that allow
trademark  conditions which  would prevent  simple  redistributions to
even  friends  and  neighbours.   The  trademark claims  made  by  ssh
trademark owner upon  openssh developers is a good  lesson not to give
room for needless and self-defeating disputes within the free software
community.

Contributions could go up in flames or be appropriated by trademark 
owners with such additional terms.

Other comments:

http://www.pff.org/issues-pubs/ps/2006/ps2.6healy.html

The spirit of the free software movement is as old as Thirumanthiram or 
any of our ancient works - Thirumoolar said "nan petra inbam peruga 
ivvaiagam" as the reason for his work.  It takes a great deal to 
complicate that :)

"The Linux that is pre-loaded is a free version and would have limited

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Wed Nov  8 06:49:38 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (R.Ramkumar)
Date: Wed Nov  8 06:49:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Acer Laptops - preloaded with Linux
In-Reply-To: <e70ef6930611071713o6f899304t8b499ad19b96d7ba@mail.gmail.com>
References: <e70ef6930611071713o6f899304t8b499ad19b96d7ba@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170611071719g181dddfft39ee1c08e00080c9@mail.gmail.com>

> The fine print states that
> "The Linux that is pre-loaded is a free version and would have limited
> functionality until another operating system is installed"
> Have anyone has any experience with these laptops and what kind of *limited*
> functionalities does it have?

If you are talking about Acer Aspire 3002NLC or anything similar, the
shipped distribution (some Linpus) is total crap.. Doesn't even have
X... I almost took their initiative to ship that as some tactic to
drive people from Linux... So, you will need to install some other
distro as soon as you buy the laptop.

As far as hardware compatibility is concerned, I guess there aren't
any major hassles except for the SIS graphics card for which DRI
support is not yet available. Please check the archives... I think I
once posted my experiences with the laptop...

it moves on...

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Nov  8 10:18:15 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Nov  8 10:19:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Query about instaling from source code.
In-Reply-To: <20061107141959.25429.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061107141959.25429.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061108044815.GA19033@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 06:19:59AM -0800, Amit Dey wrote:
> Whenever I need to install a software on my system (from source code) I have to execute the usual ./configure, make, make install commands.
>  
> Let us say I have made a simple hello world application ( using only a text editor ). How can I make the configure files for it. Isn't it too complex of shell scripting for newbie's ? Then how come every little software has one.
>  
> Need your view.

It is an artifact of "improper" POSIX compliance. Usually standards bodies have the ill repute of coming with odd or nonsensical ideas and sometimes it would not make much practical sense to follow standards.

With RFCs this is less of a problem but "controlled" US standards organizations normally don't inspire respect from implementors.

As a result of this and various other factors, commercial and free UNIX clones have ended up being POSIX compliant to various degrees.

This is what the configure script aims to detect.

For instance, in some OSes there would be index(3),some strchr(3) and many both. :)

So as a user space code developer you will have a really tough time if you wre to put #ifdef statements in the code to detect the OS . Sometimes things change between patchlevels and libc versions.

If your code is really simple without much external dependencies and fully ANSI compliant, then you don't need configure at all.

Anyway to answer your question there is a tool called autoproject that will give you a configure skeleton.

regards,
Girish
From binand at gmail.com  Wed Nov  8 10:29:12 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Wed Nov  8 10:29:21 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Query about instaling from source code.
In-Reply-To: <20061108044815.GA19033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061107141959.25429.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20061108044815.GA19033@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611072059w275cd4e0k5d687a80ba999a44@mail.gmail.com>

On 08/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> For instance, in some OSes there would be index(3),some strchr(3) and many both. :)

This is hardly the right example to prove your point, considering
strchr() is required in conformant standard C library implementations
whereas index() is not specified by any standard. Any programmer who
uses index() is writing non-portable code.

Binand

Hi All,

The IITs have taken up an initiative of starting  online teaching and
thus have started offering course materials online for  every
engineering stream.

-Many professors from all the IITs have  provided course materials for
each chapter and each subject.

-One has  to register at the link provided below and can access the
course material.

-Every Chapter has been described with diagrams and charts.

-  Please spread this message to everyone, as many can benefit from
this program  taken up by the government and IIT.

1] Go to  http://nptel.iitm.ac.in

2] Click on  Courses

3] Sign up as a NEW USER

4] And one can access any course  material.

Bye,
Krishna.

On 11/7/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 10:20:26AM +0530, Mano wrote:
>
>         You are talking about Pakistani bowlers who need "brute force"
> more than intellect.


What makes you think a bowler does not need 'intellect'!! IQ as a measure of
intellect has been trashed by researchers. Intellect can only be measured by
ones achievement in one's chosen field. So, if you ask me, I would say
Sachin Tendulakar or Ronaldinho or Michael Jordan are as intelligent as
Linus Torvalds.

        Even in the intellectual area Larry Wall said, " I did not know that
> it was impossible. Otherwise I would not even have tried it."
>
>         So it is of course good to have confidence. But I would rather
> have true confidence that comes out of hard work and experience than some
> imaginary one.
>
>
Every child is born with all the hardware (the neurons) interconnected. The
environment that one grows in strengthens some connections. So if the
connections that handle math and logic is strong you end up with a high
score in an IQ test and can call yourself 'intelligent'. But to think that
someone who has strong connections in the areas that handle eye, leg, hand
co-ordination are brutes is silly! I would'nt call Picasso dumb because he
cannot solve simple math problems! He had a view of the world which was
beyond our imagination.

You should read V S Ramachandran's 'The Emerging Mind' or listen to his BBC
Reith lectures (available on the web). And although somewhat superficial
Malcom Gladwell's 'Blink' to understand what 'intellect' is.

regds,
mano
-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!

Hi,

On 11/8/06, ?????  ????? ?????? ??????  Vivek Iyyer <v.iyyer@gmail.com> wrote:

> but it works kubuntu dapper all.. bluetooth, wifi, sound and the jazz.
> no luck with debian though.. with the matshita DVD-RAM does not seem
> to be supported. so no cdrom after the boot from the installer.
>
> if anyone had luck with debian do post back :)

OK, I had the same problem with SATA based CD/DVD-ROM's. I just used
Debian Sarge and did a minimal installation. For some strange reason
Debian Sarge managed to identify the DVD-ROM and Debian Etch didn't. I
think it's because Sarge used libsata for it's kernels and Etch would
be using libide.

After installing the minimal version of Sarge, do an apt-get upgrade
to the latest version of Debian.

-Toufeeq

blog @ http://toufeeq.net

>
> Hi All,

> The IITs have taken up an initiative of starting  online teaching and
> thus have started offering course materials online for  every

> On 11/7/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 10:20:26AM +0530, Mano wrote:
> >
> >         You are talking about Pakistani bowlers who need "brute force"
> > more than intellect.
>
>
> What makes you think a bowler does not need 'intellect'!! IQ as a measure of
> intellect has been trashed by researchers. Intellect can only be measured by
> ones achievement in one's chosen field. So, if you ask me, I would say
> Sachin Tendulakar or Ronaldinho or Michael Jordan are as intelligent as
> Linus Torvalds.
>
>        Even in the intellectual area Larry Wall said, " I did not know that
> > it was impossible. Otherwise I would not even have tried it."
> >
> >         So it is of course good to have confidence. But I would rather
> > have true confidence that comes out of hard work and experience than some
> > imaginary one.
> >
> >
> Every child is born with all the hardware (the neurons) interconnected. The
> environment that one grows in strengthens some connections. So if the
> connections that handle math and logic is strong you end up with a high
> score in an IQ test and can call yourself 'intelligent'. But to think that
> someone who has strong connections in the areas that handle eye, leg, hand
> co-ordination are brutes is silly! I would'nt call Picasso dumb because he
> cannot solve simple math problems! He had a view of the world which was
> beyond our imagination.
>
> You should read V S Ramachandran's 'The Emerging Mind' or listen to his BBC
> Reith lectures (available on the web). And although somewhat superficial
> Malcom Gladwell's 'Blink' to understand what 'intellect' is.
>
> regds,
> mano
> --
> War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!

>
> OK, I had the same problem with SATA based CD/DVD-ROM's. I just used
> Debian Sarge and did a minimal installation. For some strange reason
> Debian Sarge managed to identify the DVD-ROM and Debian Etch didn't. I
> think it's because Sarge used libsata for it's kernels and Etch would
> be using libide.
>
> After installing the minimal version of Sarge, do an apt-get upgrade
> to the latest version of Debian.
>
> -Toufeeq
> --
> blog @ http://toufeeq.net

From kums at gmx.net  Thu Nov  9 00:14:20 2006
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru Gajarajan)
Date: Thu Nov  9 00:14:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Intex ethernet card driver
In-Reply-To: <a0c4f6270611010411t67287647jf9bce7c126fad168@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a0c4f6270611010411t67287647jf9bce7c126fad168@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45522584.7020303@gmx.net>

Hi,

Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> Dear ILUGC,
> 
> One of my friends has the Intex (cheap) LAN card Silan sc92031. Now,
> that doesn't work at all in most distributions. However, the CD
> provided with it ahs Linux drivers, albeit for kernels 2.4/2.5.
> 
> Now, an ILUGC member (Mr.Kumaraguru) has modified this for working
> with kernel 2.6, and it is at
> http://gurukumara.googlepages.com/
> 
> However, it doesn't compile under newer 2.6 kernels because of the
> deprecation of some functions/macros used. In particular, MODULE_PARM
> and a function called synchonize_irq.

Sorry for responding late but I was indisposed for a while. I had
compiled the driver on a Ubuntu dapper system which comes with Kernel
2.6.15. Even though MODULE_PARM was deprecated (which I only came to
know recently), there was no compilation errors due to it. So I
foolishly thought the code is going to compile for all the future 2.6.x
versions. Looks like the kernel developers decided to remove MODULE_PARM
completely. Now that I upgraded to 2.6.17 (with edgy), I can see the
compilation problems myself.

> I read up a bit and made some minimal changes which made the driver
> compile under kernel 2.6.17:
> 
> http://www.ee.iitm.ac.in/~ee03b091/sc92031.c

Thanks, I've included the changes and also fixed a few warnings.
http://gurukumara.googlepages.com/sc92031-2.6.tar.gz

> 
> It compiles, loads and works fine for about five minutes, following 
> which I get:
> 
> kernel: [some numbers]: Disabled IRQ #201 (or something similar).
> 
> Despite my best attempts and googling, I could not solve this problem.
> I'd appreciate it if someone could point it out and suggest the right
> modification in the driver, as it will be useful to many.
> 

I've tested the driver for 2 days now. It works for me without problems.
Perhaps, it's some peculiar combination of hardware that's causing
problem at your end. If this isn't solved yet, you should probably try
loading the driver after all other drivers are loaded.

Regards
Kumaraguru
--

On 11/8/06, amit saha <dandolls@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> > Whenever I need to install a software on my system (from source code) I have to execute the usual ./configure, make, make install commands.
> >
> > Let us say I have made a simple hello world application ( using only a text editor ). How can I make the configure files for it. Isn't it too complex of shell scripting for newbie's ? Then how come every little software has one.
> Perhaps you have heard about KDevelop. Since you are using FC5 chances
> are that you have them installed already. Just design your "hello world"
> app using KDevelop and everything will be done i.e the configure files
> etc will be created for you.

autoproject is another tool that does this ground work for you.

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Thu Nov  9 07:28:58 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Suzhi
Message-ID: <AB9DC7D8-100A-48CC-84EC-6D56F6C68B2E@thenilgiris.com>

hi

Suzhi is an attempt to encourage writing foss documentation in tamil.  
Since it is in wiki form, it is easy for more experienced people to  
correct the language of the newbies. I was experimenting with page  
headings in tamil. How many can access this:

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/ 
??????????_?????????

i also request authors to put links to their articles on the front  
page. If there are a bunch of related articles, they may put a link  
to a contents page on the front page and links from there to the  
other pages.

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/

you need to be logged in to edit
-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

>> Let us say I have made a simple hello world application ( using

should let you do a lot of this automatically., but learning to use the
'gnu build system' should help in the longer run.

> Thats pretty interesting. Does this mean., that if you purchase a
> key-pair from the CA., you'll have to ditch your current key-pair? Does
> it make sense to sign your current key-pair with the purchased key-pair
> to prove authenticity?

You don't purchase key pairs from the CA; you purchase certificates.

What do you mean by key pair, anyway?

Binand
From joe_steeve at gmx.net  Thu Nov  9 12:39:43 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610611082151l271c4da2nee1d01d9d5b7d9f0@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>	<b3de58900611080928j5478165ud6e931c3bf4eda9a@mail.gmail.com>	<4552C059.2070203@gmx.net>

Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> You don't purchase key pairs from the CA; you purchase certificates.

Aw., I thought a certificate was a public-private key pair signed by the
CA., certifying the identify of the owner. Did i get it wrong somewhere?

> What do you mean by key pair, anyway?

The public key, private key pair.

-------------- next part --------------
A non-text attachment was scrubbed...
Name: signature.asc
Type: application/pgp-signature
Size: 189 bytes
Desc: OpenPGP digital signature
Url : http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/pipermail/ilugc/attachments/20061109/2b58c2ba/signature.bin
From jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com  Thu Nov  9 12:40:50 2006
From: jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com (Sarad AV)
Date: Thu Nov  9 12:41:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
Message-ID: <20061109071050.44614.qmail@web33312.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

On 09/11/06, Joe Steeve <joe_steeve at gmx.net> wrote:
> Thats pretty interesting. Does this mean., that if
you purchase a
> key-pair from the CA., you'll have to ditch your
current key-pair? 


The private key, you donot reveal to anyone, not even
to the CA. You send your public key along with your
credentials to the CA. The CA will certify it for you
and issue you a digital certificate.
  You don't necessarily have to ditch your old key
pair. You can send the CA, the same old public key +
your credentials and ask them to issue you a
certificate.

> Does it make sense to sign your current key-pair
with the purchased key-pair
> to prove authenticity?
  
  Yes, you can do that, its a roundabout way.
Moreover, its not the key-pair you need to sign, its
the public key alone that needs to be signed, in this
case.
  Your private key if for you alone and not to be
shared. 

This wikipedia link should help you clear most of it
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certificate_signing_request

As for TCS- if you trust them(TCS) and if the person
verifying your authenticity trusts TCS- you can use
them as a CA.

Sarad.

http://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/r-index
From binand at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 12:57:59 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Thu Nov  9 12:58:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <4552D437.9000206@gmx.net>
References: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<b3de58900611080928j5478165ud6e931c3bf4eda9a@mail.gmail.com>
	<4552C059.2070203@gmx.net>
	<d2a92d610611082151l271c4da2nee1d01d9d5b7d9f0@mail.gmail.com>
	<4552D437.9000206@gmx.net>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611082327w643d681cy75e472787e3970e6@mail.gmail.com>

On 09/11/06, Joe Steeve <joe_steeve@gmx.net> wrote:
> Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> > You don't purchase key pairs from the CA; you purchase certificates.
>
> Aw., I thought a certificate was a public-private key pair signed by the
> CA., certifying the identify of the owner. Did i get it wrong somewhere?

Ah OK. The certificate is only the public key signed by the CA. You
generate the keypair, and send only the public key to the CA - who
certifies your identity and attaches it to the key. What you actually
purchase from the CA is the certificate (certifying that you are who
you claim to be, say securesection.mysite.com or Binand
Sethumadhavan).

I think your initial question was more related to the keypair
generated by tools like gnupg ("Does this mean., that if you purchase
a key-pair from the CA, you'll have to ditch your current key-pair?")?
Gnupg ("web of trust scheme") and the CA-based system ("PKI scheme")
are completely disjoint, PKI is the one that is more practical for
authenticating several thousand clients to a tax-filing website, for
example.

Binand

From siva.ilugc at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 13:42:17 2006
From: siva.ilugc at gmail.com (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Thu Nov  9 13:42:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] low cost linux compatible box
In-Reply-To: <A74EE22B-3B3C-42BD-89A0-D15CE93F379A@thenilgiris.com>
References: <A74EE22B-3B3C-42BD-89A0-D15CE93F379A@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <a8f990120611090012v5afb5bd8tb1cf6b4349811383@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/9/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> hi,
> i am thinking of buying a low cost box for my house. Any
> recomendations for a *fully* linux compatible MOBO and monitor.
> Should have 1gb ram - onboard graphics is ok - and where to get it
> from with some idea of price
>
   Just about every mobo with onboard graphics today has some
features (mostly related to the graphics engine) that are closed or
undocumented - whether you go with ATI, NVidia or even Intel.
If you want *full* Linux support you may have to go with an add-in
AGP/PCIe card that is fully supported.

    I have no clue about what you mean my low cost, but if it's
loaded with 1 GB of DDR, it probably doesn't meet my definition.

   My baseline low-cost configuration today would have an i810T/
i815T motherboard with a Tualatin 1.2 GHz Celeron for about Rs.2k,
with not more than 256 MB of SDRAM scrounged from somewhere.
FC4 with Xfce desktop, and I'm done.

   For a little more (say around 5k), I could probably get a S754+
Sempron combo.

-Siva
From jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com  Thu Nov  9 14:01:25 2006
From: jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com (Sarad AV)
Date: Thu Nov  9 14:01:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
Message-ID: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

> Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
>What you actually
>purchase from the CA is the certificate (certifying
>that you are who
>you claim to be, say securesection.mysite.com or
Binand
>Sethumadhavan).

Yes and we need to authenticate the CA too.

The unfortunate thing about the TCS-CA is that you
will have to do a one time import of the TCS's
certificate, unlike Thawte, VISA or Vesign whose
certificates comes default with the Firefox web
browser.
   There is really know way to know if there is a man
in the middle attack underway(though unlikely), when
you download and import the TCS certificate.

Sarad.

From vinay at vinayras.com  Thu Nov  9 15:04:22 2006
From: vinay at vinayras.com (Vinay Yadav)
Date: Thu Nov  9 14:59:49 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Routing Problem
Message-ID: <4552F61E.6040603@vinayras.com>

Hi All,

I have a strange routing problem.

Environment:
FC1, Tata Indicom CDMA Landline (1500 unlimited internet plan)

I am connected to internet and everything is working fine on this (host)
machine.

But internet is not available to other machines on network. Other
machines are FC3 and FC4. Networking is working fine.Only problem is
that they are not able to use internet.

Local IP (FC1): 192.168.0.2
FC3: 192.168.0.5
FC4: 192.168.0.4

ifconfig on FC1 (Machine connected to internet)

eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:11:11:94:1F:43
           inet addr:192.168.0.2  Bcast:192.168.0.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
           UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
           RX packets:13331 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
           TX packets:13662 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
           collisions:0 txqueuelen:1000
           RX bytes:2513923 (2.3 Mb)  TX bytes:5334416 (5.0 Mb)
           Interrupt:11 Base address:0xdc00 Memory:ff8ff000-ff8ff038

lo        Link encap:Local Loopback
           inet addr:127.0.0.1  Mask:255.0.0.0
           UP LOOPBACK RUNNING  MTU:16436  Metric:1
           RX packets:139046 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
           TX packets:139046 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
           collisions:0 txqueuelen:0
           RX bytes:18493380 (17.6 Mb)  TX bytes:18493380 (17.6 Mb)

ppp0      Link encap:Point-to-Point Protocol
           inet addr:219.64.171.130  P-t-P:172.23.118.93
Mask:255.255.255.255
           UP POINTOPOINT RUNNING NOARP MULTICAST  MTU:264  Metric:1
           RX packets:3491 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
           TX packets:3238 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
           collisions:0 txqueuelen:3
           RX bytes:715572 (698.8 Kb)  TX bytes:431698 (421.5 Kb)



Some diagnosis:
1) Ping is working fine from FC4 & FC3. Ping to google.com worked fine.
2) Traceroute is also working fine from FC4 & FC3
3) wget -c http://www.slashdot.org is able to fetch index.html file,
Firefox is not able to open site.
4) Thunderbird is fetching emails fine from client machines
5) GAIM is also working fine from client machines

Script used for routing:
iptables -F; iptables -t nat -F; iptables -t mangle -F
echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward
iptables -A POSTROUTING -t nat -o ppp+ -j MASQUERADE

Please let me as what i am missing.

Same network/routing works when using Reliance Landline dial-up.

Regards
Vinay

>getting
>it!! Do they have such a facility in any of their
>Chennai offices?

>regds,
>mano

    As you can see, that is not a very practical
solution. There can be thousands of clients and we
can't expect every one to go running around to the
nearest TCS office, even if they have this facility.
All the clients need not even be from India! We have
already a narrow scope for such a system, not to
mention it is cumbersome.

    CA's are for making authentication easier, not
difficult.
    To make it fool proof they need to tie up with
popular browsers and make the browser ship with their
certificates.

Sarad.

From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 15:53:53 2006
From: shriramadhas at gmail.com (=?UTF-8?B?4K6uLuCusOCuvuCuruCupOCuvuCuuOCvjQ==?=)
Date: Thu Nov  9 15:54:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Tamil support in firefox
In-Reply-To: <8dd9fd0611090134h18149a20l3fac56e7e6ecc3fa@mail.gmail.com>

This problem should not come had u installed *language-support-ta* package.
Without installing the language pack firefox can render proper unicode
scripts in the following ways,

First try this,

From the terminal,

*$ export MOZ_DISABLE_PANGO=0*

then refresh any unicode web site, say www.ubuntu-tam.org ;-)

Hope it should work fine. This is temporary fix. You have to do this every
time u sign in. So for a permanent fix,

edit,

*/etc/environment*
**
and add the following line,
**
*MOZ_DISABLE_PANGO=0*
**
Log off and Log in back. Hope this should help resolve the issue.

On 09/11/06, Sarad AV <jtrjtrjtr2001@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Yes and we need to authenticate the CA too.
>
> The unfortunate thing about the TCS-CA is that you
> will have to do a one time import of the TCS's
> certificate, unlike Thawte, VISA or Vesign whose
> certificates comes default with the Firefox web
> browser.

Two points that occured to me.

1. You needn't import the TCS CA into your Firefox if the CA public
certificate is signed by one of those who's already present in your
root store. You can have a chain of trust like Verisign->TCS->You.

2. In the proposed system (online tax filing), I imagine the
certificate is used purely to authenticate the user to the server, so
quite likely only the server requires the TCS CA handy.

Binand

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 19:15:20 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 08:27:59AM +0100, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> Ah OK. The certificate is only the public key signed by the CA. You
> generate the keypair, and send only the public key to the CA - who
> certifies your identity and attaches it to the key. What you actually
> purchase from the CA is the certificate (certifying that you are who
> you claim to be, say securesection.mysite.com or Binand
> Sethumadhavan).

I think there is a slight communication problem here. 

Can you please clarify what you mean by "Certifies your identity and attaches it to the key?"

> 
> I think your initial question was more related to the keypair
> generated by tools like gnupg ("Does this mean., that if you purchase
> a key-pair from the CA, you'll have to ditch your current key-pair?")?
> Gnupg ("web of trust scheme") and the CA-based system ("PKI scheme")
> are completely disjoint, PKI is the one that is more practical for
> authenticating several thousand clients to a tax-filing website, for
> example.

Ok I myself did not know this until recently that PGP web of trust has nothing to do with the hierarchical certification scheme of PKI.

But whatever it is it is all quite complicated.  :)

Most people are tired of certificates and most elaborate parts of PKI.

But certificates are essential for many real world applications, so we cannot ignore them for long.

regards,
Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 19:35:11 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Nov  9 19:35:37 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <45530923.4050000@gmx.net>
References: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<b3de58900611080928j5478165ud6e931c3bf4eda9a@mail.gmail.com>
	<4552C059.2070203@gmx.net>
	<d2a92d610611082151l271c4da2nee1d01d9d5b7d9f0@mail.gmail.com>
	<4552D437.9000206@gmx.net>
	<d2a92d610611082327w643d681cy75e472787e3970e6@mail.gmail.com>
	<45530923.4050000@gmx.net>
Message-ID: <20061109140510.GB20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 04:25:31PM +0530, Joe Steeve wrote:
> Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> > I think your initial question was more related to the keypair 
> > generated by tools like gnupg ("Does this mean., that if you purchase
> >  a key-pair from the CA, you'll have to ditch your current
> > key-pair?")? Gnupg ("web of trust scheme") and the CA-based system
> > ("PKI scheme") are completely disjoint, PKI is the one that is more
> > practical for authenticating several thousand clients to a tax-filing
> > website, for example.
> 
> Ah., ok.. i get it :) I had an idea that that CA will generate a
> key-pair sign it with their pvt-key and give the signed keys to you. I
> see I was wrong :)

Ok , there is nothing to feel bad or stupid. Crypto is overly complicated and PKI makes it still more complicated. There are so many things I don't know.

But I will try to clear some of the doubts. 

Most key concepts relating to keys have already been covered.

You generate a keypair, keep the private key safely encrypted with you. Usually private keys are encrypted with a password. It stays with you and never leaves you and you never show it to anyone.

The public key is meant to be public because only if people use your public key to encrypt data you decrypt with your private key. That is how people are supposed to use PKI.

Now , coming to signatures. It is very similar to our hand written signatures.

If you encrypt something with your private key, everybody can decrypt it since what you encrypted can be decrypted with your public key which is known to everyone.

So since only you have your private key, people can know that the message originated from you. And this serves as signature.  Simple, right?

Now, signature is appended to the message. Isn't this the way real world signatures work? So your message in plaintext is digested using MD5 or SHA1 or SHA512 or whatever and the digest is encrypted with your private key.

This encrypted digest is attached to your plaintext message. That is all.

Now let us come to certificates. OMG, now things get really messy.

Certificates are nothing but your public key signed by the private key of the CA. So your public key in plaintext is digested and signed by the private key of the CA and attached to your public key. So this is also easy.

What is the need for this? Why do we need a certificate authority(CA)?

Since public key is anyway public. Why do you want someone to certify it?

This is to avoid tampering since anybody can replace your public key with somebody else's.

That is why you have various identifying information like name, e-mail address blah blah blah based on X.500 directory parameters along with your public key in your certificate.

Ok, till now things are somewhat digestable. 

But certification presents a unique problem. The CA is not universally trusted. So you need several levels of certifications and things start getting really complicated for everyone.

I will give a real life analogy. Let us say a company in US is recruiting you. If you are from say Anna university, that US company may not know Anna university. So if Anna university is recognized by Indian govt. and if US company trusts Indian govt, then they can trust you.

This is a hierarchical real life model translated to virtual world in a straight forward manner by PKI. But there are so many complications I am not getting into. I am frankly not much interested in all those permutation combinations.

PGP has a very different approach towards trust. It argues for a decentralised model in which you determine who to trust and who not to trust. Hence the concept of keyrings.

This makes lot of sense because if you are plotting against a government and talking to your cabal members using encrypted e-mail you can't go by govt. issued certs. :)

It is like keeping a fox in charge of your cattle. 

So in this case, you certify that a particular friend is trusted through an out of band mechanism, say over phone or in person. And you assign a certain trust value between 0 and 4 or something. So you can start people certified by your friend and so on.

I think the difference is somewhat obvious now.

But PGP web of trust is not relevant for situations outside of encrypted e-mail. (It seems to have certain other narrow applications too )

For all practical uses we have to rely on PKI and X.509 certificates.

But the real world crypto use is somewhat cloudy in my brain since I only know the theoretical aspects.

Hence my curiosity on what is going on with digital signatures around. 

Thanks for all the responses.

regards,
Girish

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 19:43:01 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Nov  9 19:43:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610611090349y429dc8b4k3caadab2738b88b2@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<d2a92d610611090349y429dc8b4k3caadab2738b88b2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061109141301.GC20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 12:49:55PM +0100, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> On 09/11/06, Sarad AV <jtrjtrjtr2001@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >Yes and we need to authenticate the CA too.
> >
> >The unfortunate thing about the TCS-CA is that you
> >will have to do a one time import of the TCS's
> >certificate, unlike Thawte, VISA or Vesign whose
> >certificates comes default with the Firefox web
> >browser.
> 
> Two points that occured to me.
> 
> 1. You needn't import the TCS CA into your Firefox if the CA public
> certificate is signed by one of those who's already present in your
> root store. You can have a chain of trust like Verisign->TCS->You.

But if the browser does not ship with TCS-CA then this does not seem possible. If it is already in the chain, then there is no need to add it either.

> 
> 2. In the proposed system (online tax filing), I imagine the
> certificate is used purely to authenticate the user to the server, so
> quite likely only the server requires the TCS CA handy.

This seems logical to me.

But as I told before I don't know about real world needs.

regards,
Girish

> environment that one grows in strengthens some connections. So if the
> connections that handle math and logic is strong you end up with a high
> score in an IQ test and can call yourself 'intelligent'. But to think that
> someone who has strong connections in the areas that handle eye, leg, hand
> co-ordination are brutes is silly! I would'nt call Picasso dumb because he
> cannot solve simple math problems! He had a view of the world which was
> beyond our imagination.
>

On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 03:22:49PM +0530, R. Ramkumar wrote:
> I don't know what you mean by a Windows based protocol. The details of
> the protocol are well known and there are many clients for Direct
> Connect protocol in Linux as well... linuxdcpp, dcgui2, rccp, valknut,
> microdc etc. In fact, some of them (like microdc) outperform their
> windows counterparts in terms of performance. As a matter of fact,
> dc++, the primary client for Windows (there are others which have
> forked off it) is Free Software and linuxdcpp is its Linux port.
> 
> My personal opinion... DC is one of the better p2p protocols existing
> today... You can look at the website for the features :)

On Tue, Nov 07, 2006 at 11:30:29AM +0530, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> 
> On 07-Nov-06, at 11:12 AM, ???.????????????????????? wrote:
> 
> >Well, the latest November edition of TUX magazine impressed me a  
> >lot. To be
> >cirulated it has to be pdf which can also be made available online.
> 
> i feel scribus + inkscape + gimp + blender would be fine for this -  
> we can produce it as if it was print and distribute as a pdf for the  
> time being.
> 
> we could use a collaborative authoring application - silva running on  
> zope would be nice as it has enough version control and workflow  
> features for our purpose - to write the articles. I ran a print  
> newsmagazine for several years. That was in my doze days and i used  
> corel draw, photoshop and page maker.

I first of all apologize for carelessness on my part. 

I had been tied up with work.

I think Tamil or English is not a big concern. And I also appreciate very much the fact that there are people who can translate stuff. So I think it is a non issue. 

And the point about taking technology to the masses also taken. As far as I am concerned if we enable people to do computing in local languages we can speed up adoption.

Another side effect is that people will develop pride about one's culture and appreciate the fact that there are technologists who care for them.

And it might be a nice way to get people started on to computers and technology and they can pick up English along the way .

So the language issue though very important should not be the fundamental focus of discussion right now.

This is my humble opinion.

First let us focus on getting high quality technical subject matter.

After that grammar, language, translation etc. can be handled. 

And let us take it up slowly. I was thinking of a bimonthly edition. 

What do people think?

Later if it gathers enough momentum we can make it monthly , fortnightly or whatever. But I think only monthly issues will be sustainable in the long run.

I think someone has to take initiative and the "buck should stop there."

Otherwise it will be hard to execute the plan.

I am somewhat unwilling at this point largely because I am yet to keep my promise of the tech talk. I am hoping that I send the slides at least  by Nov 20th. That will give me confidence to take up higher responsibilities.

For now, few people have come forward Parthan, Kenneth and various other folks whose names don't display in my mutt mail client.

And you people have experience in this field. There are so many of us who can write articles but we would not know how to release a magazine.

Any thoughts?

How many volunteers are there?

I think ILUGC has immense potential, both technical and otherwise. 

Releasing a magazine will immensely popularize our cause and also bring about a lot of other nice side effects.

Primarily I have the most selfish motive of bringing about a culture of innovation, creativity and technical excellence in our beautiful country.

If people start writing articles that lot of folks read it will help breed the above qualities.

What say people?

I shall get back with a table of contents or something similar for the first issue sometime soon.

Sorry again for the delay. I was tied up with an immediate deliverable.

regards,
Girish

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Nov  9 20:33:40 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Nov  9 20:33:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Routing Problem
In-Reply-To: <4552F61E.6040603@vinayras.com>
Message-ID: <20061109150340.27221.qmail@web50209.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Vinay Yadav <vinay@vinayras.com> wrote:
> 1) Ping is working fine from FC4 & FC3. Ping to
> google.com worked fine.

Which means your FC3 and FC4 can use the Internet.

> Firefox is not able to open site.

Edit->Preferences->General->Connection Settings and
set "Direct connection to the Internet".

With the above setup, you can have a default route to
your FC1 machine and set nameserver in
/etc/resolv.conf file to your FC1 machine.

You can check your "/sbin/route -n" entry from your
FC3 or FC4 machine.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com  Thu Nov  9 21:08:26 2006
From: jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com (Sarad AV)
Date: Thu Nov  9 21:08:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
Message-ID: <20061109153826.42530.qmail@web33315.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

From: Girish Venkatachalam
<girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com>
 
> 1. You needn't import the TCS CA into your Firefox
if >the CA public
> certificate is signed by one of those who's already
>present in your
> root store. You can have a chain of trust like
>Verisign->TCS->You.

That would be nice if it was that way but it doesn't
seem to be the case for TCS or any other CA in India.

Have a look at this
On TCS's certificate chain
http://www.tcs-ca.tcs.co.in/index.jsp?leftHtml=html/chainleft.html&rightHtml=html/chain.html&leftTitle=Repository&right1stLink=cert_chain&right1stTitle=Certificate%20Chain&right2ndTitle=Repository&highlight=0

and on  Controller of Certifying Authorities (CCA), in
India
http://www.cca.gov.in/

It says-"CCA at the root of the trust chain in India."

and I can't find the CCA's certificate on my firefox
browser.

Sarad.

Date: Thu Nov  9 21:21:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <20061109141301.GC20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<d2a92d610611090349y429dc8b4k3caadab2738b88b2@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109141301.GC20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611090751p5ad0a883uc6577d69f7882520@mail.gmail.com>

On 09/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> > 1. You needn't import the TCS CA into your Firefox if the CA public
> > certificate is signed by one of those who's already present in your
> > root store. You can have a chain of trust like Verisign->TCS->You.
>
> But if the browser does not ship with TCS-CA then this does not seem possible.

It needn't be present. Assuming the above
Verisign->TCS->https://mysite.com chain of trust, if you visit
https://mysite.com, you are presented with mysite.com's certificate
signed by TCS, and TCS's public key signed by Verisign. So long as the
browser has Verisign's public key handy, it can verify
https://mysite.com to whatever extend of trust the user is willing to
place on the site.

Binand

On 09/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> I think there is a slight communication problem here.
>
> Can you please clarify what you mean by "Certifies your identity and attaches it to the key?"

Think of it as the electronic equivalent of getting photostatic copies
of your certificates attested by a gazetted officer. The officer
certifies the copy as a true one and attaches his signature/office
seal to the document.

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 04:55:58PM +0100, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> Think of it as the electronic equivalent of getting photostatic copies
> of your certificates attested by a gazetted officer. The officer
> certifies the copy as a true one and attaches his signature/office
> seal to the document.

As I guessed it is a terminology problem. All signatures are attached.

So without attaching the signature of the CA, a certificate is no certificate. So what is attached is the signature of the CA and not the key.

I think my previous mail talks about this.

Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610611090751p5ad0a883uc6577d69f7882520@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<d2a92d610611090349y429dc8b4k3caadab2738b88b2@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109141301.GC20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611090751p5ad0a883uc6577d69f7882520@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061109162127.GA1477@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 04:51:25PM +0100, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
 >
> >But if the browser does not ship with TCS-CA then this does not seem 
> >possible.
> 
> It needn't be present. Assuming the above
> Verisign->TCS->https://mysite.com chain of trust, if you visit
> https://mysite.com, you are presented with mysite.com's certificate
> signed by TCS, and TCS's public key signed by Verisign. So long as the
> browser has Verisign's public key handy, it can verify
> https://mysite.com to whatever extend of trust the user is willing to
> place on the site.

Ok let me try to think aloud about the whole affair. 

I am afraid I have to leave the browser alone since my experience has been theoretical.

If I understand things correctly there are two directions in which traversal happens in a certificate chain. Either from the root CA level , you traverse down the hierarchy to fish out a particular certificate with a certain subject or you start from a leaf node, say a user's certificate and you traverse up until you hit a node that is trusted by the other party.

Most of the time the traversal is done from the leaf node upwards.

For instance, take the case of 

A -> B -> C -> D

A issues a cert to B which issues one to C which issues one to D.

Now D is authenticating against a public server. If the server does not have any of the certificates A,B or C in his list of trusted certs, then D is rejected. 

Now coming back to our discussion.

To have 

Verisign->TCS->mysite.com list of certificates with you, you should first import the TCS certificate into your browser right?

Or am I missing something?

I positively admit a lack of clarity as this is something I should most certainly know but don't. :(

regards,
Girish
From binand at gmail.com  Thu Nov  9 22:38:03 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Thu Nov  9 22:38:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <20061109162127.GA1477@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<d2a92d610611090349y429dc8b4k3caadab2738b88b2@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109141301.GC20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611090751p5ad0a883uc6577d69f7882520@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109162127.GA1477@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611090908t3b8e1f6evd261b550ea58013b@mail.gmail.com>

On 09/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> Verisign->TCS->mysite.com list of certificates with you, you should first import the TCS certificate into your browser right?
>
> Or am I missing something?

Yes. The fact that mysite.com presents to the user, its own
certificate signed by TCS, and TCS's signing certificate signed by
Verisign. So, TCS's signing certificate needn't be "imported" into the
browser (importing is basically just ensuring you have a local copy of
TCS's signing certificate).

Binand

On 11/9/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> But certificates are essential for many real world applications, so we cannot ignore them for long.

True, the world is becoming more and more insecure and people are
exploring new ways to keep things secure. Here is a list (search for
'List of Certificate Uses')
ftp://ftp.isi.edu/in-notes/rfc2692.txt

- Mac OS X uses certificates to verify updates of important components.
- Windows 2K and later use certificates to verify drivers.
