From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 06:08:13 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Fri Nov 10 06:08:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20061107122555.GA14594@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <4553C9F5.8020802@gmail.com>

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> 	I  hear quite a lot about digital signatures in India. That you will require that for credit card purchases and tax filing.
>
> 	I am told that some company in Blore provides solutions for this.
>
> 	What exactly is going on? 
>   
The Information Technology Act, 2000, was enacted to provide legal 
recognition for transactions carried out electronically, and is based on 
the United Nations model law adopted by UNCITRAL, in 1997, and is fairly 
uniform across the world.   The basic idea is to provide alternatives to 
paper based methods of communication and storage of information. 

MCA 21 of the Ministry of Company Affairs is a major initiative in India 
to make active use of the enactment. Please visit http://www.mca.gov.in/ 
for information and details on where and how it has use and application. 
http://www.mca.gov.in/MinistryWebsite/dca/dsc/certifying-new.html gives 
market details for Digital Signature Certificates. The handbook for 
using digital signatures is at:
http://www2.mca.gov.in/MinistryWebsite/dca/help/ProcessHandbook.pdf

Users need to exercise great caution in using these facilities, and the 
pitfalls are listed at:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_certificate
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_third_party

It should be noted that the CA is doing nothing more than attesting your 
identity.  The above link says:

<quote>
How to arrange for (trustable) third parties of this type is an unsolved 
problem. So long as there are motives of greed, politics, revenge, etc, 
those who perform (or supervise) work done by such an entity will 
provide potential loopholes through which the necessary trust may leak. 
The problem, perhaps an unsolvable one, is ancient and notorious. That 
large impersonal corporations make promises of accuracy in their 
attestations of the correctness of a claimed public key \leftrightarrow 
user correspondence (eg, by a certificate authority 
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certificate_authority> as a part of a 
public key infrastructure 
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_key_infrastructure>) changes little.
</quote>

AFAIK, the age old tradition of building trust with personal contact is 
the only real way to ensure trust, and the only security that is known 
and proved to work well is that of openness and publicity.

Our Supreme Court had the occasion in Naresh v. State of Maharashtra 
[AIR 1967 SC 1] to consider the merits of open and public trials for 
"healthy objective and fair administration of justice," and quoted 
Bentham with approval as follows:

     "In the darkness of secrecy, sinister interest, and evil in every 
    shape, have full swing. ... Publicity is the very soul of justice. 
    It is the keenest spur to exertion, and the surest of all guards 
    against improbity. It keeps the Judge himself while trying under 
    trial in the sense that the security of securities is publicity."

The principles laid are equally true for filings or transactions that 
are public in nature.  It is easy to see that the greatest danger comes 
from the obligation to keep your private key a secret or make sure that 
only you can use your digital signature certificate.  On the contrary, 
merely publishing filings online (albeit without any complicated 
encryption or digital signature, in just plain text) offers maximum 
security, in that, anyone who sees something going wrong merely has to 
raise hue and cry with the truth, and does not have to investigate how 
and where his secrets were compromised.  A simple login id with password 
should work fine in a world where people are straightforward and honest.

The bottom line is that the digital signature certificate is just a 
complicated method to get a login, and the usual precautions taken with 
passwords apply. 

-Ramanraj K
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 06:32:19 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Nov 10 06:32:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <5d0d0e310611091019w604e338fk4ddb298fddd0c8f9@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<5d0d0e310611091019w604e338fk4ddb298fddd0c8f9@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061110010219.GA24394@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 11:49:48PM +0530, Vijairaj wrote:
> On 11/9/06, Sarad AV <jtrjtrjtr2001@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >   There is really know way to know if there is a man
> >in the middle attack underway(though unlikely), when
> >you download and import the TCS certificate.
> 
> Why not, if the certificate is downloaded from an authenticated host?
> 

Sarad is right. There is a lot of slip between the cup and the lip.

Recently my cousin's yahoo! account was broken into and the attacker spent mney thro' his Paypal account.

My cousin used a very strong password. Still this happened.

It is very hard to analyze the security properties of an architecture.

And real life bugs and implementation slackness makes things much worse than we can imagine.

Being paranoid is the norm rather than the exception for security engineers.

So Sarad is on the dot. 

regards,
Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 07:00:58 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Nov 10 07:01:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] digital signatures in India
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610611090908t3b8e1f6evd261b550ea58013b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061109083125.38727.qmail@web33314.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<d2a92d610611090349y429dc8b4k3caadab2738b88b2@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109141301.GC20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611090751p5ad0a883uc6577d69f7882520@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109162127.GA1477@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611090908t3b8e1f6evd261b550ea58013b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061110013058.GB24394@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 09, 2006 at 06:08:03PM +0100, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> Yes. The fact that mysite.com presents to the user, its own
> certificate signed by TCS, and TCS's signing certificate signed by
> Verisign. So, TCS's signing certificate needn't be "imported" into the
> browser (importing is basically just ensuring you have a local copy of
> TCS's signing certificate).

Wait Binand. This is getting a bit above my head. Let us start from first principles.

Always in any authentication setup, there is a "supplicant" and a "verifier."

In the real world, when I produce my ration card to the gas company(Dammit, I can't get a new cylinder now since I dont have a ration card), I am the supplicant and the gas company is the verifier.

This is when certificates  are used for authentication. Certificates are mainly used for this though it is also used for exchanging keys since the certificate contains the public using which anyone can communicate securely with you. 

Now, there are two cases.
  
  a) User authenticates to server
  b) Server authenticates to user

Okay?

Now, let us begin.

It is always the supplicant or the party who wants to prove his/her authenticity that presents a certificate/certificate chain. The verifier looks for someone whom he trusts amongst the list of certificates in the chain. The use can alternately specify multiple distinct certificate chains also.

This is like I produce a US college certificate and an Indian degree to a European company. I don't know who they trust more.

So to summarize when the user authenticates to server, user presents the chain.

Usually user authenticates using password. 

When the server authenticates to user(this is the common scenario), When you click "Accept certificate" that is what you are doing. Since if the server is masqueraded then you end up revealing your password and other credentials and the disaster that happened with my cousin recently might happen to you too. (He lost around 500$ thro' paypal as his yahoo! acct got broken into,but I hear paypal has refunded it).

So we have to identify which of the two is happening here.

We import different certificates into the browser to add it to our trust store. This will be useful to use only when we are the verifier and not when we are the supplicant. Does this make sense?

Because just by importing a certificate we cannot create a certificate chain. If our certificate is signed by TCS-CA. Then the chain exists automatically since who all have certified TCS-CA is neither our concern nor do we have to worry about it.

So that chain is built automatically without our doing anything.

I now understand very clearly what you are saying. I think everyone can easily get it now.

That we need to import only root CAs into our browser.

So if TCS-CA is root CA we import. Otherwise there is no need since the particular case that you mention or when there are 100 certificates between Verisign and TCS-CA will all work without our having to import anything.

OMG, this was such a simple idea, wonder why I missed it all along.

So now comes the question, is TCS-CA the root CA?

regards,
Girish

Wait man. Rome was not built in a day. :)

I am still thinking hard whether we should make it quarterly like Cisco IPJ or bimonthly. Monthly is out of question.

What "managers"? You don't want me started on how much I hate corporates, do you? :)

You need one guy ( Editor)  who is responsible for kicking the butts of others to get people to write articles. And he should mentor them, hand hold, criticize them, call them up at 2:00 am at night etc. to ensure that he gets good quality articles.

The editor will also write editorials in the first page which usually makes very interesting reading in most magazines. :)

And he has to take the final decision after getting inputs from all of us as to what the theme of each issue will be. I think linuxjournal decides this well in advance.

Then he has to coordinate getting art work done, and getting articles on time.

Plain and simple. 

We need a guy of high standing, seniority and respected in our community.

What better choice than Kenneth? :)

Or Raman? 

I want someone older than we kids. :)

To begin with I can identify one bakra at least. 

Ramkumar, can you promise an article on zsh for the first issue? :)

You get the distinction of being the first bakra for our magazine.

Also we need a catchy name for the magazine.

Suggestions please. And a logo.

I don't like a "Westernised" name.

It should sound distinctly Indian. At the same time it should not have any regional/cultural/ethnic overtones.

regards,
Girish

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 07:44:31 2006

On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 06:08:13AM +0530, Ramanraj K wrote:
> 
> AFAIK, the age old tradition of building trust with personal contact is 
> the only real way to ensure trust, and the only security that is known 
> and proved to work well is that of openness and publicity.

What does the above statement mean? I wonder.

I understand the first part of your statement perfectly, not the second.
> 
> Our Supreme Court had the occasion in Naresh v. State of Maharashtra 
> [AIR 1967 SC 1] to consider the merits of open and public trials for 
> "healthy objective and fair administration of justice," and quoted 
> Bentham with approval as follows:
> 
>     "In the darkness of secrecy, sinister interest, and evil in every 
>    shape, have full swing. ... Publicity is the very soul of justice. 
>    It is the keenest spur to exertion, and the surest of all guards 
>    against improbity. It keeps the Judge himself while trying under 
>    trial in the sense that the security of securities is publicity."

Is that so? Then how come Sanjay Dutt and Salman Khan are roaming about scot free? And Sidhu?

And poor people who have nobody to argue their case being incarcerated illeglly?

In all cultures and at all times, clout has mattered much more than everything else. :)

This is true even in America and elsewhere.

I get your point that the press should be open and democratic and that by bringing things to light people will be scared to do wrong things but it is not a panacea against all crime.

> 
> The principles laid are equally true for filings or transactions that 
> are public in nature.  It is easy to see that the greatest danger comes 
> from the obligation to keep your private key a secret or make sure that 
> only you can use your digital signature certificate.  On the contrary, 
> merely publishing filings online (albeit without any complicated 
> encryption or digital signature, in just plain text) offers maximum 
> security, in that, anyone who sees something going wrong merely has to 
> raise hue and cry with the truth, and does not have to investigate how 
> and where his secrets were compromised.  A simple login id with password 
> should work fine in a world where people are straightforward and honest.
> 
> The bottom line is that the digital signature certificate is just a 
> complicated method to get a login, and the usual precautions taken with 
> passwords apply. 

I agree PKI is overly complicated. I don't think the term "digital signature certificate" is correct never mind if it used in official technical documentation.

Signatures and certificates are closely related and you can't have one without the other but at the same time they are distinct. So you either have a
certificate or a digital signature.

Anyway I am not too bothered about superficial things.

I don't understand your argument above. What are you trying to say?

I think real world and digital world are more or less equivalent in the sense that instead of keeping your license or house key safe, you have to now keep your private key safely.

And like reading what you are attesting before signing you know what you are doing when using digital signatures.

But there is much more room for fraud and things going wrong in the digital world because there can be trapdoors, Trojan horses, viruses etc...

Which means that people should start using open source solutions to minimize this. :)

Thanks for your detailed mail. I don't mean to pick at you, just some sincere queries and concerns, that is all.

regards,
Girish

On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 08:22:42AM +0530, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> 
> On 10-Nov-06, at 8:07 AM, ???.????????????????????? wrote:
> 
> >If the magazine is going to be a English one - Swatantra Sanchika  
> >is my
> >suggestion....
> 
> as already mentioned, i am not interested in yet another english one  
> - a start of art, kick-ass tamil one is needed with a good tamil name

My idea is to make a world class Indian technical magazine.

And I have the ulterior motive of kicking the butt of ***.

So a Tamil "only" magazine does not fit in. Does it?

As I already mentioned language is beside the point.

I will try asking the bsd-india@ to see if there is some traction there.

I want to stop the hegemony and high handedness of *** and at the same time also bring about the jewels in you people in a manner that all can see and appreciate.

I wonder why you guys are going in the language track. 

It is defeatist I tell you. If you want to serve the Tamil cause then develop localized software or still better make devices that talk and understand Tamil.

If you want to reach the masses through Tamil, then an English magazine that is translated perfectly into Tamil will do that much much better than a Tamil only magazine.

Think about it. 

What I am saying might sound counter intuitive but it is true.

It is better to welcome comments, criticism and reviews from a much larger audience instead of locking it in Tamil language whereby you are restricting your canvas.

This positively reeks of misguided values.

We are losing ourselves in some sort of defeatist ideology instead of serving the goal and practical purpose of breeding excellence and taking technology to the masses.

regards,
Girish

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 11:25:02 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Fri Nov 10 11:28:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazines
In-Reply-To: <4D074C9F-D80C-4C59-A3BF-E9800B2D31FC@thenilgiris.com>
References: <20061109162148.58CBD1DB27A@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>	<1163124485.5238.4.camel@localhost>	<20061110015003.GC24394@lakshmi.susmita.org>	<e3dcb5360611091759p1b2ba853gc0ec322e6701da95@mail.gmail.com>	<E2080532-EE1E-4A9B-BC40-B5D691D66C24@thenilgiris.com>	<e3dcb5360611091853s3fea4928v4d467cd206dd00ad@mail.gmail.com>
	<4D074C9F-D80C-4C59-A3BF-E9800B2D31FC@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <45541436.9040507@gmail.com>

My Thoughts,

* My vote goes for a Tamil Magazine, as there are lots of English 
magazines available.
* I will say, start small, work more, make big. Concentrating too much 
on printing, selling and other commercial aspects can be placed at the 
sides and let us ponder about the content
* The content of the proposed magazine depends upon the intended 
audience of the magazine. If the intended audience is common or low 
level thechies, then no use in putting up geeky stuff.
* I favor individual sections on hot news, for the beginners, power 
users, happenings around, new releases and hot apps. May be a few other 
sections will do end in a decent magazine.
* Think, for the initial stages a wiki will do good. Lets put up 
articles there and editing be done on them. lets there be a dead end for 
the articles to be put up and get edited. The team lead / editor then 
selects articles from these collections and prepares the new issue.

Hope we start working soon, we have another 20 days left to bring our 
first issue December 1st :)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan (TechnoFreak)

.   A Proud GNU/Linux User and Ubuntero
.0.
..0 [Web] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Parthan
000 [Blog]http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com

From vinay at vinayras.com  Fri Nov 10 12:25:58 2006
From: vinay at vinayras.com (Vinay Yadav)
Date: Fri Nov 10 12:21:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Routing Problem
In-Reply-To: <4553F16F.6070301@gmx.net>
References: <4552F61E.6040603@vinayras.com>	<e0900f3e0611090430s47971381v51b14d691106f5eb@mail.gmail.com>	<45533048.6030401@vinayras.com>
	<4553F16F.6070301@gmx.net>
Message-ID: <4554227E.90002@vinayras.com>

Hi Joe,

> What do you get for 'iptables -t nat -L', 'iptables -t mangle -L' and
> 'iptables -t filter -L' ?

Here are the required outputs.

# iptables -t nat -L
Chain PREROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain POSTROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination
MASQUERADE  all  --  anywhere             anywhere

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination


# iptables -t mangle -L
Chain PREROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain FORWARD (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain POSTROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

# iptables -t filter -L
Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain FORWARD (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Regards
Vinay

Mob: 9422113939

------------------------------------------------
Vinay Yadav			vinayRas Infotech
www.vinayras.com		Nagpur, India
------------------------------------------------
    Linux Consultant & PHP/MySQL Developer

From dandolls at yahoo.co.in  Fri Nov 10 12:42:13 2006
From: dandolls at yahoo.co.in (amit saha)
Date: Fri Nov 10 12:42:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magaznine
Message-ID: <20061110071213.43447.qmail@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>

Gisrish says,
My idea is to make a world class Indian technical magazine. 

And I have the ulterior motive of kicking the butt of ***. 

So a Tamil "only" magazine does not fit in. Does it? 

As I already mentioned language is beside the point. 

I will try asking the bsd-india@ to see if there is some traction there. 

I want to stop the hegemony and high handedness of *** and at the same time also bring about the jewels in you people in a manner that all can see and appreciate. 

I wonder why you guys are going in the language track. 

It is defeatist I tell you. If you want to serve the Tamil cause then develop localized software or still better make devices that talk and understand Tamil. 

If you want to reach the masses through Tamil, then an English magazine that is translated perfectly into Tamil will do that much much better than a Tamil only magazine. 

Think about it. 

What I am saying might sound counter intuitive but it is true. 

It is better to welcome comments, criticism and reviews from a much larger audience instead of locking it in Tamil language whereby you are restricting your canvas. 

This positively reeks of misguided values. 

We are losing ourselves in some sort of defeatist ideology instead of serving the goal and practical purpose of breeding excellence and taking technology to the masses. 

regards, 
Girish 


Parthan writes,

My Thoughts, 

* My vote goes for a Tamil Magazine, as there are lots of English 
magazines available. 
* I will say, start small, work more, make big. Concentrating too much 
on printing, selling and other commercial aspects can be placed at the 
sides and let us ponder about the content 
* The content of the proposed magazine depends upon the intended 
audience of the magazine. If the intended audience is common or low 
level thechies, then no use in putting up geeky stuff. 
* I favor individual sections on hot news, for the beginners, power 
users, happenings around, new releases and hot apps. May be a few other 
sections will do end in a decent magazine. 
* Think, for the initial stages a wiki will do good. Lets put up 
articles there and editing be done on them. lets there be a dead end for 
the articles to be put up and get edited. The team lead / editor then 
selects articles from these collections and prepares the new issue. 

Hope we start working soon, we have another 20 days left to bring our 
first issue December 1st :) 

--

My thoughts 

well a Tamil only magazine will actually limit the participation  both from the authors and the readers. I am a bengali and i dont know tamil. so i do not have any means by which i could contribute to the mag for instance.

So perhaps griish's suggestion that we could have a English mag and a Tamil translation does hold more promise .

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Fri Nov 10 12:47:06 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Fri Nov 10 12:47:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazines
Message-ID: <1373.61.247.255.57.1163143026.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

> My idea is to make a world class Indian technical magazine.
> And I have the ulterior motive of kicking the butt of ***.
> So a Tamil "only" magazine does not fit in. Does it?
> As I already mentioned language is beside the point.

> Girish
The problem is that there is already a glut of magazines in English.

However, the problem with bringing out this magazine only in Tamil and
getting authors to contribute in Tamil will be that it will severely limit
the number of people who can contribute towards it. The vast majority of
the good technical content out there is in English and most authors are
probably more conversant in English than in Tamil.

Having said that, I think there is a need for good technical documentation
in vernacular languages including Tamil.

A lot of people from the villages and small towns may be good programmers,
but their inability to communicate very well in English, or even
understand technical documentation in English, limits their ability to
gain skills and that is a shame. I faced this problem with someone who I
was trying to train to program. I personally taught some of the basic
computer skills, but for this person to advance in skills, he must be able
to read documentation available in the web, get good books on the subject
etc. However, since all of that was missing, he was having real problems
improving his skills.

If there are enough people willing to translate documentation from the web
- it may be stuff from the PHP docs, the Java docs etc, and then place
them online, then it will definitely be useful.

Also, if authors can send in articles in english and have that translated
into Tamil for inclusion into the magazine, it will be great.

And thirdly, if existing applications can be translated into Tamil and
included into CDs sold along with the magazine, or made available for
download, it will benefit a lot of people.

So in a sense, you need the following workflows:

Foreign language authors -> Translators -> Print / Web
Foreign language documents -> Translators -> Print / Web
Foreign language apps -> Translators -> Programmers -> Web / CD

Thanks,
PK

Languages. Since we speak Tamil, we took Tamil.

Its equallay appreciable to start a Bengali edition if you could form a
Team. Begali people should get the techinical resources in Bengali for sure.

translated to Tamil/ Bengali etc., Or a Cartoon n/w program translated to
native Languages.

The originality of each language will be Lost. The motto is to express the
concepts in mind in one's own mother tongue. May it be Bengali or tamil.

Have you read the India today's Tamil editorial translations... Oooof...
Nativity at total Loss! Rather look at any other Magazine like Kalki or
Kumudam (not Off late)... Thats what is being spoken here...

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 14:17:28 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Nov 10 14:17:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magaznin
In-Reply-To: <e3dcb5360611092327k401b1fafl5b91455fed17b024@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061110071213.43447.qmail@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>
	<e3dcb5360611092327k401b1fafl5b91455fed17b024@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061110084728.GB28773@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 12:57:15PM +0530, ???.????????????????????? wrote:
> Its equallay appreciable to start a Bengali edition if you could form a
> Team. Begali people should get the techinical resources in Bengali for sure.
> A Land of Tagore and Vivekananda! And Maharishi Arabindo and Nethaji.... It
> would be gr8 if you could make the intiative to start a Bengali edition.

That idea did cross my mind. I have far more hope from Tamil and Bengali cultures than any other.

I definitely don't mean to offend anyone but culturally speaking our nation has benefitted the most by these two cultures.

Gigantic world moving personalities were born here.

But then there are so many other great men born in so many other places too. :) What about Gandhi eh?

The West does not recognize anyone as much him, do you know?

And the language forms an essential part of both sensibilities.

At the same time one should not be narrow minded and dogmatic and look down upon others.

There are close to 800 dialects/languages. What is important is nationalist ideals and if possible even global ideals but with a strict local context.

We definitely do not want fanaticism in the name of language.

We already have enough in the name of caste and religion.

> 
> The technology of creating magazine is going to be common... on which we can
> work together.. and the medium of communication between us can either be
> Hindi/ English.
> 
> >So perhaps griish's suggestion that we could have a English mag and a
> Tamil translation > > does hold more promise .
> 
> Translation kills native thinking. It will end up in Hollywood movies
> translated to Tamil/ Bengali etc., Or a Cartoon n/w program translated to
> native Languages.

I did think long and deep about this.

I disagree. 

Movies and cartoons are a work of art. Technology is black and white like mathematics.

And guess what , I really don't believe in a separate solution for developing and poor nations.

Today India's economy is so good that a computer is definitely within the reach of most educated public.

This is the reason I am advocating for an English base.

Dammit, who the hell is gonna pay for vernacular tech journals?

And how long are you going to motivate people with ideals and cultural bullshit?

You need hard cash, money to motivate excellence.

I wonder why the stupid corporate world in India has not got this idea in spite of playing the game for 6 decades.

That there is plenty of money in excellence.

Mark my words. I cannot support any initiative in which there is even a slightest chance of getting a feeling of "inferiority" or "weakness".

People dread world classness in India as though it is some sort of demon that is going to swallow you.

I KNOW as opposed to think that Indian technical talent is world class.

(Have you read other worldwide mailing lists like freebsd-questions@?)

I just want it to come out in the open so the world takes notice.

Long long ago Swami Vivekananda quite clearly expressed this fact.

If at all there is any hope for India it is only in opening up to the advanced, economic giants, the West.

Otherwise we cannot sustain for long.

Today all that is happening, be it call centers or IT industry or whatever is thanks to Western wealth.

Let us not forget that.

That also is a healthy ecosystem in which there is free flow of ideas, money and what not.

Let us not lock up ourselves in mediocrity by thinking local.

Think global, but act locally. 
> 
> The originality of each language will be Lost. The motto is to express the
> concepts in mind in one's own mother tongue. May it be Bengali or tamil.

How will you express "virtualization" in Tamil or Bengali? Or Sanskrit?

Just think. You will get what I mean, not too hard.
> 
> Have you read the India today's Tamil editorial translations... Oooof...
> Nativity at total Loss! Rather look at any other Magazine like Kalki or
> Kumudam (not Off late)... Thats what is being spoken here...

I know that the media in Tamil Nadu and Kerala are really sound and advanced.

It even beats the Western media. There is far less gossip here.

But then, India Today might not be a good example.

All this is happening due to the politics, "this is enough" thinking that has taken over our race.

Pity!

Let us understand and appreciate the importance of money first.

If you pay people well they do world class stuff.

And that of thinking big as Amit said. It is not thinking big.

How big? :)

It is thinking "world class excellence".

My usual disclaimer.

I only want to help. Never hurt anyone.

If you find something wrong, please forgive. :)

regards,
Girish

On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 12:42:13PM +0530, amit saha wrote:

Hi,
> Gisrish says,
> My idea is to make a world class Indian technical magazine. 
> 
> And I have the ulterior motive of kicking the butt of ***. 
> 
> So a Tamil "only" magazine does not fit in. Does it? 
 
> As I already mentioned language is beside the point. 
> 
> I will try asking the bsd-india@ to see if there is some traction there. 
> 
> I want to stop the hegemony and high handedness of *** and at the same time also bring about the jewels in you people in a manner that all can see and appreciate. 
> 
> I wonder why you guys are going in the language track. 
> 
> It is defeatist I tell you. If you want to serve the Tamil cause then develop localized software or still better make devices that talk and understand Tamil. 
> 
> If you want to reach the masses through Tamil, then an English magazine that is translated perfectly into Tamil will do that much much better than a Tamil only magazine. 

Yes i a agree with u. It should not be "tamil only" magazine, which kills appreciation from other users who are non-tamilians across the country/nations.
One needs to agree that the defacto universal language for communication across nations is English. so coexistence of tamil and english versions is most preferrable.
Pls note that almost all the people who are into linux are aware of english, not tamil. lets keep the motive of educating masses abt linux as top proiroty and eliminate lingustic chauvanism. -- let it be an "open magazine" with respect to natural languages.

regards,
KM

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 14:31:43 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Nov 10 14:32:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazines
In-Reply-To: <1373.61.247.255.57.1163143026.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>
References: <1373.61.247.255.57.1163143026.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>
Message-ID: <20061110090143.GC28773@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 12:47:06PM +0530, Prem Kurian Philip wrote:
> The problem is that there is already a glut of magazines in English.

Who says so?

There is a lot of glut in software too.

There is only one open source print magazine called linuxjournal.

No other. Not even one for BSDs. You call it glut?

There are plenty for perl, this and that. But none of the same class and calibre of linuxjournal.

My idea is to compete with the only open source tech journal in India.

Where is the glut? Am I missing something?
> 
> However, the problem with bringing out this magazine only in Tamil and
> getting authors to contribute in Tamil will be that it will severely limit
> the number of people who can contribute towards it. The vast majority of
> the good technical content out there is in English and most authors are
> probably more conversant in English than in Tamil.
> 
> Having said that, I think there is a need for good technical documentation
> in vernacular languages including Tamil.
> 
> A lot of people from the villages and small towns may be good programmers,
> but their inability to communicate very well in English, or even
> understand technical documentation in English, limits their ability to
> gain skills and that is a shame. I faced this problem with someone who I
> was trying to train to program. I personally taught some of the basic
> computer skills, but for this person to advance in skills, he must be able
> to read documentation available in the web, get good books on the subject
> etc. However, since all of that was missing, he was having real problems
> improving his skills.

What have people with all the benefit of convent education and top notch engineering colleges done for India?

I don't mean to naysay or anything.

But the other day a call taxi driver was telling this.

"Thamizha vechundu mavarakka than mudiyum."

I felt insulted of course. But what to do?

That was his perspective and one has to respect it.

We should help people gain strength, not weaken them. In all the discussions this should be key.

If your idea is to take technology to the masses, remember that you also have to bring them towards technology.

I feel reminded of the relevant Tirukural here.

"Solluthal yarkum eliya ariavam,
	solliya vannam seyal."

It is all easy to talk, but how will you sustain a low end magazine meant for the poor in the long run?

Is any NGO gonna come forward?

At least will you survive till then?

Anyway I am not a heartless techie only focused on excellence.

If there is enough business and money in the game, I am willing to do service. And help less fortunate folks.

There is a saying in Hindi.

"Pehle ghar mein diya jalao, phir mandir mein."

First light the lamp at home, then worry about lighting it in the temple.

Really beautiful, isn't it?

So profound. 

First tell me where the money will come from. Then talk of charity.

> 
> If there are enough people willing to translate documentation from the web
> - it may be stuff from the PHP docs, the Java docs etc, and then place
> them online, then it will definitely be useful.

Provided they get paid for that.
> 
> Also, if authors can send in articles in english and have that translated
> into Tamil for inclusion into the magazine, it will be great.

This is no issue.
> 
> And thirdly, if existing applications can be translated into Tamil and
> included into CDs sold along with the magazine, or made available for
> download, it will benefit a lot of people.
> 
> So in a sense, you need the following workflows:
> 
> Foreign language authors -> Translators -> Print / Web
> Foreign language documents -> Translators -> Print / Web
> Foreign language apps -> Translators -> Programmers -> Web / CD

It should not become a low end transliteration shop. :)

So far of all mails received I think this has been most practical.


regards,
Girish

education of them needs to be in tamil. There is absolutely no  
shortage of matter in english to educate those who know/want english.

chauvinism - tamil is not my mother tongue, nor is it my second  
language. In fact it is my third language if anything. But in  
tamilnadu we need to do it in tamil to fill a void.

On 11/10/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 09:01:14AM +0530, Joe Steeve wrote:
> > Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> > > Ah, yes. Why not use a NAS solution instead? What do people use?
> >
>
> > Hmm., a SAN is completely different from a NAS box.
>
> PMI but I am curious. What are the differences?
>
>
A NAS makes a filesystem available over the network on which client machines
can read and write. The linux admin handbook says its just a fancy name for
a file server! A SAN makes block devices available over the network. Client
machines can create their own filesystems on this.

Using GNBD one can make thier hdd available as a block device over the
network. Check out RedHat documentation on this.

regds,
mano


-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!

*Meivarutha Kooli Tharum*
**
*> "Thamizha vechundu mavarakka than mudiyum."
*

to him,*
**
*Mella Thamizh Ini Saagumnnu.... (Tamil will die henceforth)*
**
*In the same song he also said the solution,*

*Piranaattu Nallarignar saathiangal Thamizh Moziyir Peyarththal Vendum*
*Iravatha Puthu Noolkal Thamizh Moziyir Iyarra Vendum*
**
*We need to compose the great works of intellectuals of the world in tamil*
*We have to write Books in Tamil that will live for ever *
**
That is exactly what I am speaking about nothing more. :-)

> First light the lamp at home, then worry about lighting it in the temple.
>
> Really beautiful, isn't it?
>
> So profound.
>
> First tell me where the money will come from. Then talk of charity.
>
> >
> > If there are enough people willing to translate documentation from the
> web
> > - it may be stuff from the PHP docs, the Java docs etc, and then place
> > them online, then it will definitely be useful.
>
> Provided they get paid for that.
> >
> > Also, if authors can send in articles in english and have that
> translated
> > into Tamil for inclusion into the magazine, it will be great.
>
> This is no issue.
> >
> > And thirdly, if existing applications can be translated into Tamil and
> > included into CDs sold along with the magazine, or made available for
> > download, it will benefit a lot of people.
> >
> > So in a sense, you need the following workflows:
> >
> > Foreign language authors -> Translators -> Print / Web
> > Foreign language documents -> Translators -> Print / Web
> > Foreign language apps -> Translators -> Programmers -> Web / CD
>
> It should not become a low end transliteration shop. :)
>
> So far of all mails received I think this has been most practical.
>
>
> regards,
> Girish
> _______________________________________________
> To unsubscribe, email ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in with
> "unsubscribe <password> <address>"
> in the subject or body of the message.
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc

In-Reply-To: <ed2d3c000611092257q5c325d35sb4711ab00df9a3e4@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/10/06, Thyagu rajan <citizenofgnu@gmail.com> wrote:
> Fatal error: Cannot redeclare class DateTime in

This problem can happen when the said class is already defined. What
could cause this 'DateTime' to be already defined? I think it could be
that DateTime is now part of php 5.2 and yes it is...
http://at.php.net/releases/5_2_0.php

So you need to remove DateTime from your stack and it should work.

cheers,

  -Suraj

70 million across globe. Equal stanza stands good for all Indian Language.

Communication...

mother Tongue. It is not Chavunism. We are indeed Bharathians. No doubt.

Oh.. Think of the time it will take for this entire 70 million to learn
English first and then Learn Linux.

I know English and I know Tamil. I know ten kids who do not English. I want
to teach them Linux. The best way is to teach them in their Language. Isn't
that simple!

From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Fri Nov 10 16:52:14 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul Sundaram)
Date: Fri Nov 10 16:52:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magaznin
In-Reply-To: <e3dcb5360611100314i5de1b60x435528b3910ebe2c@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061110071213.43447.qmail@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>	<e3dcb5360611092327k401b1fafl5b91455fed17b024@mail.gmail.com>	<20061110084728.GB28773@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<e3dcb5360611100314i5de1b60x435528b3910ebe2c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455460E6.4060207@fedoraproject.org>

?.??????? wrote:
>> This is the reason I am advocating for an English base.
>> Dammit, who the hell is gonna pay for vernacular tech journals?
> 
> I think we are going to release it under GPL. No copyright. :-) Its free as
> in freedom.
> 

GPL is a copyright license generally applied to software and not 
documentation. If you would like to disown all copyrights you can put it 
under public domain though I wouldnt recommend that. The better option 
would be the OPL license without the optional restrictive clauses or the 
creative commons attribute share alike license. The OPL license has a 
advantage of a proper no warranty provision which is useful if you 
target a litigation happy place like US.

http://opencontent.org/openpub/
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.5/deed.en

Rahul

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Fri Nov 10 18:38:53 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Fri Nov 10 18:39:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazines
Message-ID: <1468.61.247.255.57.1163164133.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

>> There is a lot of glut in software too.
>>
>> There is only one open source print magazine called linuxjournal.
>>
>> No other. Not even one for BSDs. You call it glut?

>> There are plenty for perl, this and that. But none of the same class and
>> calibre of linuxjournal.
>>
>> My idea is to compete with the only open source tech journal in India.
>>
>> Where is the glut? Am I missing something?

Got it. If your focus is to develop the best opensource mag, then please
do ignore my last comments on creating a magazine in Tamil summarized by
the following workflows that I suggested:

> Foreign language authors -> Translators -> Print / Web
> Foreign language documents -> Translators -> Print / Web
> Foreign language apps -> Translators -> Programmers -> Web / CD

I agree with you that the quality of magazines out there is too poor. If
you are going to be creating a new magazine, you have the choice of:

a) Targetting the low-end in which case you could fill your magazine with
advertisements, comparison of hardware, a few token sections with software
reviews, some language tutorial thrown in etc.

b) Target the high end and really go for the meaty subjects. Discuss
issues such as standardization, discuss the kernel.. That is more in-depth
article, and less hype/hoopla/product-reviews kinda like Byte.

Ofcourse, if you want to create the *best* open source mag out there, you
must go with (b) and not (a). Actually, I would love a magazine like that
and I would happily buy it and recommend it to others.

If would highly recommend that for a start:

a) Avoid going the print route as the logistically it is far more of a
challenge than doing a web-only version or even a PDF version.

b) Keep the graphics small, and the content big. :) So you can spend less
time trying to figure out how to do the graphics and more time creating
the great articles :)!

Anyway, you have my support and the first subscription.

Thanks,
PK

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 19:23:34 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Fri Nov 10 19:23:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magaznine
In-Reply-To: <20061110090400.GA27826@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20061110071213.43447.qmail@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>
	<20061110090400.GA27826@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <4554845E.4000507@gmail.com>

km wrote:
> Pls note that almost all the people who are into linux are aware of english, not tamil. lets keep the motive of educating masses abt linux as top proiroty and eliminate lingustic chauvanism. -- let it be an "open magazine" with respect to natural languages.
On the contrary, most coding standards ask developers not to assume that 
the default language used would be English. 

And, one speciality of the Tamil language is that it could stand alone, 
without support from any other  language.   The Tamil grammarians were 
very well versed in both Sanskrit and Tamil, but deliberately chose to 
keep Tamil pure in line with its ancient traditions.  Kambar translated 
Ramayan from Sanskrit to Tamil, but did not use Sanskrit words anywhere 
in his translation. "Tamil only" works would be most welcome and true to 
the spirit and culture of the language.

Tamil has two grammars - the high and the low.  The low is called 
"kodunthamiz" - or the common dialect and is generally liberal in 
allowing imports from other languages. Hurricane, TV, cinema, KD are all 
part of the Tamil dialect.  It would do no harm if words like 
"virtualisation" are simply imported without any translation too for 
purposes of the common dialect.  Of course, that would never be 
acceptable in the high and poetic sen Tamil.

Rahul Sundaram wrote:
> ?.??????? wrote:
>>> This is the reason I am advocating for an English base.
>>> Dammit, who the hell is gonna pay for vernacular tech journals?
>>
>> I think we are going to release it under GPL. No copyright. :-) Its 
>> free as
>> in freedom.
>>
>
> GPL is a copyright license generally applied to software and not 
> documentation.

Computer programs are treated just like literary works, and there is no 
harm in releasing documentation or other literary works under the GPL.

The GPL is much less complicated than most other options.  Further, 
ideally, the code should be self documenting, in which case the GPL 
would automatically cover the documentation too.  Take for instance the 
documentation generated with help from doxygen - there is absolutely no 
need to invent or use a different license for the documentation.

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
>> How will you express "virtualization" in Tamil or Bengali? Or Sanskrit?
kdict and stardict have very nice dictionaries - about a dozen including 
gcide, wordnet, oed, collins, etc that give English to English meanings, 
and also English to other languages such as Sanskrit and Hindi (the 
Monier Williams English to Sanskrit, and the freedict eng-hin dict). I 
do not find a suitable English to Tamil or vice versa dict. I hope Hari, 
Sri Ramadoss, and others could find a way to release some usable 
dictionary with help of the translations already available.

Tamil, Sanskrit and most Indian languages have strong root words, and 
so, it should be fairly easy to find suitable translations. 
Virtualisation merely has something to do around jumping from one system 
to another, and and I could suggest thavu-sakthi-palam (all the three 
words have the same meaning too!).

For anyone interested in finding the appropriate Hindi translation for 
"vitualisation", here is a snip from kdict:
<quote>
virtual:
1. ??????????~???~????
"Our Vice-Principal is the virtual head of our school."
"Their demonstration was a virtual failure."
</quote>

From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Fri Nov 10 19:38:43 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul Sundaram)
Date: Fri Nov 10 19:39:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazine
In-Reply-To: <4554848D.5050503@gmail.com>
References: <20061110071213.43447.qmail@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>	<e3dcb5360611092327k401b1fafl5b91455fed17b024@mail.gmail.com>	<20061110084728.GB28773@lakshmi.susmita.org>	<e3dcb5360611100314i5de1b60x435528b3910ebe2c@mail.gmail.com>	<455460E6.4060207@fedoraproject.org>
	<4554848D.5050503@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455487EB.9080202@fedoraproject.org>

Ramanraj K wrote:

>>
>> GPL is a copyright license generally applied to software and not 
>> documentation.
> 
> Computer programs are treated just like literary works, and there is no 
> harm in releasing documentation or other literary works under the GPL.

That depends on the context. GPL clause 2.a requires that each revision 
be identified uniquely. When applied to code, this requirement is easily 
satisfied by using a source code management tool but for other creative 
works, the use of a SCM is not as much a common practice.
If documentation source format is different from the published format 
which is the case for docbook generated documentation for example, GPL 
clause 3 might add unnecessary complications.

For fonts, the use of GPL might have unintended consequences.
http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/gpl-faq.html#FontException

> The GPL is much less complicated than most other options.  

For reciprocal licenses that is generally correct but creative commons 
set of licenses have "human readable" versions which makes this process 
much more understandable. OPL is not complex either.


Further,
> ideally, the code should be self documenting, in which case the GPL 
> would automatically cover the documentation too.  Take for instance the 
> documentation generated with help from doxygen - there is absolutely no 
> need to invent or use a different license for the documentation.

Thats true for documentation associated with code. Not a magazine.

Rahul

On Fri, Nov 10, 2006 at 07:23:34PM +0530, Ramanraj K wrote:
> And, one speciality of the Tamil language is that it could stand alone,

Sanskrit too ... !

>   The Tamil grammarians were 
> very well versed in both Sanskrit and Tamil, but deliberately chose to 
> keep Tamil pure in line with its ancient traditions.  Kambar translated 
> Ramayan from Sanskrit to Tamil, but did not use Sanskrit words anywhere 
> in his translation. "Tamil only" works would be most welcome and true to 
> the spirit and culture of the language.

Well ! gone are the days in which literature flourished in ancient India, far different from todays. that time we had universities to educate people in vedic studies who used to come from other countries, but now we are in the other corner. anycase, i dont think its good to have "only tamil" magazine. be in touch with the world thru a common language - English. Its better to first implement it in english - watch out how it goes - then think of translating into vernacular languages.

> Tamil has two grammars - the high and the low.  The low is called 
> "kodunthamiz" - or the common dialect and is generally liberal in 
> allowing imports from other languages. 

Pls note that, Samskritam was a scholarly language in ancient times. common people used to converse in Prakrit. also worth mention is that even the westeners recognize the unparalleled clarity of grammatical syntax and power of expression in samskritam. No other grammarian is compared as tall as panini at the design of samskritam grammar. Samskritam was also dubbed the best suitable language for use in programming amongst all natural languages known todate (read an article sometime back).

That doesnt mean that one should start magazine in samskritam. so be practical!
one can - but after establishing it in english.

regards,
KM

From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Fri Nov 10 22:58:31 2006
From: shriramadhas at gmail.com (=?UTF-8?B?4K6uLuCusOCuvuCuruCupOCuvuCuuOCvjQ==?=)
Date: Fri Nov 10 22:58:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magaznine

References: <20061110090400.GA27826@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<4554845E.4000507@gmail.com> <20061110172210.GA30837@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <e3dcb5360611100928y4ee8425ene27949cc5107c8cd@mail.gmail.com>

> watch out how it goes - then think of translating into vernacular
languages.

It is not going to be a translation to native language. Making of a magazine
in native language.

One of our friend Kapilan, suggested a classic difference between
Translation and Original making.

The word "Water Falls".. How do you translate? Neer Veezchi? This is
translation. What is the originality ? It is "Aruvi"

I think we have enough topic to be covered independently in a native
language magazine alone. These are specific to Tamil alone. Let me site very
basic few...

1) Keyboard Layouts
2) Encoding
3) Translator Tools - KBabel etc.,
4) Fonts
5) Input methods - SCIM etc.,

These are just to begin.. We have all these to cover.. How come these things
be covered in a English Magazine...

Well interested few can indeed start English Magazine.. And the technology
used for making magazine can be made common....

But Tamil Magazine should not be a translated version of that... It has to
deal with Tamil specific technical/ non-technical issues... Lot of issues
are there.. I have already cited few...

??????? - ??????, ??????????, ?????????? ???? ??????????? ????????????
????????.

???? - Is to let free. Free software is about a user Freedom on a software.

Any software should give a user,

 * The freedom to run the program, for any purpose (freedom 0).
 * The freedom to study how the program works, and adapt it to your needs
(freedom 1).
   Access to the source code is precondition for this.
 * The freedom to redistribute copies so you can help your neighbor (freedom
2).
 * The freedom to improve the program, and release your improvements to the
public,
   so that the whole community benefits (freedom 3). Access to the source
code is a
   precondition for this.

It would be apt to add ???? to ????. ???? ???? can be the suffix... One more
prefix.. Two or three letters...

FSF's definition of free software has repetition of the word program in it.
The freedom is to run, study, distribute and improve a program...

program in Tamil Virtual University Glossary is referred to as ?????????...
In short ????? is also used to refer program..

?????????? ???? (????????) ???? - ????? ???? ????

So shall we have the name of our magazine to be - ????? ???? ???? ?

Logo can be a creative cartoon of a parrot - ??????????? - "?????"  :-)

>> documentation.
>
> Computer programs are treated just like literary works, and there  
> is no harm in releasing documentation or other literary works under  
> the GPL.

no - if you want GNU --> gnu free document license is there

From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Sat Nov 11 07:25:33 2006

Message-ID: <e3dcb5360611101755v1072b7c4sc4f64e4c32d26d1f@mail.gmail.com>

parrot and pigeon are two birds used by people to send "Thoothu".

Cock and Peacock are associated with Tamilians.  Sevar Kodi is the Flag of
Lord Muruga, the God of Tamils..

Peacock, is also associated with him since ancient times.

Parrot is associated with Thoothu.

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Sat Nov 11 19:29:50 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sat Nov 11 19:30:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Fwd: [GNU/FSF Press] Press release: FSF announces release
	of gNewSense 1.0
In-Reply-To: <1162467424.4946.218.camel@localhost>
References: <1162467424.4946.218.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <f480bf1e0611110559k2caa1903oecb1138ee2fc4f72@mail.gmail.com>

I just installed the gNewSense distro. Anyone tried using it?  It has
a Builder program to create custom live cd distros - that is not found
in others.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Peter Brown <peterb@fsf.org>
Date: Nov 2, 2006 5:07 PM
Subject: [GNU/FSF Press] Press release: FSF announces release of gNewSense 1.0
To: info-press@gnu.org


BOSTON, November 2, 2006 - Free Software Foundation announces release of
gNewSense version 1.0.

(Screenshots available at http://www.fsf.org/news/gnewsense)

gNewSense (http://www.gnewsense.org) is a free software GNU/Linux
distribution created by two Irish free software advocates, Brian Brazil
and Paul O'Malley, and is based on the Ubuntu and Debian distributions.
The goal of gNewSense is to provide users with a software package that
offers the stability of Ubuntu with the addition of freedom.

In announcing the release of version 1.0, the gNewSense developers
stated, "From a philosophical perspective we wanted to create a
GNU/Linux distribution where the user has access to all the sources for
all software on the system. This includes everything from the heart of
the kernel through to the everyday desktop applications."

With the avowed goal of providing a completely free distribution - one
without non-free kernel binary "blobs" or any other non-free software,
the Free Software Foundation has announced sponsorship of the project.
Ted Teah, FSF's free software directory maintainer explained, "With all
the kernel firmware and restricted repositories removed, and the
reliance on Ubuntu's proprietary distribution management tool Launchpad
gone, this distribution is the most advanced GNU/Linux distribution that
has a commitment to be 100% free."

gNewSense will provide users with full security updates and is available
for immediate download in LiveCD ISO format along with a version of the
Ubiquity graphical installer. Furthermore, the gNewSense team has
created a set of software called Builder which allows users to create
their own gNewSense-based distributions.  gNewSense provides detailed
instructions on how to use the software and the recipe to roll out a
customized distro.

The Free Software Foundation is providing the gNewSense team with a high
end build machine (running with a free BIOS), with bandwidth and with
assistance in developing artwork. The FSF plans to aid widespread
adoption of the distribution and, with the release of gNewSense 1.0, is
making a call for volunteers who have the skills to act as the
following:

*  Developers;
*  Website Maintainers;
*  Graphic Artists;
*  Freedom verifiers to monitor package additions and mailing lists;
*  Documentation Writers.

To volunteer, please, sign on at irc.freenode.net and /join #gnewsense.
You can also join the mailing list via the project website
http://www.gnewsense.org/

----30----

About the Free Software Foundation

The Free Software Foundation, founded in 1985, is dedicated to promoting
computer users' right to use, study, copy, modify, and redistribute
computer programs. The FSF promotes the development and use of free (as
in freedom) software - particularly the GNU operating system and its
GNU/Linux variants - and free documentation for free software. The FSF
also helps to spread awareness of the ethical and political issues of
freedom in the use of software. Their Web site, located at www.fsf.org,
is an important source of information about GNU/Linux. Donations to
support their work can be made at http://fsf.org/join They are
headquartered in Boston, MA, USA.

Press contact:
To schedule an interview with the developers of gNewSense, please
contact Ted Teah at the Free Software Foundation (+1 617-542-5942) or
Peter Brown (+1 617-542-5942) or email pr@fsf.org

FSF And GNU Press mailing list <info-press@gnu.org>
http://lists.gnu.org/mailman/listinfo/info-press
From mailzico at gmail.com  Sat Nov 11 19:51:02 2006
From: mailzico at gmail.com (Zico)
Date: Sat Nov 11 19:51:20 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] gprs modem + debian sarge
Message-ID: <69621d830611110621m46c4a706o2a7236f9c6641c9b@mail.gmail.com>

I want to use my Siemence CX75 GPRS modem in Debian Sarge. But i cannot do
it with
gnome-ppp or kppp. When i use "dmesg" then it shows that, it get the usb
drive ( my cell
phone, CX75). But i cannot query my modem with "gnome-ppp" or "kppp".

How can i use my modem?

Thanks,

Zico
From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sat Nov 11 20:06:50 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sat Nov 11 20:07:56 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] gprs modem + debian sarge
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611110621m46c4a706o2a7236f9c6641c9b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611110621m46c4a706o2a7236f9c6641c9b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4555e002.of4kbDhuE56EMgwA%linux@frodo.hserus.net>

Zico <mailzico@gmail.com> wrote:

> I want to use my Siemence CX75 GPRS modem in Debian Sarge. But i cannot do

Just specify the modem port (/dev/ttyacm0 or whatever) in the ppp options

Quite easy in wvdial - for example this is for a tata indicom phone

[Dialer Defaults]
Init1 = ATZ
Init2 = AT+CRM=1
Stupid Mode = 1
ISDN = 0
Modem Type = USB Modem
New PPPD = yes
FlowControl = Hardware (CRTSCTS)
Phone = #777
Modem = /dev/ttyACM0
Username = internet
Password = internet
Baud = 460800

And if you use pppconfig (so that kppp etc will use these)

/etc/chatscripts/tata

# This chatfile was generated by pppconfig 2.3.10.
# Please do not delete any of the comments.  Pppconfig needs them.
#
# ispauth PAP
# abortstring
ABORT BUSY ABORT 'NO CARRIER' ABORT VOICE ABORT 'NO DIALTONE' ABORT 'NO DIAL TON
E' ABORT 'NO ANSWER' ABORT DELAYED
# modeminit
'' "ATZ AT+CRM=1"
# ispnumber
OK-AT-OK "ATDT#777"
# ispconnect
CONNECT \d\c
# prelogin

# ispname
# isppassword
# postlogin

# end of pppconfig stuff

and /etc/ppp/peers/tata

# This optionfile was generated by pppconfig 2.3.10.
#
#
hide-password
noauth
connect "/usr/sbin/chat -v -f /etc/chatscripts/tata"
debug
/dev/ttyACM0
115200
defaultroute
noipdefault
user "internet"
remotename tata
ipparam tata

On Sat, Nov 11, 2006 at 07:15:39AM +0530, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
>

> >>alone,
> >>without support from any other  language.

> 
> and kannada, malayalam, telugu, marati, bengali, gujarati, polish,

These languages are not standalone. they are derived from various other languages. for example telugu is heavily derived from samskritam though the script is different. so are other indian languages except tamil. one can know it from the grammatical syntax  and wordings. i was refering to uniqueness  of a language. when told abt uniqueness, i would like to mention one thing that samskritham has withstood importing of words from other languages since ages. one doesnt find change in grammar or the way one speaks in samskritham since ages. thats not true with other languages. well there are only a few standalone languages - like - samskritham, tamil, latin , hebrew etc from which present day languages arose.

regards,
KM

?.??????? wrote:
>>> this is ubuntu specific - i would prefer someplace more general, and
>>> where the drafts can be put up for correction before exposing my
>>> ignorance to the public ;-)
>
> Yes. Shall we use fsf-tn mailing list or create some other mailing 
> list for
> encouraging users writing articles in Tamil ? Can some one send fsf-tn
> mailing list's info page?
>
> What was the prime intention in creating the fsf-tn mailing list? Is it
> really active?
I missed reading your earlier post.

The fsf-tn mailing list is at 
http://gnowledge.org/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo/fsf-tn

Please feel free to subscribe to fsf-tn to discuss localisation plans. 
Nagarjun and a number of others working on various localisation projects 
are part of that list.

It was conceived as a state level list to help co-ordinate free software 
activities here. One of the goals has been to initially have at least 
one fsug in each district. Of course, everything is driven by voluntary 
action and there is no central command there. Out of the chaos we call 
free software, a few sparks do light up things here and there making the 
place bright. If you have plans for fsf-tn, please share it - it could 
help to invite more volunteers.
>
> *To come back to topic on FSM and TUX , On my search for the tools 
> used, i
> too found its LaTex... 
To create pdf documents, you could use OpenOffice or GNU Texmacs - both 
of which are wysiwyg editors eminently suitable for the purpose at hand. 
OpenOffice by default comes with a pdf button, that could save the 
default opd files in pdf format. With GNU Texmacs, you could create 
content and output files in pdf using File->Export->Pdf

Rahul Sundaram wrote:
>
> That depends on the context. GPL clause 2.a requires that each 
> revision be identified uniquely. When applied to code, this 
> requirement is easily satisfied by using a source code management tool 
> but for other creative works, the use of a SCM is not as much a common 
> practice.
> If documentation source format is different from the published format 
> which is the case for docbook generated documentation for example, GPL 
> clause 3 might add unnecessary complications.
What complication?  It is an online magazine that would probably include 
a number of code snippets, and the GPL would be the best for such a work.
>
> For fonts, the use of GPL might have unintended consequences.
> http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/gpl-faq.html#FontException
We are not talking about fonts here.
>
> Thats true for documentation associated with code. Not a magazine.
Rubbish.  By legal definition computer programs are literary works, and 
a copyright license that could be used for computer programs could 
easily be used to release literary works - especially an online work 
that is nothing but a computer program which looks like a magazine to 
your eyes.





From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Sun Nov 12 06:51:03 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sun Nov 12 06:51:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Abstraction
Message-ID: <455676FF.7060905@gmail.com>

The connection between language syntax and tool use is not so obvious.  
Recently, Dr. VS Ramachandran elaborated on the connections between the 
syntax of sentences like: 'She hit the boy who kissed the girl that she 
disliked' and 'He knows that I know that he knows that I had an affair 
with his wife' (hierarchic embedding in language), and tool use - 
especially the sub assembly technique that involves making tools in a 
series of steps, like, making an axe with a head, handle and then using 
the whole as a tool. All these appear to originate from the TPO junction 
in the brain.  He reveals several facts about the mind and may be of use 
to those working on AI.  The Reith Lectures by Dr. VS are available 
online at http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/reith2003/ 
<http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/reith2003/>

The following snippet is from the ilugc archives:

<quote>
SK> Now is a GUI necessary? (-:

Yes, very much.  In case you did not realize, the CLI is also a GUI,
its just that its all in pure text.  The point is if you abstract out
everything so that any type of GUI is possible the whole thing becomes
more powerful.  So on the console you use a curses based GUI or if
that is not available just use plain text.  Otherwise you get a nice
GUI where you can select stuff, look at help, search for help, look
for examples etc. [- Prabhu Ramachandran -]
</quote>

Having this idea in mind should help to make free software a more 
powerful option.  I have plans to write gstar - an interface that would 
decide whether to invoke star or gtar in a given situation (both 
released under the GPL).

-Ramanraj K
From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Sun Nov 12 06:51:52 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sun Nov 12 06:52:06 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazine [Sanskrit]
Message-ID: <f480bf1e0611111721j36fc7d44o78dff44928757b46@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/11/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:

> ... there are only a few standalone languages - like - samskritham, tamil,
> latin , hebrew etc from which present day languages arose ...

Thank you for writing that.  I would like to share the following with you.

Chennai has been a cosmopolitan town since time immemorial, and
nurtured the growth of both Sanskrit and Tamil.  The ancient names
have survived and have a story to tell: Velachery is a corruption of
Velvi cheri - a colony inhabited by Sanskrit scholars who built their
philosophies sitting around fire from time immemorial.  The place
where I live is Thiruvanmiyur, and it is a matter of pride that it was
the home of Sage Valmiki once upon a time - his shrine luckily escaped
the ECR bulldozers recently.  Koyambedu derived from "Ko ambu medu" -
the spot where Luva and Kusa are believed to have fenced a meadow with
arrows - the Thenupuriswarar temple folks keep the legend alive to
this day.

AFAIK, Sanskrit still lives vibrantly in TN - it is not very visible
though.  A number of judges and lawyers of the High Court here have
been Sanskrit scholars - a tradition that continues even now. The
Madras Sanskrit College, the Ramakrishna Mutt, and several
institutions in Kanchi do their best to keep Sanskrit in active use.
Some of the good schools here mandate learning of Sanskrit.

Tamil is much lighter than Sanskrit - the main reason it has survived
well.  The fault is not with Sanskrit but just that its utility is not
appreciated enough.  It has a C like charm in its ability to
communicate thought without ambiguity (that would be fairly difficult
in Tamil) or with ambiguities, easy in Tamil also but which may never
be possible with C.   I would boldly say a free software issue in
Sanskrit would be received well here - atleast a hundred people would
promote it enthusiastically. Anyone interested in experimenting here
may please start with just a single page monthly phamplet along with
English translations.
From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Sun Nov 12 08:47:24 2006
From: shriramadhas at gmail.com (amachu)

Starting from Thivakara Nigandu to Veeramamuni's Chaturagarathi...To the
Manavai Mustapa's latest glossary of Technical Tamil Words..

Having come from the Land of Cholas I can site such examples for every
one Kilometer i have wandered :-)

available... Time has to answer... Ubuntu Indian team has a sanskrit
Team. I mailed about my friends interest but no response. Some one from

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Sun Nov 12 09:13:11 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)

On 11-Nov-06, at 11:15 PM, km wrote:

> These languages are not standalone. they are derived from various  
> other languages. for example telugu is heavily derived from samskritam

i regret to say that misconceptions like this lead to language  
chauvinism. The idea that there are 'pure' languages which are 'first  
class languages' and 'derived' languages, which are 'third class  
languages' has no scientific basis. It is a total misconception, for  
example, to say that telugu, kannada, malayalam are 'derived' from  
tamil. It is not so. All these four languages have evolved from a  
common root - evolved in different ways, and none is superior to the  
other. This is OT anyway. Please note that similar theories (with no  
factual basis) lead to the rise of hitler, milosovic and other  
proponents of ethnic cleansing.

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Sun Nov 12 09:20:20 2006
From: shriramadhas at gmail.com (=?UTF-8?B?4K6uLuCusOCuvuCuruCupOCuvuCuuOCvjQ==?=)
Date: Sun Nov 12 09:20:30 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magaznine
In-Reply-To: <259F7326-7B21-41B5-924F-2A31965C8000@thenilgiris.com>

On 11/12/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
>
>
> On 11-Nov-06, at 11:15 PM, km wrote:
>
> > These languages are not standalone. they are derived from various
> > other languages. for example telugu is heavily derived from samskritam
>
> i regret to say that misconceptions like this lead to language
> chauvinism. The idea that there are 'pure' languages which are 'first
> class languages' and 'derived' languages, which are 'third class
> languages' has no scientific basis. It is a total misconception, for
> example, to say that telugu, kannada, malayalam are 'derived' from
> tamil. It is not so. All these four languages have evolved from a
> common root - evolved in different ways, and none is superior to the
> other. This is OT anyway. Please note that similar theories (with no
> factual basis) lead to the rise of hitler, milosovic and other
> proponents of ethnic cleansing.
>

> How will you express "virtualization" in Tamil or Bengali?

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtualization

In computing <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computing>, *virtualization* is
"a technique for hiding the physical characteristics of computing resources
from the way in which other systems, applications, or end users interact
with those resources. This includes making a single physical resource (such
as a server, an operating system, an application, or storage device) appear
to function as multiple logical resources; or it can include making multiple
physical resources (such as storage devices or servers) appear as a single
logical resource."

So simple.. have u read Thirupaavai..

A song begins ????? ????? ??????? ???????.. (Mayanai mannu Vadamadurai
Mainthanai)

Have u heard the song of film Baba... ????  ????  ??????? ????  ????...

Maya is common in most Indian Language...

Virualization is close to this.. In Tamil I can suggest another word
"Mayakkuthal".... "?????????" If one mind can suggest two words for a
concept.. Just think what will happen when a Team sits...

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Sun Nov 12 09:59:34 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Sun Nov 12 09:51:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Suzhi
Message-ID: <6F80021E-29D7-4F80-8579-6C8DE688AE41@thenilgiris.com>

hi,

I am making this into a separate thread. Ramdas and I had a meeting  
regarding Suzhi. The idea is to have a space where we could encourage  
and help people who want to read/write technical articles in tamil.  
Ramdas has started contributing some articles on the basics of linux  
- all the articles have a glossary giving the english equivalents of  
tamil technical words. Since this is a wiki, please dont wait for him  
to do all the writing. Even if you add a sentence here or a paragraph  
there or even a suggestion for an alternate word, it helps the corpus  
to grow.

I have started a translation of Eric Raymond's 'The Cathedral and The  
Bazaar'. I am doing this translation in the bazaar model. Translating  
what i feel is important first and doing the rest later. Even here, i  
am leaving words i dont know in english in the hope that the gurus in  
the lug will fill in the gap. Others who would like to translate the  
works of other Gurus like Richard Stallman and Linus Torwalds are  
most welcome to take the initiative. Please give the url to the  
english original so others can contribute.

If we could get a big enough body of work going we will have enough  
stuff to feed a magazine.

Licenses: each individual author may choose whatever license he/she  
wants for the work. However, in translating, it would be prudent to  
keep the same license as the original author.

Hacker dictionary: we are attempting to compile translations of  
technical terms in tamil. Please add english terms here - and  
suggestions for translations too. If we get enough entries, we can  
plan on organising it alphabeticaly with index etc.
-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

From lug at chandrashekar.info  Sun Nov 12 12:08:34 2006
From: lug at chandrashekar.info (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Chandrashekar=20Babu?=)
Date: Sun Nov 12 12:16:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Putting stress on the Linux Kernel
Message-ID: <20061112063834.29369.qmail@server301.com>

Hi,

>  Hello Folks,
>  This might sound weird, how do i slow my linux box to a 
> crawl..So that I  get 100% CPU usage.

Perhaps, the command 'cp /dev/urandom /dev/null' in 
the background could help. Yet, its not guaranteed
to bring your system to a crawl. My system still remained
very responsive while showing 99.7% CPU usage 
consistently (and it was a VIA C3 733 MHz box).

Another recipe in perl (for slurping all your available RAM) 
would be this one-liner:
   perl -e 'print (a .. z x 7) while(1)' > /dev/null

Increase or decrease the value (7) depending on your
available memory (inclusive of swap). And yes, setting too
high a value could eventually freeze your system!

Good luck :-)

--
Chandrashekar Babu.,
FOSS Technologist,
http://www.chandrashekar.info/

Subject: [Ilugc] FSM & TUX Magazine
In-Reply-To: <455676D6.6010500@gmail.com>

Ramanraj K wrote:
> Rahul Sundaram wrote:
>>
>> That depends on the context. GPL clause 2.a requires that each 
>> revision be identified uniquely. When applied to code, this 
>> requirement is easily satisfied by using a source code management tool 
>> but for other creative works, the use of a SCM is not as much a common 
>> practice.
>> If documentation source format is different from the published format 
>> which is the case for docbook generated documentation for example, GPL 
>> clause 3 might add unnecessary complications.
> What complication?  It is an online magazine that would probably include 
> a number of code snippets, and the GPL would be the best for such a work.

You seem to have ignored and not addressed what I pointed out just 
above. GPL adds restrictions which require every different iteration to 
be maintained separately. Unless you are going to put the whole magazine 
into a SCM I dont see how you can easily resolve that.

>> For fonts, the use of GPL might have unintended consequences.
>> http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/gpl-faq.html#FontException
> We are not talking about fonts here.

Magazine involve fonts too.

>> Thats true for documentation associated with code. Not a magazine.
> Rubbish.  By legal definition computer programs are literary works, and 
> a copyright license that could be used for computer programs could 
> easily be used to release literary works - especially an online work 
> that is nothing but a computer program which looks like a magazine to 
> your eyes.

I never heard of a online magazine being described as just a computer 
program before. Wouldnt a magazine have editorial columns, opinions, 
reviews etc?

Rahul
