References: <1163311365.4596.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<154eca020611112207m7a65222el5b198f04fbdc6783@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <bc5cb460611120037u46da4c7p8d1c70be0d1ae244@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/12/06, Anand Saha <anandsaha@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 11/12/06, Sudharshan S <sudharsh@gmail.com> wrote:
> > This might sound weird, how do i slow my linux box to a crawl..So that I
> > get 100% CPU usage. Open Office is good, but not good enough..
> > The motive, of course is to convince my dad to get more RAM to my rig..

If you want to manipulate your dad's mind to get you more RAM, maybe
you are looking in the wrong direction of programming... maybe you
should try http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuro-linguistic_programming
;)

More seriously, the most 'natural' way is to lessen memory due to
which the system becomes slow due to heavy swapping. Maybe run tomcat
or somesuch java app that starts with system boot? ;)

However, if you want to just use up the CPU, this spinlocking C
program should do:

void main() { while (1); }

This will simply use up one CPU and any program that needs CPU cycles
will be affected (if you have a multi-processor box or HT then you
will have to run as many instances of this program as the number of
CPUs that your box has). Programs which are, say, interrupt driven
(like a wget instance over a slow connection) won't be affected very
heavily since they are waiting only on IO and not on CPU.

cheers,

  -Suraj
From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Sun Nov 12 19:02:31 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (R.Ramkumar)
Date: Sun Nov 12 19:02:44 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Putting stress on the Linux Kernel
In-Reply-To: <1163311365.4596.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1163311365.4596.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170611120532q44a3b5cdw5ac31be46219234b@mail.gmail.com>

My contribution to this noble cause ;) If you have frequency scaling,
modprobe the cpufreq and cpufreq_powersave modules and write powersave
to the file /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpuN/cpufreq/scaling_governor

N is the cpu number starting from 0... If you have more than one cpu,
like a multicore or a ht system, you will need to do this for each
cpu...

This reduces the cpu to the lowest speed possible...

But this might be a clincher... no need infinite loops... pass mem=64M
to the boot command line and watch the magic :D

it moves on...

-- 
One of the main causes of the fall of the Roman Empire
was that, lacking zero, they had no way to indicate
successful termination of their C programs.
                             -- Robert Firth

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Nov 12 22:57:03 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Nov 12 22:57:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Cannot open display
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611120808u330387c2l5a9a2e0a0954ad65@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061112172703.87442.qmail@web50211.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Zico <mailzico@gmail.com> wrote:
> What i want to mean
> that, suppose i am using
> "su" for root

Before doing su, enable X client connections:

  xhost +

No "su -" ('-' adds root environment variables
settings too) and check your DISPLAY variable.

If not set, try:

  export DISPLAY=:0.0

and try to open xterm or any X application from the
terminal.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From binand at gmail.com  Sun Nov 12 23:47:43 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Nov 12 23:47:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Putting stress on the Linux Kernel
In-Reply-To: <bc5cb460611120037u46da4c7p8d1c70be0d1ae244@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1163311365.4596.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<154eca020611112207m7a65222el5b198f04fbdc6783@mail.gmail.com>
	<bc5cb460611120037u46da4c7p8d1c70be0d1ae244@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611121017y4f8853f8q3548a083f9ca516e@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/11/06, Suraj Kumar <suraj@sunson.in> wrote:
> However, if you want to just use up the CPU, this spinlocking C
> program should do:
>
> void main() { while (1); }

This might not work - any self respecting compiler would notice that
the loop is not doing anything and optimize it out. Try a little
modification:

volatile int i = 1;
int main (void) { int j; while (1) j = i; }

This should do the trick.

Suraj: note that in C, main should return an int.

Binand

Subject: [Ilugc] Putting stress on the Linux Kernel

Hi,

On 11/12/06, Sudharshan S <sudharsh@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hello Folks,
> This might sound weird, how do i slow my linux box to a crawl..So that I
> get 100% CPU usage. Open Office is good, but not good enough..The
> motive, of course is to convince my dad to get more RAM to my rig..

just fork bomb it , but that would make the box unusable.

Here's a nifty one-liner..
: () { : | : & } ; :

: is the function name, it could very well be f, like this
f () { f | f & } ; f

or

f()
{
	f | f&
}

f

-Toufeeq
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

On 11/13/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
>
> On 13-Nov-06, at 10:28 AM, Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
>
> > Also, gNewSense is very usable, Mark Pilgrim tried it out and it all
> > devices on his PC were supported. His account is available here :
> >
> > http://diveintomark.org/archives/2006/11/06/gnewsense
>
> and he conludes that he is not going to use it - and contends that it
> is not meant to be used, but is only a 'proof of concept'

FUD

quoting mark pilgrim :

"Will I switch from Ubuntu to gNewSense? No. But I could, and that's
enough of a victory for today."

Will I switch from Debian to Ubuntu ? No! but it's always good to know
that there's a distro out there which could give me something which
"Just Works!". It's the same case with gNewSense, if in future someone
(like Mark) needs to move from Ubuntu to a completely free distro
which is "not tainted", it's possible.

He also mentions very clearly why gNewSense is required :
"this is one distribution that the world absolutely does need."

and..

"The gNewSense maintainers apparently feel that saying you're "a
little bit non-free" is akin to saying you're "a little bit pregnant."
Close doesn't count, and even if people don't notice the difference
today, they'll definitely notice it nine months from now."

The word he uses is "reference implementation" and not "proof-of-concept".

-Toufeeq
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Mon Nov 13 11:22:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Best intro to crypto
Message-ID: <20061113055217.GA29537@lakshmi.susmita.org>


Just read and enjoy! :)

It is like a nice thriller novel. :)

Written by none other than the author of PGP Phil Zimmerman.

I hear that he was subsequently jailed or something but I am more likely to be wrong. :)

I know this much that he was penalised for popularising strong unbreakable crypto.

http://girish1729.googlepages.com/crypto-overview.pdf

(yes, copied from OpenBSD man page :)

Enjoy! :)

regards,
Girish

Zico wrote:

> 
> the problem is,sometimes debian can get it and sometimes it cannot. 
> When i had ps2 mouse,such type of problem never occured.

Usually., when the X does not identify the mouse., I just replug the
mouse and restart gdm. I've had this issue with almost every mouse i used.

One reason why sticking to PS/2 is better for mice/keyboard.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Nov 13 13:58:10 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon Nov 13 13:59:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] TKEY configuration
In-Reply-To: <OF47FED574.E1111875-ON65257225.002A84DD-65257225.002AF43C@flextronicssoftware.com>
References: <OF47FED574.E1111875-ON65257225.002A84DD-65257225.002AF43C@flextronicssoftware.com>
Message-ID: <45582C9A.8080305@frodo.hserus.net>

Check your bind install / named.conf - you'd typically define the key in
rndc.conf

Just searching for "dnssec-keygen named.conf" gave me yet another useful
link ..

http://caunter.ca/nsupdate.txt

Remember - if you're using a prepackaged (rpm, deb etc) version of bind,
the actual filenames, paths etc of this stuff can vary.

Karthikkumar.Armugam@aricent.com wrote:
> Has anyone done TKEY configuration on Server side?
> I would like to know in which directory i should place the DH keys 
> generated by dnssec-keygen. and if possible, changes to be done to 
> named.conf file.

> This might sound weird, how do i slow my linux box to a crawl..So that I
> get 100% CPU usage. Open Office is good, but not good enough..The

Why dont you make it naturally slow?
Pass  ``mem=16M''  or something to the kernel from your grub or lilo
configuration file.
Linux will behave as if you are in 20th century :)

Though I am happy that FOSS-II is approved, I feel we need to assess
the impact of FOSS-I so far. It is very sad that there is no
practicals for FOSS-I. I was astonished when a student told she has
not even for a  moment worked on linux. The irony is the entire batch
of student from this particular college passed out well in FOSS-I.

Some urgent action is required on the part of NRCFOSS and Anna
University to setup FOSS Lab and allow student to practice rather
than mug what is in the book.

In my humble opinion FOSS-I has not made any impact - atleast among
the students with whom I interacted.

Raman.P

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Mon Nov 13 18:22:13 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Mon Nov 13 18:22:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Open Source Software needed
In-Reply-To: <3da91a280611130319xe1f8b67m2481709f8db56606@mail.gmail.com>
References: <3da91a280611130319xe1f8b67m2481709f8db56606@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061113125213.GA26675@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Mon, Nov 13, 2006 at 04:49:07PM +0530, Murugiah Piramanayagam wrote:
> Hi All,
> 
> I need the following open source software.
> 
> 1. To maintain hardware inventory.

You may look at what supermarkets like Food World(Spencers Daily) do.

You can easily generate unique bar code labels and paste it on each of your hardware components.

Then you can get a cheap bar code scanner( a device that converts bar codes to key presses), it emulates a keyboard using USB interface. 

Once your bar code is read, the component is uniquely identified and you can retrieve the particulars from a database. All of these stuff is available open source and free of cost. But it needs some patient time to study and research.
> 2. To maintain a library management

You could use the bar code approaches to books too. But library management needs some special care since you will have to track where each book is kept, how long it is lent and all that.

Ask the  google Goddess for this and she shall help you out. Lot  of work has gone into it and several open source options are there.

Pick one that suits your taste best.
> 3. On line request (Every user should send the request reg. thier system
> problem / hardware changes / upgradation to the system administrator via
> email)

No direct email client support is needed. Typical approach is to have a web page with a simple html form. People can fill up the form and the backend sends email.

Best,
Girish
From prashmohan at gmail.com  Mon Nov 13 18:27:59 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)
Date: Mon Nov 13 18:28:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Time & date
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611130351j121f0088hf2ff799904aa0e20@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611130351j121f0088hf2ff799904aa0e20@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45586BD7.9040000@gmail.com>

Zico wrote:
> I am facing a strange problem.i have ubuntu & debian in my machine.if
> i configure the time in ubuntu then the time of debian change. And
> after that,if i change the time of debian,the time of ubuntu change.
> How can i solve that one?

Are the Time Zones set to the same region on both distros? One of them
might have the time zone set to UTC. You could try googling for how to
change the setting from UTC to your local time.

-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

From karuppuswamy at gmail.com  Mon Nov 13 19:04:53 2006
From: karuppuswamy at gmail.com (KaruppuSwamy.T)
Date: Mon Nov 13 19:04:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Time & date
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611130351j121f0088hf2ff799904aa0e20@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611130351j121f0088hf2ff799904aa0e20@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4558747D.80706@gmail.com>

Zico wrote:
> I am facing a strange problem.i have ubuntu & debian in my machine.if
> i configure the time in ubuntu then the time of debian change. And
> after that,if i change the time of debian,the time of ubuntu change.
> How can i solve that one?
>
> Zico
Set your time zone as either "localtime" or "GMT" in both ubuntu and 
debian. Ensure that both are same. Then set the time in one distro. It 
will be reflected in both distros.

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Mon Nov 13 23:01:22 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Mon Nov 13 23:01:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Tamil monospace fonts
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310611130931x34497bf4mc14cf67967d20101@mail.gmail.com>

Friends,
Tamil text with fixed fonts don't seem to show up right in Firefox.
This site (http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/drtv/translation_help) for
example has Tamil text in the "<pre>" tag and doesn't render nicely.
Same is the case for sans-serif fonts. Serif fonts are rendered
perfectly. To overcome this, I tried setting all three {serif, sans,
monospaced} to serif fonts in "Fonts for: Tamil" option but for some
strange reason this setting is not reflected but when I do the same in
"Fonts for: Western" the setting is reflected on the page and the text
in "<pre>" tag is displayed in serif font. Do anybody else face the
same issue. Is there something else I can do to enable fixed width
Tamil font support.

PS:
1. Firefox was built with PANGO support
2. ttf-tamil fonts are installed
3. Character encoding is set to UTF8

-- 
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Tue Nov 14 01:03:34 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Tue Nov 14 01:04:09 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Tamil monospace fonts
In-Reply-To: <1163440333.5064.30.camel@amachu-laptop>
References: <5d0d0e310611130931x34497bf4mc14cf67967d20101@mail.gmail.com>
	<1163440333.5064.30.camel@amachu-laptop>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310611131133r73e02081u16d5a0fde08a9221@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/13/06, amachu <shriramadhas@gmail.com> wrote:
> to be honest not many of us know about fonts its type, what is Serif
> fonts, Monospace fonts... etc.,

- Serif fonts are the one which come with small ticks at the ends of the glyph.
- *Sans*-serif fonts are the one with out these ticks.
- Monospace fonts are fixed with fonts (eg: i and H are of same width).

-- 
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/

accounts on the wiki.

I would like to know if there is single free ttf Tamil font based on the

I have been using a proprietary Tamil font for long, that I purchased 
for about Rs. 100/-. All that I do is copy the font to .fonts in my home 
directory, and it is immediately available (I think Xserver takes care 
of this) in OpenOffice or any other editor and I simply select the font 
to type in Tamil. If I want to change to English, I simply have to 
select an English font on the editor toolbar.

The SCIM and Keyboard Indicator programs seem to apply globally to all 
applications - I certainly don't want to be using Tamil to enter console 
commands even if I have a opened an editor to do some work in Tamil. The 
SCIM route appears to be an overkill for Tamil which is not so 
complicated like the Chinese, Japanese or Korean scripts based on 
thousands of ideograms.

Anyway, I installed the Remington layout you pointed to here, and it is 
visible in the System>Preferences>SCIM_Input_Method_Setup under the 
global setup page. I have scim running but I can't get to using Lohit 
Tamil or the others in OO. The tamil font does print on the console, but 
it is not perfect - the pulli are never in their place. The Remington 
Layout is not available as an option in the "Keyboard Indicator" program 
on the panel. What is that I am missing?

Thanks,
Ramanraj K

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Tue Nov 14 11:23:39 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Tue Nov 14 11:23:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Putting stress on the Linux Kernel
Message-ID: <1113.61.247.255.58.1163483619.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

>> On 11/12/06, Sudharshan S <sudharsh@gmail.com>
>> freezes my box.
>>
>> Will be fun when he logins to work tomorrow :D

The OSS community is based on the notion of trust and altruism where
people spend years developing software to practically give away so that
others may also benefit. This LUG is also based on the same concept - many
people answer queries and help out people on this list even though they
themselves get nothing in return except perhaps some acknowledgement and
additional experience solving problems.

If you are willing to cheat your dad to get some RAM, I will worry for
anyone who employs you or works with you. I would suggest that you speak
to your Dad - he may be willing to give you the RAM. Else, you can
consider saving up some pocket money, or perhaps even do something small -
such as helping out at a shop/office for a few days to make the money you
need to buy RAM. It will be far more rewarding than the method you have
adopted.

Regards,
PK

Message-ID: <d2a92d610611140236xecbe1c7l90589bba90e004a0@mail.gmail.com>

On 10/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Hmm., a SAN is completely different from a NAS box.
>
> PMI but I am curious. What are the differences?

NAS - Network Attached Storage - is basically a box with massive
storage space and its own TCP/IP stack and an administrative
interface. It exports filesystems over predominantly NFS or CIFS.
Client machines mount the shares (who can mount can be controlled on
the NAS box by specifying ACLs or the like) over the LAN via TCP/IP.
Throughput is dictated by network latency and bandwidth (on a
well-designed gigabit LAN, you can get 100 MB/sec throughput though).
Big vendors include EMC, HP etc. You can build a home-grown one with a
regular PC  and a few IDE disks, running Linux/*BSD and NFS/Samba.

SAN - Storage Area Network - is a separate network itself, with
cabling (fibre in the most common case, but copper is not unheard of),
switches and routers distinct from the LAN gear. Client machines
require hardware units called HBAs (Host Bus Adapters - usually a PCI
card from Emulex or QLogic) with appropriate drivers. The HBA is
connected to the nearest SAN switch (similar to hooking the network
adapter to the nearest LAN switch), to which the storage unit is also
connected. If things go well, the HBA driver exposes a block device to
the host OS, which can be partitioned, formatted with a regular
filesystem type (ext3, reiser, whatever) and used as if it is a local
attached drive. Big players in this market are EMC and Fujitsu, among
others. Thoughput is as good as host attached storage typically.

To justify investment in a SAN, one should ideally have storage
requirements of several terabytes whereas a NAS can be built cheaply
enough for even SMBs and home users.

Binand
From manokaran at gmail.com  Tue Nov 14 16:30:56 2006
From: manokaran at gmail.com (Mano)
Date: Tue Nov 14 16:31:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] About SAMBA
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610611140236xecbe1c7l90589bba90e004a0@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061106184413.32477.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20061107022246.GA22656@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611062028o3e492021ka13a31ee14a1754@mail.gmail.com>
	<1c4dc2780611062150n5525f82bke010f0014a6c4a10@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061109144020.GJ20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<4553F282.6070400@gmx.net>
	<20061110082500.GA28773@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<d2a92d610611140236xecbe1c7l90589bba90e004a0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7bf1bec50611140300o20b7c2a1hb8a2c31a20c51e84@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/14/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> connected. If things go well, the HBA driver exposes a block device to
> the host OS, which can be partitioned, formatted with a regular
> filesystem type (ext3, reiser, whatever) and used as if it is a local
> attached drive. Big players in this market are EMC and Fujitsu, among
> others. Thoughput is as good as host attached storage typically.
>
> To justify investment in a SAN, one should ideally have storage
> requirements of several terabytes whereas a NAS can be built cheaply
> enough for even SMBs and home users.

SAN can also be built using iSCSI speaking devices and regular
ethernet cabling. A Chennai company called Sanatdata sells IDE HDD
based iSCSI devices. Costwise compares very well with the big guns in
storage! Another option is ATAoE. However, as of now only one company
in this space.

Another off-the-shelf hardware approach is to use a GNBD server (a
linux box with regular ide hdd) to export block devices over ethernet
and GNBD clients (on the hosts that need storage) to import these
devices. I did this with a CentOS distro and it works. Am yet to
achieve clustering though!

regds,
mano

-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!

What do you mean by not connecting ? Any errors ? Most of us have/had 
BSNL Dataone Connection and UT-300R2 modem. Btw, that modem can be 
configured to connect on its own when switched on. You can try that and 
just give the modem's IP (192.168.1.1) as the gateway. No pppoe at all, 
just like connecting to a LAN.

The only thing I missed was creating the 75custom-scim_init file with 
the entries:

export XMODIFIERS="@im=SCIM"
export GTK_IM_MODULE="scim"
export XIM_PROGRAM="scim -d"

Now, it works absolutely great. I finally use a system that is totally 
free !! Thanks a lot.

From vinay at vinayras.com  Tue Nov 14 17:44:49 2006
From: vinay at vinayras.com (Vinay Yadav)
Date: Tue Nov 14 20:53:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Routing Problem
In-Reply-To: <20061109155944.GO20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <4552F61E.6040603@vinayras.com>	<e0900f3e0611090430s47971381v51b14d691106f5eb@mail.gmail.com>	<45533048.6030401@vinayras.com>	<20061109141634.GD20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>	<4553463A.8020003@vinayras.com>
	<20061109155944.GO20955@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <4559B339.8060709@vinayras.com>

Hi Girish,

> I think it might be a low level MTU issue. I only faced a problem like this when I set the MTU smaller than the layer 2 size.

Thanks for your help. It was an MTU issue.

MTU used by dial-up phone was 264. I changed to 1500 and then everything 
was working fine.

Thanks again
Vinay

Mob: 9422113939

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Nov 14 20:53:28 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Nov 14 20:53:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Widescreen Laptops with Linux.
In-Reply-To: <8e6637b50611140702o6ea4ebb2s28292c690b593f2d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061114152328.82383.qmail@web50202.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- vishnu vyas <vishnuvyas@gmail.com> wrote:
> Does Core 2 Duo work effectively with Linux? 

Yes.

> Does
> the kernel see a
> Core 2 Duo as 2 separate processors and splits the
> process on them

Yes.

> Heard Core 2 Duo + Hyperthreading equals 4 virtual
> processors? 

Yes. 

> does the linux kernel recognize that as 4 different
> processes?
 
No, just two. "cat /proc/cpuinfo" should show two
processors, and each processor will have two entires
for fpu.

cpuinfo showing Hyper-Threading support:
http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-htl/

/proc/cpuinfo:
http://www.mactel-linux.org/wiki//proc/cpuinfo

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

http://new.mail.yahoo.com

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Wed Nov 15 09:27:33 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Wed Nov 15 09:27:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] UTF-8 and indic languages
Message-ID: <455A902D.5040005@gmail.com>

Tamil and other indic scripts are 3 bytes per character if encoded
with UTF-8. That appears to be expensive.  Unicode says we could 
compress with algorithms but it would make every processor along the way 
crawl needlessly.

The basic alphabet for computing in Tamil takes up only 31 characters, 
and it is around that number for most indic languages. In the ASCII 
table, if we could map the space allocated for a-z to represent vowels 
and A-Z to represent consonants, that would leave enough gaps for even 
others and pave way to use just one byte per character.

There is no harm in using UTF-8 like some kind of universal language 
look up table as long as some intelligent mapping is done and followed 
for indic language processing needs in the existing ASCII code table.

Has anyone studied UTF-8 from the point of view of indic language computing?
From Kavitha.Duraisamy at cognizant.com  Wed Nov 15 09:33:15 2006

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Nov 15 10:36:34 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Wed Nov 15 10:37:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] DNS problem.
In-Reply-To: <3142AB86-8C77-4E7D-8E0D-7F8434F9F446@thenilgiris.com>
References: <9acfbb0b0611142044y1231d8baxa153e6cbbd9de928@mail.gmail.com>
	<3142AB86-8C77-4E7D-8E0D-7F8434F9F446@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <455AA05A.6040406@frodo.hserus.net>

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> 
> what distro?
> are your running your own dns?
> 

His dsl modem keeps giving him new IPs with dhcp, and its configured to
have 192.168.1.1 as the dns server.  Probably has a dns proxy built in
that often doesn't work too well, so he notices it.

Go login to the dsl modem (http://192.168.1.1 or whatever) and change
the dns servers in there to bsnl's dns servers.

Or run bind / dnscache on your local box and then set dhclient.conf /
dhcpcd.conf or whatever you use to have something like this

prepend domain-name-servers 127.0.0.1;

From Kavitha.Duraisamy at cognizant.com  Wed Nov 15 10:53:08 2006
From: Kavitha.Duraisamy at cognizant.com (Duraisamy, Kavitha (Cognizant))
Date: Wed Nov 15 10:53:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] CVS unix triggers
In-Reply-To: <455A969D.3030204@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <8595DEEF8B08D347BF085D1EEB357AE150FB2F@CTSINCHNSXUL.cts.com>


I want to create triggers for naming conventions to be followed during
tag and branch creation. In taginfo I couldn't trace whether tag is
being created or branch is being created.

These are the values which we can access in taginfo file
%p Directory name relative to the current root.
%m Message supplied on the command line.
%s List of files being tagged
%v List of versions being tagged
%b tag type
%o tag operation
%t tag name

My taginfo file's content :
ALL /netapp/home/s3428/umacvs/CVSROOT/loggit %t %b %o %p %{sVv} %c

Loggit's content
#!/bin/sh
echo "$@" >>/netapp/home/s3428/umacvs/CVSROOT/taglog

And taglog's content
%t %b %o %p %{sVv} %c tag11 add /netapp/home/s3428/umacvs/trunk test1.c
1.1.1.1 test2.c 1.1.1.1 test3.c 1.1.1.1

%b and %c doesn't have any content .... Is it any configuration issue???
%c - is supposed to hold the current command being executed 

Thanks 
Kavitha

Hi,

> Has anyone studied UTF-8 from the point of view of indic language
computing?

Time for UTF-16. Do not know much about all these though.. We have form a
Team who will deliberatly look into the encoding stuff.. May be a Team of
two or three...

Recently Tamil Virutual University, Thanjavur submitted a memorandum to the
Tamil Nadu Government about the 16-bit encoding. They even conducted a
conference. Download the document in both Engilsh and Tamil Versions
unfortunately .doc format :-(
http://tamilvu.org/coresite/html/cwwhatnw.htm

Regards..

From prasthelinuxgeek at gmail.com  Wed Nov 15 11:57:34 2006
From: prasthelinuxgeek at gmail.com (Prasanna Kumar)
Date: Wed Nov 15 11:57:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] CVS unix triggers
In-Reply-To: <8595DEEF8B08D347BF085D1EEB357AE150FB2F@CTSINCHNSXUL.cts.com>
References: <8595DEEF8B08D347BF085D1EEB357AE150FB2F@CTSINCHNSXUL.cts.com>
Message-ID: <455AB356.7010705@gmail.com>

   Duraisamy, Kavitha (Cognizant) wrote:

 I want to create triggers for naming conventions to be followed during
 tag and branch creation. In taginfo I couldn't trace whether tag is
 being created or branch is being created.

 These are the values which we can access in taginfo file
 %p Directory name relative to the current root.
 %m Message supplied on the command line.
 %s List of files being tagged
 %v List of versions being tagged
 %b tag type
 %o tag operation
 %t tag name

 My taginfo file's content :
 ALL /netapp/home/s3428/umacvs/CVSROOT/loggit %t %b %o %p %{sVv} %c

 Loggit's content
 #!/bin/sh
 echo "$@" >>/netapp/home/s3428/umacvs/CVSROOT/taglog

 And taglog's content
 %t %b %o %p %{sVv} %c tag11 add /netapp/home/s3428/umacvs/trunk test1.c
 1.1.1.1 test2.c 1.1.1.1 test3.c 1.1.1.1

 %b and %c doesn't have any content .... Is it any configuration issue???
 %c - is supposed to hold the current command being executed

 Thanks
 Kavitha




 -----Original Message-----
 From: ilugc-bounces@ae.iitm.ac.in [mailto:ilugc-bounces@ae.iitm.ac.in]
 On Behalf Of Suresh Ramasubramanian
 Sent: Wednesday, November 15, 2006 9:55 AM
 To: ILUG-C
 Subject: Re: [Ilugc] CVS unix triggers


 Duraisamy, Kavitha (Cognizant) wrote:
  

 I have a query in CVS -unix.I couldn't trace to variables(%c - current
    

  

 command being executed and %b - tag or branch) in taginfo file of
    

 CVSROOT folder -Concurrent Versions System (CVS) 1.11.1p1
 (client/server)
  

 
    

 Can you be more specific?  Where are you invoking %c etc?  These are
 context sensitive .. if you run one of those in a hook from cvs up,
 you'd get %c as "update"

         srs

refuses to add RAM even if I buy it from my own pocket money..So the

Message-ID: <70106e0b0611142302u7d4455a2u6e5839f08c1a763b@mail.gmail.com>

> > They have only CD reader. Is it possible to install thro' network?
Ya. You can net boot the PCs using the pxe, tft and nfs/http/ftp.
http://www.stanford.edu/~alfw/PXE-Kickstart/PXE-Kickstart.html
I used this with fedora. You can basically use any distro that can
install over network.

> If the above is not possible, how to create CDs from the DVD.
Just get the installer image and burn it to a cd. You can start the
installation with it. You get it for debian. So you might get it for
the others also.
> Many software were installed using apt-get install.How to get those software
> from this PC so that i need not go for net again.
Create a mirror-like setup with what you have downloaded already on
the existing machine. That way you might even be able to propagate
updates to the newly installed. I don't have the exact links, but I
remember reading about setting up mirrors in the debian site. Simpler
yet, just go through the tree in the iitm ftp site and create yours in
a similar fashion.

Hope that helps.
-- 
Regards,

Abishek Goda
http://goda.abishek.googlepages.com

From raja.mallik at sqlstar.com  Wed Nov 15 15:36:47 2006
From: raja.mallik at sqlstar.com (Raja Mallik)
Date: Wed Nov 15 15:31:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Jobs] Urgent requirement - Sr. Embedded Software ( 3-7
	years Exp)
In-Reply-To: <44E54250.7030109@lynusacademy.com>
References: <44E54250.7030109@lynusacademy.com>
Message-ID: <1163585207.2704.91.camel@Neo>

Hi all,

Please forward this to your friends: This is an immediate requirement.

====================================================================

At the moment, a new venture merging into Wimax(802.16) devices software
development for next generation mobile devices are looking for a few
strong candidates with the details mentioned below: 

Designation: Sr. Techical Eng.(Embedded Software)

Post            : 2

Experience : 5 years++ ( + 0r - 1 years)

Packages  : (As per industry standard)


Skills    : ( desired from SOC engineers) : 

1) OS -Embedded Linux/Vxworks/Windows
2) Embedded Board/SOC -- OMAP, ARM Versatile, etc. any flavour.
3) Cross toolchain -- arm-linux, mips-linux, i386-linux
4) Bootloader -- rrload, u-boot, armboot
5) Kernel  --- Linux-2.6/linux-2.4 
6) Board Support Package -- Knowledge on BSP patches applied to kernel 
                            for any SOC.
7) File system -- writing a file system for an embedded board from
scratch.( jffs2)
8) Flash programming( MTD block)
9) Debugger used: JTAG, MULTI-ICE, GDB/KGDB integration.
10) Serial port console.
11) Tiny-Login, Busybox port to board
12) Tools : Code Composer Studio, Eclipse, etc. 
13) DSP knowledge and application programming.
14) Knowledge of wrting interface between kernel device driver and
low-level device driver of board peripherials.

Additional skills:

1) TCP/IP,SCTP,SIP/oRTP network layer and application.
2) Network protocol debugging.
3) High comfort level using unix and windows OS. 
4) Loyal and honesty.

Pl, write to raja.mallik@sqlstar.com with current CV attached. 

==================================================================

Raja Mallik
Embedded and Telecom

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Wed Nov 15 19:01:31 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Wed Nov 15 19:01:11 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] UTF-8 and indic languages
In-Reply-To: <e3dcb5360611142131p1ab3996eq77b7625e1fd62684@mail.gmail.com>
References: <455A902D.5040005@gmail.com>	<EA0D1203-090B-41D8-A892-DE2BAFDA5E08@thenilgiris.com>
	<e3dcb5360611142131p1ab3996eq77b7625e1fd62684@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455B16B3.70903@gmail.com>

?.??????? wrote:
> > Has anyone studied UTF-8 from the point of view of indic language 
> computing?
>
> Time for UTF-16. Do not know much about all these though.. We have form a
> Team who will deliberatly look into the encoding stuff.. May be a Team of
> two or three...
I was wrong. With UTF-8 encoding, ? takes 3 bytes, ?? takes 6 bytes and 
?? would take 9 - I was thinking all the three would take 3 bytes each, 
and that was expensive. Under the usual ASCII toggle scheme, they would 
take 1, 2 and 3 bytes respectively. Anyway, filling up the missing chars 
may be more useful and that seems to be the real issue now.
>
> Recently Tamil Virutual University, Thanjavur submitted a memorandum 
> to the
> Tamil Nadu Government about the 16-bit encoding. They even conducted a
> conference. Download the document in both Engilsh and Tamil Versions
> unfortunately .doc format :-(
> http://tamilvu.org/coresite/html/cwwhatnw.htm 
Was any invitation to the Conference sent to ILUGC, FSF-India or any of 
the free software user groups in India? I may have missed seeing it.

I am afraid I could not follow many of the statements in that conference 
document. They don't seem to be talking about UTF-16 (that requires 4 
bytes for each character). Substantially, it looks like they would like 
the Unicode Consortium to amend the UTF-8 encoding table to accomodate 
all the 247 Tamil Characters, along with other special characters to 
denote numerals, the vada sol chars and other special chars. While that 
is commendable and would correct the situation to some extent, I totally 
fail to follow what the experts call as "Unique encoding standard for 
Tamil". Unicode is a common encoding standard for the whole world. The 
paper should be written with more clarity, so that the folks at Unicode 
Consortium can follow and act on the request.

It says:
<quote>
75% supported the view that the effort of implementing 16?bit encoding 
for Tamil can be independent of similar efforts for other Indian languages.
</quote>

I belong to the 25% who oppose that view and would stay, it is of 
crucial importance to co-ordinate such efforts along with all the other 
indic language working groups - who are also in the same boat. While 
making requests for amendments, it should be noted:

The ASCII character encoding is smart in the following ways:

- the Lsb's for numerals (0, 1, 2, ... 9) represent the numbers 
themselves (0000, 0001, 0010 ... 1001)
- ASCII integers can be converted to binary by flipping bits 5 and 4 to 0
- Uppercase to lower case could be done by flipping bit 5 from 0 to 1
- Uppercase alphabets can be converted to control characters by flipping 
bit 6 of Msb from 1 to 0

How elegant!

Now, UTF-8 has room for all the chars in all the languages of the world. 
It ought to be easy for us to transliterate from one indic language to 
another, without much coding effort - by just flipping a few bits. If we 
don't do it now, when else would we do it? As far as possible, all the 
indic languages should be allocated contigious space so that phonetic 
connections etc could be easily seen and dealt with elegantly. Also, the 
characters should be arranged so that sorting is possible. The Tamil 
chars in the existing UTF-8 encoding table seem to arranged in a random 
order.

Also, we should ask for including Sanskrit and Tamil in the UTF-8 ranges 
higher than the basic multilingual plane, so that they can be encoded 
with just 2 bytes, placing them along with Latin and Greek.

-Ramanraj K

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Wed Nov 15 22:17:31 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Wed Nov 15 22:17:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] BSD licensed implementation of ELF and GELF
Message-ID: <455B44A3.9010001@gmail.com>

For the attention of any BSD aficionados here:

__fwd message from Joseph Koshy__

The past few months I have been writing a BSD-licensed
implementation of the SysV ELF(3) and GELF(3) API.

These APIs allows you to write applications that manipulate
ELF files, e.g., nm, strip, ld.  The GELF(3) API permits
applications to be written in an ELF class (32/64 bit)
agnostic way.

It is now available here:
 http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/cvsweb.cgi/src/lib/libelf/

It implements 82 public APIs, in approx 8K LoC of code,
and documents them in 4.5K lines of manual pages.  An
accompanying TET based test suite is about 10K LoC of
M4/C code.  The test suite is still only about half way
done.

-- 
FreeBSD Volunteer,     http://people.freebsd.org/~jkoshy

On 11/15/06, ?.??????? <shriramadhas@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> > Has anyone studied UTF-8 from the point of view of indic language
> computing?
>
> Time for UTF-16. Do not know much about all these though.. We have form a
> Team who will deliberatly look into the encoding stuff.. May be a Team of
> two or three...

Values in the range 0800 - FFFF can be coded in 2 bytes using UTF16
where as it will need 3 bytes in UTF8. For documents written entirely
in Tamil (0B80 - 0BFF) UTF16 will give a 33% saving.

Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/

On 11/15/06, Ramanraj K <ramanraj.k@gmail.com> wrote:
> I was wrong. With UTF-8 encoding, ? takes 3 bytes, ?? takes 6 bytes and
> ?? would take 9 - I was thinking all the three would take 3 bytes each,
> and that was expensive. Under the usual ASCII toggle scheme, they would
> take 1, 2 and 3 bytes respectively. Anyway, filling up the missing chars
> may be more useful and that seems to be the real issue now.

Yes it will solve a lot of other issues and will simplify searching
and processing of Tamil text.

> I am afraid I could not follow many of the statements in that conference
> document. They don't seem to be talking about UTF-16 (that requires 4
> bytes for each character).

I haven't read the document completely. But it is confusing (What is
16-bit Unicode system?)
- Unicode is a 4byte coding scheme developed to represent all language.
- On the assumption that the codes for characters used in a document
will be concentrated on one particular region different encoding
schemes were developed to optimize space: UTF8, UTF16, UTF32.

> It says:
> <quote>
> 75% supported the view that the effort of implementing 16?bit encoding
> for Tamil can be independent of similar efforts for other Indian languages.
> </quote>
>
> I belong to the 25% who oppose that view and would stay, it is of
> crucial importance to co-ordinate such efforts along with all the other
> indic language working groups - who are also in the same boat.

I too strongly agree with you. Unicode makes it possible to mix
different languages in a simple text document which, otherwise, would
not have been possible.

> Now, UTF-8 has room for all the chars in all the languages of the world.
> It ought to be easy for us to transliterate from one indic language to
> another, without much coding effort - by just flipping a few bits. If we
> don't do it now, when else would we do it? As far as possible, all the
> indic languages should be allocated contigious space so that phonetic
> connections etc could be easily seen and dealt with elegantly. Also, the
> characters should be arranged so that sorting is possible. The Tamil
> chars in the existing UTF-8 encoding table seem to arranged in a random
> order.
>
> Also, we should ask for including Sanskrit and Tamil in the UTF-8 ranges
> higher than the basic multilingual plane, so that they can be encoded
> with just 2 bytes, placing them along with Latin and Greek.

Truly these are some nice suggestions, I hope these concerns are taken care

-- 
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/
From prashmohan at gmail.com  Thu Nov 16 00:38:42 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)
Date: Thu Nov 16 00:39:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] UTF-8 and indic languages
In-Reply-To: <455A902D.5040005@gmail.com>
References: <455A902D.5040005@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455B65BA.9060408@gmail.com>

Ramanraj K wrote:
> Tamil and other indic scripts are 3 bytes per character if encoded
> with UTF-8. That appears to be expensive.  Unicode says we could
> compress with algorithms but it would make every processor along the way
> crawl needlessly.

Could someone give a tiny intro to the Problems faced by the
localization community? GLV/Monthly meet?
-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

<Title of the page>

<Details of each technical Tamil word used in this page and their equivalent

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Thu Nov 16 09:46:52 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Thu Nov 16 09:47:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Suresh on news.com
In-Reply-To: <1163649995.5726.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20061115175402.32470.qmail@web54701.mail.yahoo.com>	<c293dd340611151010o395a2981k5bf4d70f6bd92436@mail.gmail.com>	<1AC9CC65-646E-475F-B33C-70B7EAB0524C@thenilgiris.com>	<455BDCA6.8050307@frodo.hserus.net>
	<1163649995.5726.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <455BE634.3060305@frodo.hserus.net>

Deepan wrote:
> On Thu, 2006-11-16 at 09:06 +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
>> Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
>>> cool interview - cool guy too, although he looks over 30 ;-)
>>>
> 
> Hi Suresh,
>   How will promotion of open source help in controlling spam?  

One very simple way.  Windows PCs get infected with viruses, and virus
infected PCs are among the single largest sources of spam / DDoS etc
traffic in the world today.  The more linux boxes there are (and there
are several publicly available PCs in kiosk setups that are now linux,
the world over .. for example if you fly Lufthansa - check out the
frankfurt airport lounges. There are some public access internet
terminals there, basically small PCs that run SuSE and boot into a very
restricted X session that only loads firefox). No chance of that kind of
PC, used by a wide variety of people, getting infected.

ps: At least in India, Sify iWay tried using linux PCs with the standard
iway frontend but they had this badly botched implementation and very
old OS (rh 9 when fc3/fc4 was out) so that it was not very usable for
most people who went there.. if I went to an iWay and sat at a linux PC,
the cafe guy would say "sir, thats a linux PC, take that other PC over
there, its windows". :)

Another thing is that FOSS software is free as in beer, besides the
"free as in freedom" thing.  Certainly a rather more attractive
alternative for cash strapped ISPs in developing countries, than buying
licenses for an expensive mailserver on windows (and a lot more, and far
more powerful servers to install windows + that mailserver software on)

I know people who can run mail for several dozen to a few hundred users
on an old 486 without any problems, if that box is running linux (in
fact I set up a few of those using uucp over dialup for some branch
offices, in a previous job years back).  Try to do the same thing in
windows and you'd need far more ram / disk space / cpu, and you'd spend
a lot more on licenses if you went and bought exchange or notes instead
of installing postfix.

There's more, but these two are the most visible benefits of FOSS
against antispam.

	srs

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Nov 16 11:58:11 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Nov 16 11:58:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Suresh on news.com

	<c293dd340611151010o395a2981k5bf4d70f6bd92436@mail.gmail.com>
	<1AC9CC65-646E-475F-B33C-70B7EAB0524C@thenilgiris.com>

	<1163649995.5726.15.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<455BE634.3060305@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <20061116062811.GB5305@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 16, 2006 at 09:46:52AM +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
> One very simple way.  Windows PCs get infected with viruses, and virus
> infected PCs are among the single largest sources of spam / DDoS etc
> traffic in the world today.  The more linux boxes there are (and there
> are several publicly available PCs in kiosk setups that are now linux,
> the world over .. for example if you fly Lufthansa - check out the
> frankfurt airport lounges. There are some public access internet
> terminals there, basically small PCs that run SuSE and boot into a very
> restricted X session that only loads firefox). No chance of that kind of
> PC, used by a wide variety of people, getting infected.

 [snip] 

> Another thing is that FOSS software is free as in beer, besides the
> "free as in freedom" thing.  Certainly a rather more attractive
> alternative for cash strapped ISPs in developing countries, than buying
> licenses for an expensive mailserver on windows (and a lot more, and far
> more powerful servers to install windows + that mailserver software on)
> 
> I know people who can run mail for several dozen to a few hundred users
> on an old 486 without any problems, if that box is running linux (in
> fact I set up a few of those using uucp over dialup for some branch
> offices, in a previous job years back).  Try to do the same thing in
> windows and you'd need far more ram / disk space / cpu, and you'd spend
> a lot more on licenses if you went and bought exchange or notes instead
> of installing postfix.
> 
> There's more, but these two are the most visible benefits of FOSS
> against antispam.

There are plenty other reasons of course. :)

Bruce Schneier, the most respected cryptographer on earth(though there are better guys) has always been advocating open algos and source code for strong crypto.

'Security thro' obscurity' is a losing proposition. I look at spam,viruses,worms etc. as the sister fields of crypto though I would hesitate from calling it security topics.

Now, I will go to the extreme of saying that open source is a one stop solution for all technology problems on earth but I think hardly 1% of ILUGC will agree with me on that. ;)

In purely practical terms , most anti spam solutions are open source. And anti spam is more of an individual preference issue than something black and white. Well not always but sometimes.

So you may not like an e-mail about a Nigerian widow or Vi***a  but I may love it. :)

So each individual has to "train" or educate his own spam filter based on his preferences. And this corpus needs to talk to other such databases for quickness and early efficiency.

Without free sharing of data, information and customization possibilities this model cannot work.

I can conceive that such things can theoretically be done in a closed source manner too but it is incredibly impossible to predict what the user will want accurately. Customization and closed source are not bed fellows.

Moreover open source is excellence, open source is worldclassness, open source is quality of the highest order...

You know quite well what else I will say. So I will stop.

Best,
Girish

        from /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/net/protocol.rb:116:in `readuntil'
        from /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/net/protocol.rb:126:in `readline'
        from /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/net/http.rb:1988:in `read_status_line'
        from /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/net/http.rb:1977:in `read_new'
        from /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/net/http.rb:1046:in `request'
         ... 23 levels...
        from /usr/local/lib/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/cmd_manager.rb:94:in
`process_args'
        from /usr/local/lib/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/cmd_manager.rb:67:in
`run'
        from /usr/local/lib/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/gem_runner.rb:13:in `run'
        from /usr/bin/gem:17

Hacker Agarathi - Guidelines suggestions..

Hi every one,

That was a gr8 name to begin with. Well here are few suggestions.. Right now
English technical words and their proposed equivalent Tamil words are being
added to one single page...

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/Hacker_??????

As words pile up it may not give desired results.. Keeping in view of that,
an alphabetical grouping of words is necessary,

So,

If u type in future, on the web browser,

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/A

it will give all words compiled beginning with A.

Similarly for B, http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/B

We can have 50 words in a page, two column.. each having 25 words and then
keep on adding new page if more and more words comes.. by giving next page
link under each page..

Also its worthwhile to define each word.. how it came and examples of using
it in a word specific page..

Say i have for Directory - ????? (Adaivu), a link on that word would lead me
to a page where in i will find the definition of the word.. and sample words
as to how to use and where to use..

So this will help people not only in knowing the words but also how to use
them..

These can form long term objectives...

Thats it for now :-)

Well, one doubt.. is there a provision of taking daily backup of contents of
Suzhi?







-- 
????????,
?. ???? ???????.

Blog: http://aamachu.blogspot.com/

line.

From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Fri Nov 17 07:17:05 2006
From: shriramadhas at gmail.com (=?UTF-8?B?4K6uLuCusOCuvuCuruCupOCuvuCuuOCvjQ==?=)

Subject: [Ilugc] Ubuntu Tamil Forum & Ubuntu TamilNadu User Mailing List
Message-ID: <e3dcb5360611161747s6a9753e3p9205a36721403a2@mail.gmail.com>

Hi all,

How do you reply to your mom when she tries to wake you up in the morning?
"Amma! Amma! please ma.. innum konjam neram thoonga viden..."

How do you ask your dad to buy a bike.? "Appa.. appa.. College pogarathukku
pudusa oru bike vaangi kungalen.."

How dou u ask your friend to accompany you to Satyam Talkies.. "Machi!
Vaada.. Naalaikku Varalaaru Pakka Polam"

How do u speak to your gf! "" (sorry, no comments, personal matters...)

How do you discuss with your friends about a Cricket Match, Politics etc.,
etc.,

So your language which is capable of expressing all your feelings above can
also express your thoughts and ideas in Technical aspects too.. The only
thing is that the oppurtunity might not have been provided for that...

Well, Personally, I have seen lot of my friends who are technically sound..
will not simply express his ideas and views because of some kind of an
inferiority complex that, what they might speak in English may be wrong...
It should not and never be an issue henceforth...

We at Ubuntu Tamil Wanna end this... Presenting you, the Ubuntu Tamil
Forum.. where you can debate and discuss technical issues in our mother
Tongue... thamizh.ubuntuforums.org

Presenting you the , Ubuntu Tamil Nadu Users mailing list,
https://lists.ubuntu.com/mailman/listinfo/ubuntu-tam

And also we have an IRC channel: #ubuntu-tam @ freenode

We already have Suzhi to mold us into Technical Writing.. Only thing we need
is all your support and encouragement...

--

On 16-Nov-06, at 11:04 PM, ?.??????? wrote:

> http://nrcfosshelpline.in/Suzhi/Hacker_??????
>
> As words pile up it may not give desired results.. Keeping in view  
> of that,
> an alphabetical grouping of words is necessary,

true - but in the typical foss development model, we keep everything  
on one page until it becomes too big - then split like A-L and M-Z,  
and then keep splitting as it grows. Nothing more annoying than to go  
to a page with nothing on it.

hi,

NRC-FOSS at AU-KBC is pleased to announce the Indian FOSS Conclave -  
2007. The preliminaries for the IFC will commence in foss.in and will  
culminate in the Conclave to be held at Chennai in March 2007.  
Foss.in will be providing BOF slots for the preliminary sessions of  
the IFC on all three days of foss.in. Please check the schedule for  
details. Full details of the IFC are available at the IFC wiki at  
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/ifc/

From anjeas_net at yahoo.com  Fri Nov 17 09:35:22 2006
From: anjeas_net at yahoo.com (Ashok Antony)
Date: Fri Nov 17 09:35:48 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Getting file contents
Message-ID: <20061117040522.39374.qmail@web54111.mail.yahoo.com>

join OLD.file NEW.file > merge
  The above command gets the records, which is common to both the files. ( OLD.file,NEW.file)

join ?a1 OLD.file NEW.file > all
  The above command gets the common records as well as the records which is available only in OLD.file

comm ?13 merge all
  The above command results the records, which is available only in OLD.file.

My objective is to extract the records which is avilable only in OLD.file, is the above commands are correct to met my objective.

Please correct me if I am wrong.

anthony

As you might know, Java Is Now Open Source. So to mark the occasion,
IndicThreads.com Conference On Java Technology is running a contest
where you answer four questions and can win -

1) A copy of "Beginning EJB 3 Application Development: From Novice to
Professional" by Raghu R. Kodali, Jonathan R. Wetherbee and Peter
Zadrozny

2) A copy of "Java Persistence with Hibernate" by Christian Bauer and
Gavin King

3) A full conference pass to the IndicThreads.com Conference On Java Technology

For Details Check Out -
http://www.IndicThreads.com
or
http://conference.indicthreads.com

thanks,

From srini.it at gmail.com  Sat Nov 18 12:09:58 2006
From: srini.it at gmail.com (Srinivasan Sundararajan)
Date: Sat Nov 18 12:10:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Second foss elective approved
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170611130443k7228dcc5t3a7e69d6034c0d8b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1163416565.3141.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<A56DBA97-5662-45F6-AECD-EA9D3216EE94@thenilgiris.com>
	<20061113122801.GA25234@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<9a9bfc170611130443k7228dcc5t3a7e69d6034c0d8b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <328077850611172239i2601ab21t41649bfcf237fa69@mail.gmail.com>

hi everybody:

1. Anna University normally gives a list of electives for a given
semester. However, FOSS electives could be taken in any semester in
which electives are offered [CSE (6th and 8th sem) and IT (8th sem)].
Our suggestion is : CSE6th should take Elective I and the 8th sem
students of CSE/IT could take the Elective II. I would appreciate if
you could send us a mail and discuss how we could cooperate to "sell"
the elective to the students and make the effort fruitful.

2. The absence of lab component is a serious drawback. However, some
colleges had provided a semblance of FOSS lab. NRCFOSS is in the final
stages of the FOSS Lab "server" which will contain most of the
docs/reports/codes of relevance to the electives -- we plan to demo it
during FOSS.IN. Once the college provides a FOSS Lab with the server
and 10-20 systems, the students could have a better chance. We also
hope that the student projects in FOSS will increase.

3. FOSS is not confined to CSE/IT. However, I would not like to
venture for "FOSS courses" for other branches. They could (a) have
exposure in the first year -- computer practice course could have a
unit on FOSS concepts & philocophy ; the lab could have Open Office
components and (b) during later semesters get guidance to use the open
source packages of relavance to them. Hope to catch you all on the
"migration" work during the forthcoming months.

Srinivasan, NRCFOSS.

It cant find it so throws an error

Read the docs on how to fix that

Thyagu rajan wrote:
> Hello friends,
> 
> I have an ruby on rails application which i want to install in a server
> When i start my script/server it gives me the following error
> 
> 
> ./script/../config/boot.rb:16:in `require': no such file to load --

You might want to sign up for the Chennai.rb list for Ruby/Rails
specific queries:

http://groups.google.com/group/chennairb

Regarding your error, most probably because the file 'server' in the
script directory is not executable. You might want to make all the files
in that directory executable.


V.
From vamlists at gmail.com  Sat Nov 18 14:05:36 2006

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> hi,
> 
> after a long time i had to set up postgresql on fc6. It is working fine

From kushaldas at gmail.com  Sat Nov 18 14:12:44 2006
From: kushaldas at gmail.com (Kushal Das)
Date: Sat Nov 18 14:12:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] postgresql and fc6 problem
In-Reply-To: <4C9238DA-AE09-4684-81CD-6BCCD16E9B7A@thenilgiris.com>
References: <056D368D-7E4A-427F-9091-054192A88384@thenilgiris.com>
	<455EC5D8.1000301@gmail.com>
	<4C9238DA-AE09-4684-81CD-6BCCD16E9B7A@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <b399909d0611180042g316ac86du78c337c3b3ea37b@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/18/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
>


By default pg_hba.conf file in FC6:

# TYPE  DATABASE    USER        CIDR-ADDRESS          METHOD

# "local" is for Unix domain socket connections only
local   all         all                               ident sameuser
# IPv4 local connections:
host    all         all         127.0.0.1/32          ident sameuser
# IPv6 local connections:
host    all         all         ::1/128               ident sameuser


Now change only in the first line, change the method from "ident
sameuser" to "password"


# TYPE  DATABASE    USER        CIDR-ADDRESS          METHOD

# "local" is for Unix domain socket connections only
local   all         all                               password
# IPv4 local connections:
host    all         all         127.0.0.1/32          ident sameuser
# IPv6 local connections:
host    all         all         ::1/128               ident sameuser



-- 
Fedora Ambassador
http://kushaldas.blogspot.com

	<b399909d0611180042g316ac86du78c337c3b3ea37b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <354FE306-4777-4EDB-B8E1-23E419BD582A@thenilgiris.com>


On 18-Nov-06, at 2:12 PM, Kushal Das wrote:

> By default pg_hba.conf file in FC6:
>
> # TYPE  DATABASE    USER        CIDR-ADDRESS          METHOD
>
> # "local" is for Unix domain socket connections only
> local   all         all                               ident sameuser
> # IPv4 local connections:
> host    all         all         127.0.0.1/32          ident sameuser
> # IPv6 local connections:
> host    all         all         ::1/128               ident sameuser
>
>
> Now change only in the first line, change the method from "ident
> sameuser" to "password"
>
>
> # TYPE  DATABASE    USER        CIDR-ADDRESS          METHOD
>
> # "local" is for Unix domain socket connections only
> local   all         all                               password
> # IPv4 local connections:
> host    all         all         127.0.0.1/32          ident sameuser
> # IPv6 local connections:
> host    all         all         ::1/128               ident sameuser

if you had looked at my original post, you would have found that all  
this had been done long ago, this is not the problem - the problem  
was that selinux had been installed. Once that was reset to  
permissive mode, the problem was solved. Aparently fc6 has strictest  
selinux installed by default

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Nov 18 15:34:37 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Second foss elective approved
In-Reply-To: <328077850611172239i2601ab21t41649bfcf237fa69@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061118100437.85098.qmail@web50203.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

My thoughts below:

--- Srinivasan Sundararajan <srini.it@gmail.com>
wrote:
> 2. The absence of lab component is a serious
> drawback. 

Indeed.

> However, some
> colleges had provided a semblance of FOSS lab.

Quite a number of students living in hostels in the
colleges have their own computer or share it with
their roommates. So, these can definitely complement
the FOSS lab resources that colleges may or may not
provide.

The major constraint that I see is a *proper* 24x7
Internet connection at these colleges (at cities,
towns, villages). If they want to work with FOSS
projects, they need to be able to *use* the Internet,
and discuss with developers/mentors through mailing
lists/IRC/forums.

> Once the college provides a FOSS Lab
> with the server
> and 10-20 systems, 
> the students could have a better
> chance. 

Should alteast aim for one system per student. Nothing
like hands-on experience.

Regards,

SK

From srinivasanr at gmail.com  Sun Nov 19 00:15:24 2006
From: srinivasanr at gmail.com (Srinivasan R)
Date: Sun Nov 19 00:15:33 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] choice of web development technology
In-Reply-To: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <e70ef6930611181045l7bf17fedo54c98a52301537f6@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/18/06, anantha narasimhan <anantha.narasimhan@gmail.com> wrote:
> hey,
>
> iam trying to build a web service. I tht i ss hd take a quick response
> from the community in choosing the technology. The project demands a
> good UI (planing to rope in ajax) and has  pretty complex
> datastructures to work with in the back end. The performance is also
> critical as its  traffic is going to be a bit high. which
> technology/framework/language would be best  for developing such an
> application.

Two popular languages used for web development right now are Python and Ruby.

There are numerous frameworks for Python like web.py, turbogears,
django, pylons, etc.
I prefer web.py as it 'doesn't get into your way'. the most simplest
of all frameworks that python world has to offer.

If you want to go for Ruby, Ruby on Rails is the most popular over
there. It has got one nice feature 'scaffolding' where a single
command creates all the necessary code for your controller with all
the basic actions like new, edit, delete, view, etc.
It is from the Basecamp people and many websites use Rails.

I am trying to see how good is Pylons. It has got all the good things
from perl, python, and rails.

web.py - http://webpy.org/
Pylons - http://pylonshq.com/
Turbogears - http://www.turbogears.org/
Django - http://www.djangoproject.com/
Ruby on Rails - http://www.rubyonrails.org/

PS: sorry for not including PHP in here.
-- 
Next mail in %d minutes
cnu - http://cnu.livejournal.com
http://www.fslog.com - Free Software Blog

From vamlists at gmail.com  Sun Nov 19 03:04:11 2006
From: vamlists at gmail.com (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Sun Nov 19 03:04:28 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] choice of web development technology
In-Reply-To: <e70ef6930611181045l7bf17fedo54c98a52301537f6@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
	<e70ef6930611181045l7bf17fedo54c98a52301537f6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455F7C53.90704@gmail.com>

Srinivasan R wrote:

> If you want to go for Ruby, Ruby on Rails is the most popular over
> there. It has got one nice feature 'scaffolding' where a single
> command creates all the necessary code for your controller with all
> the basic actions like new, edit, delete, view, etc.
> It is from the Basecamp people and many websites use Rails.
> 

Perhaps scaffolding is not the best feature of Rails - it is a nice
thing to play with when you are initially prototyping your webapp - but
you always end up re-writing all your scaffolding code anyways. The most
compelling feature might be what you can call 'best-practices built-in'
- database migrations (one of my favorites), convention over
configuration, DRY (do not repeat yourself) etc. There's a whole
philosophy behind the Rails way ;-) (and obviously, a whole new industry
to make money off it).

If you're seriously evaluating Rails, then you might want to talk to
some of the folks here:

http://groups.google.com/group/chennairb

(you will be surprised at how many startups in Chennai are doing Rails
work - they might have some war stories to share).

Otherwise, I like the philosophy of web.py - it doesn't hurt that it was
written by one of Reddit's founders, Aaron Swartz (and Reddit itself
runs on it). Definitely worth a try.


V.

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Sun Nov 19 07:42:13 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sun Nov 19 07:41:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Suresh on news.com
In-Reply-To: <20061115175402.32470.qmail@web54701.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20061115175402.32470.qmail@web54701.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <455FBD7D.3010003@gmail.com>

 >news.com.>
 >http://news.com.com/Exterminating+the+nuisance+of+spam/2008-7349_3-6135649.html?tag=nefd.lede

Cool.  Looks like google is yet to hear about srs. Ever since I got a 
gmail id, I have had the pleasure of receiving tons of bytes of spam 
(majority of which google "filters" for me and saves them neatly in a 
Spam folder for 30 days that I can search, mark or delete  if I want to.) 

Additionally gmail also delivers mails addressed to ramson@gmail.com, 
ramanuja.g@gmail.com and a host of ram*@gmail.com addresses to me, 
probably using its "patented" "PigeonRank Technology" :) I am not sure 
if I should classify these as spam or as misdirected deliveries or both.

"Spam" originally meant "finely chopped cooked meat that has been 
pressed together in a container, usually sold in cans and served cold in 
slices" (OALD).  That changed with:

<quote>
The same Senate Report recounts the origin of the term "spam," 
explaining "'it all started in early Internet chat rooms and interactive 
fantasy games where someone repeating the same sentence or comment was 
said to be making a 'spam'. The term referred to a Monty Python's Flying 
Circus scene in which actors keep saying 'Spam, Spam, Spam, and Spam' 
when reading options from a menu.'" S. Rep. No. 108-102, at n.l (quoting 
April 5, 1999 edition of Computerworld).
</quote> (source: http://www.spamlaws.com/cases/whitebuffalo.shtml)

"Repeating the same sentence or comment" is a sure sign of having lost 
an argument, and those good there would hardly stop at anything else. 
Naturally, spam has managed to maintain its original meaty flavour.  
Ever since US passed the CAN SPAM law (one cannot miss the message in 
bold there) spammers have been seen suing Universities who were blocking 
their uce's which is technically not the same as anything else.  CAN 
SPAM and many others like to say officially you cannot spam, but the 
emerging position appears to be: [1] At most places, right to spam is 
subject to reasonable restrictions [2] The right to block spam is 
recognized. That makes enough room for all :)

http://spamlinks.net/legal.htm
http://www.spamlaws.com/federal/108s877.shtml
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Can_Spam_Act_of_2003

What we do is to bounce (or rather smtp 550 reject at our gateway) any
spam that we detect

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Sun Nov 19 08:13:10 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sun Nov 19 08:12:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] UTF-8 and indic languages
In-Reply-To: <5d0d0e310611151034jf587bbdhba97c1620a085c8d@mail.gmail.com>
References: <455A902D.5040005@gmail.com>	<EA0D1203-090B-41D8-A892-DE2BAFDA5E08@thenilgiris.com>	<e3dcb5360611142131p1ab3996eq77b7625e1fd62684@mail.gmail.com>
	<5d0d0e310611151034jf587bbdhba97c1620a085c8d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455FC4BE.2040404@gmail.com>

Vijairaj wrote:
> On 11/15/06, ?.??????? <shriramadhas@gmail.com> wrote:
>> Hi,
>>
>> > Has anyone studied UTF-8 from the point of view of indic language
>> computing?
>>
>> Time for UTF-16. Do not know much about all these though.. We have 
>> form a
>> Team who will deliberatly look into the encoding stuff.. May be a 
>> Team of
>> two or three...
>
> Values in the range 0800 - FFFF can be coded in 2 bytes using UTF16
> where as it will need 3 bytes in UTF8. For documents written entirely
> in Tamil (0B80 - 0BFF) UTF16 will give a 33% saving. 
First and foremost - characters have to be available as Unicode data. 
Tamil is currently at a Level-2 implementation of the Unicode standard, 
and making it a Level-1 standard so that every character has a unique 
code should be the top priority.

Next, we could use any UTF to represent that data. UTF-8 appears to be 
emerging as the defacto standard for character encoding, because of its 
ability to efficiently encode using 1, 2, 3 or 4 bytes. UTF-16 is used 
by java and windows - may be it would be around, but UTF is only about 
the implementation and http://www.unicode.org/unicode/faq/utf_bom.html 
gives a detailed picture about the comparative advantage of using each.

http://www.utf-8.com/ gives links to a number of or resources for 
developers.

Since the main concern now is to see to it that Unicode includes all 
Tamil characters, it would be necessary to make a list of them first, 
and then see how it could be made to relate well both internally and 
with other languages.

The most unique thing about Tamil may be its affinity with mathematics. 
There are specific names and symbols for a number of fractions from 1/2 
to immi with surprising octet connections with a huge number of them in 
the series 1/8, 1/16, 1/32 to 1/320 and less. AFAIK, fractions are 
poorly represented in the computing field even today, and making room 
for these characters should be interesting and useful.

A number of old works on Tamil grammar are in the public domain, and if 
any attempt is made to publish it online (without gifs or other image 
files to represent characters), it would immediately expose the full set 
of Tamil characters that need to be sent to Unicode.

Ramanraj K

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Sun Nov 19 09:02:59 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Sun Nov 19 09:07:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] choice of web development technology
In-Reply-To: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455FD06B.3050605@gmail.com>

anantha narasimhan wrote:
> hey,
> 
> iam trying to build a web service. I tht i ss hd take a quick response
> from the community in choosing the technology. The project demands a
> good UI (planing to rope in ajax) and has  pretty complex
> datastructures to work with in the back end. The performance is also
> critical as its  traffic is going to be a bit high. which
> technology/framework/language would be best  for developing such an
> application.

First you have to select with either Python or Ruby to have as the base 
language. I do not have much idea about Ruby, other than something about 
Ruby on Rails. But, I work in Django. Python is easier to learn, 
documentation is fantastic and you have a very good community.

Django, again has a fantastic documentation and tutorial. Even a Django 
book is being written. Has a very good community on IRC and google 
groups. Being Python based, it is very powerful in terms of the 
language. Makes it easy to create database using models ,and your 
database, python code or logic and the template/presentation layer is 
loosely coupled so that you gain more flexibility in handling each of 
them. It is well suited for faster production and deployment.

The best suggestion will be to select a few options and try a pilot 
module on them. Whichever seems to be more comfortable to you and whose 
results are more satisfactory can be taken up for the main project :)


-- 
With Regards

Parthan (TechnoFreak)

.   A Proud GNU/Linux User and Ubuntero
.0.
..0 [Web] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Parthan

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Sun Nov 19 09:56:13 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Sun Nov 19 09:56:52 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] choice of web development technology
In-Reply-To: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5d8c3fec0611180958s5e0d2c41tc8d11a89a9990e21@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <455FDCE5.6060203@gopalarathnam.com>

anantha narasimhan wrote:
> hey,
> 
> iam trying to build a web service. I tht i ss hd take a quick response
> from the community in choosing the technology. The project demands a
> good UI (planing to rope in ajax) and has  pretty complex
> datastructures to work with in the back end. The performance is also
> critical as its  traffic is going to be a bit high. which
> technology/framework/language would be best  for developing such an
> application.
> 

The most popular programming/scripting language best suited for the web 
is PHP.

Since your application might use a lot of exchanges back-and-forth 
between the browser and the web server (for AJAX) you can use JSON as 
the data interchange format.

Many high volume traffic web sites including Yahoo! are powered by PHP.

Rasmus Lerdorf, the creator of PHP, is here for FOSS.in and would be 
giving a talk on PHP5, you can put forth your questions to him.

-- 
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

http://gopalarathnam.com/

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sun Nov 19 18:56:46 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sun Nov 19 18:57:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Ubuntu 7.04 (Feisty Fawn) adds proprietary drivers in the
	base distro
In-Reply-To: <9acfbb0b0611190341k7b3a967bkc08f79c21d17110f@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9acfbb0b0611190341k7b3a967bkc08f79c21d17110f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45605B96.5060605@frodo.hserus.net>

I've added the relevant links from the story as footnotes

http://www.desktoplinux.com/news/NS7895189911.html

Ubuntu to add proprietary drivers
Nov. 17, 2006

Analysis -- Reluctantly, the Ubuntu developer community has decided that
with the next version of Ubuntu, Feisty Fawn, it will be including some
proprietary drivers. Feisty Fawn's emphasis on "multimedia enablement"
appears to be the culprit.

Feisty Fawn, aka Ubuntu 7.04, is scheduled for release on Apr. 19, 2007.
According to Mark Shuttleworth, Ubuntu's founder, "The main themes for
feature development in this release will be improvements to hardware
support in the laptop, desktop and high-end server market, and
aggressive adoption of emerging desktop technologies. Ubuntu's Feisty
release will put the spotlight on multimedia enablement and desktop
effects."

To accomplish, the Ubuntu developer community has decided that it must
use, for now at least, proprietary drivers.

It's not that Ubuntu's developers like proprietary drivers. The
developers felt [1] that given that, "A large proportion of people using
Ubuntu -- including 70%-80% of people with new computers -- need a
non-Free driver for reasonable performance from their graphics card,
wireless card, or modem, because there is no Free driver available, they
had little choice in the matter.

In particular, the Ubuntu developers are working on adding binary ATI
and NVIDA graphic card drivers to the distribution. This is because,
"Currently, Ubuntu does little to enable 3D acceleration [2] on cards
that support these features. Composite support is enabled by default on
X.Org since Ubuntu Edgy, but various video boards need specific options
to support either Composite or 3D acceleration correctly, or have them
explicitly disabled, in case these technologies are not supported."

So it is that Ubuntu has "chosen to install non-Free drivers by
default." Specifically, it has been decided that "Both NVIDIA and ATI
proprietary drivers will be installed by default, on Ubuntu Feisty."
That does not mean, however, that they will be enabled for all video
boards. For example, since ATI proprietary drivers do not support
Composite graphics, this "driver will only be enabled by default for
users whose video boards are not supported by the open source 'ati'
video driver."

In addition, work has started on bringing proprietary drivers into
Ubuntu for the so-called Win-modems (fritz isdn/dsl modules, lt-modem)
and the Atheros (ath_hal aka madwifi) and Intel 3945 Intel wireless
chipsets.

The developers are well aware of the problems with using these drivers.
For example, there are the simple technical problems that support for
the drivers is completely dependent on the hardware vendor. And, then,
when the vendor does make a bug fix, that "improvement" will require
careful testing, since the developers won't know what was changed in the
update. Of course, on top of that, there are the philosophical
objections to using binary drivers in Linux.

Many public comments about this decision object to Ubuntu's decision.
One writer [3] said, "We should not give up our freedom for a short term
advantage."

A public poll [4], on the Ubuntu forums, however, reveals far less
outrage and far more desktop pragmatism. As of the evening of Nov. 17,
on the question, "Should binary NVidia/ATI drivers be automatically
installed & activated in Ubuntu?," the answers were:

    * 32.62 percent -- "Yes, while informing the user of the relevant
issues, etc."
    * 54.63 percent -- "Users should be given a choice about this during
installation"
    * and only 12.75 percent voted for "No, such drivers can stay in a
non-free repo, just like now"

In any case, Ubuntu is moving forward with incorporating proprietary
drivers. At the same time, though, Ubuntu will be trying to educate
users about the issues around non-free drivers. The plan, now, is for
this to be done by "using a notification bubble on login, an extra
section in the Device Manager, and a CGI script on Ubuntu.com for
providing up-to-date information about alternative hardware."

Thus the goal is that while Ubuntu will be shipping "proprietary drivers
in the short term, we should take steps to improve the situation in the
long term. We believe the best way to do this is to convey the problem
to people using Ubuntu - explaining why we distribute non-Free drivers
at all, what the risks are, and what people can do to avoid such
hardware in future."


-- Steven J. Vaughan-Nichols

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/BinaryDriverEducation
[2] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/AcceleratedX
[3] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/AcceleratedX/Comments
[4] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/AcceleratedX/Comments
