Apologies for top posting :)

Personally, I would prefer to block bcc messages.  Since the mail 
transfer protocols seem to allow implicit addresses, it may not be easy 
to distinguish bcc from others.  Mailman handles bcc posts to the list 
correctly! I sent the text quoted below the quoted text as *bcc* to the 
list, and the response I got was:

<quote>
Your mail to 'ilugc' with the subject
    Re: [Ilugc] [OT] Suresh on news.com
Is being held until the list moderator can review it for approval.
The reason it is being held:
    Message has implicit destination
Either the message will get posted to the list, or you will receive
notification of the moderator's decision.  If you would like to cancel
this posting, please visit the following URL:

    
http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/confirm/ilugc/56d79e7de89e0b4cdf284927602ad62cf6c44db1

</quote>

Ramanraj K wrote:
> Creative Wolf wrote:
>> 2. Ramanraj's question made me ask something on the same lines. So,
>> does gmail deliver a genuine mail to ram[someone]@gmail to RamanRaj as
>> spam?
>> /cw
>> Conserve Internet; Transfer less? 
> Appears, the assumption in such cases would also be that I was 
> bcc'ed.  It would be better if the headers of the bcc'ed recepient 
> include "bcc: <recepient>" though the other recepients marked to and 
> cc obviously should not get the bcc headers. The headers of a mail I 
> received addressed to ramanson@gmail.com are attached - it does not 
> include "bcc: <recepient>@gmail.com" and that does cause some 
> confusion that may be avoided by a suitable header. As you say, there 
> is no point in this conservation, and a little more could be transferred.
>
> -Ramanraj K

> 
>    
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/confirm/ilugc/56d79e7de89e0b4cdf284927602ad62cf6c44db1
> 
> </quote>
> 
> Ramanraj K wrote:
> >Creative Wolf wrote:
> >>2. Ramanraj's question made me ask something on the same lines. So,
> >>does gmail deliver a genuine mail to ram[someone]@gmail to RamanRaj as
> >>spam?

Oops! You guys are going off on a completely different track!

Suresh should correct me but this is how I read things.

Firstly gmail's spam filtering is not representative of the current zeitgeist in spam filtering. Well gmail does a pretty good job but that does not mean that we should learn about spam control only from gmail. :)

Now, mailman has nothing to do with this. Mailman can be configured to either allow unregistered mail ids to post or disallow.

ILUGC disallows and hence Ramanraj's mail got rejected. Whether it is in bcc or CC or To does not matter.

Let us focus on spam filtering now.

If you were gmail how would you know if a mail addressed to ram@gmail.com is not addressed to Ramanraj as well?

Heck, what has the mistyping of e-mail IDs got to do with this?

Nothing. 

If the address is in bcc the mail will come.

Spam filtering happens mostly in the body in these cases.

It looks at the content rather than the headers.

Header based spam filtering happens during mail delivery and acceptance.

So if the body is not suspect or if Bayesian and Markovian filtering does not throw up high scores mail is delivered.

Just wait for my slides for the gory details. I shall send them tomorrow. ;)

regards,
Girish

Hi,

I have updated http://freeshell.in/~ramanraj/ with a couple of short 
stories that make use of unicode Tamil encoding.
[1] ????? http://freeshell.in/~ramanraj/arivu.pdf
[2] ????? ????????? ???????? 
http://freeshell.in/~ramanraj/arivu_good_or_bad.pdf

The short stories are styled after typical Tamil magazine fare.  ????? - 
"Arivu" - means "sense" in Tamil, and  a common name among Tamils.  The 
first story is actually a very short HOWTO install gNewSense distro on a 
new system.  There are only three characters - Arivu, our hero, his 
friend Kalai (means "art") and Kumar - the "kid" who fancies proprietary 
software.  ????? ????????? ????????  is about the anxiety of Arivu to 
share information about his new system with a nearby school. I am 
working on splitting it into two stories to avoid crowding and focus 
more on the content relating to free software. ????? ????????? based on 
explaining things about the Wikipedia is on the way.  Ultimately, if 
enough number of Arivu stories get written, it could be compiled into 
Arivayanam - The journey of Arivu :)

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Nov 21 15:04:46 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Nov 21 15:05:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Great tip for avoiding spelling mistakes in vim
Message-ID: <20061121093446.GA8887@lakshmi.susmita.org>

Hi brothers and sisters,
   
   I chanced upon an excellent idea to avoid typos in emails.

   Typos give a very bad impression about us and I usually find that I make typos due to keyboard sensitivity problem or speed of typing though I do sometimes misspell too.

   This works only if you are using vim+mutt. :)

   So please gmail web users and emacs users excuse me.

   Though I have several ways by which I can invoke spell checking inside vim or mutt, I still prefer runtime highlighting ala MS Word.
   
   This is what you have to do for that.

   Just drop this line in your ~/.vimrc.

   :setl spell spelllang=en_us

   And now onwards you can easily sound erudite and impeccable. 

   What to speak of the wonders of modern technology?

   (Of course there are so many mistakes this thing can't catch, no substitute to "sraddha" of course :)

love,
Girish

Hi Folks , 

The Boss team is proud to announce the Beta Release of BOSS Gnu/Linux codenamed "Tarang". The Beta Release introduces 3 different cd's ,

1. Live CD
2. Install CD
3. Add On CD 

BOSS Gnu/Linux is a Linux distribution for your desktop , with a fast and easy install, a tight selection of excellent packages installed by default, every other package you can imagine available from the
network, and professional technical support from Boss Team.

BOSS Gnu/Linux is one among the four distros which are LSB 3.1 certified.

To Get BOSS Gnu/Linux Beta
---------------------------

Download BOSS Gnu/Linux Beta here 

 http://nrcfoss.org.in/boss



About BOSS Gnu/Linux Beta
--------------------------

To see it all, you'll need to try the CD, but the highlights 
include:

  * The Graphical mode installer

  * Faster system startup and login

  * Simplified menu organization

  * Easy access to power management settings with GNOME Power Manager

  * Improved support for video playback

  * GNOME 2.14
 
  * 3d desktop Eyecandy with Beryl and AIGLX

  * BharatheeyaaOO (A localised openoffice.org 2.0.1 ? currently Tamil and Hindi) 

  * X.org 7.1
  
  * Enhanced Removable Media Support
  
  * Liferea ? RSS/RDF Reader
  
  * Plug & Play of the devices with Graphical Front-End.
  
  * Multimedia support ? Totem, Xmms

  * TV Tuner Support ? xawtv 
 
  * Bluetooth Support 
 
  * Optional NetworkManager for convenient roaming between different
    wireless and wired networks

  * Migration Tool -  Bulk Document converter

  * Presentation Tool  - keyjnote

  * Menu Editor ? Alacarte

  * Evolution Mail Client

  * Best of available internet tools ? Firefox, Gaim, Xchat, Gnome meeting

  * Input Method ? SCIM with Remington Keyboard Layout for Tamil, Hindi, Punjabi,         Marati

  * CD/DVD Burning tool ? bonfire

 
?Under the hood? 

  * gcc 4.1.1
  
  * g++ 4.1.2

  * glibc 2.3.6

  * linux 2.6.17-2

  
As always, BOSS includes the very best of the 100% Free / Libre application software world, and each new release incorporates countless new features and bugfixes from the development Team.



Feedback and Helping
--------------------

Your comments and suggestions will help turn this Beta into the best release of BOSS ever.If you would like to help shape BOSS,mail us at nrcfoss@cdac.in

 
If you have a question, or if you think you may have found a bug but aren't sure, first try asking on the #boss-Nrcfoss IRC channel on FreeNode, or mail us at  nrcfoss@cdac.in
 

More Information
----------------

You can find out more about BOSS and about this preview release on 
our website, IRC channel and wiki. Please
visit:

       http://nrcfoss.org.in

       http://nrcfoss.org.in/boss

       
with warm Regards

Chandu
BOSS Gnu/Linux Developer

On Tue, Nov 21, 2006 at 04:10:16PM +0530, km wrote:
> How abt this plugin ? 
> http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=465

There seem to be others too , I had downloaded a spell.vim file.

The idea is not being able to check spelling, I know that gmail has that.

But it is that of showing misspelt words in a non obtrusive but at the same time useful manner.

If you have to click the "check spelling" link every time , then if you are like me you might forget.

I remember clearly mentioning in my mail that I know several ways to invoke it from both vim and mutt.

The idea is not being able to do it but forcing you to do it. :)

To me at least that makes all the difference...

Anyway thanks for all the inputs. 

regards,
Girish

From vprajan at gmail.com  Tue Nov 21 18:05:13 2006
From: vprajan at gmail.com (Pushparajan V)
Date: Tue Nov 21 18:05:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Query about daemons
In-Reply-To: <20061121050524.8232.qmail@web36811.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061121050524.8232.qmail@web36811.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <d6e7f37f0611210435r5bcefb5eq544847dea465b1b6@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/21/06, Amit Dey <eamitdey@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> I have create a simple daemon ( referred to Linux HowTo on recommendation
> of some of you guys ).


You need to write a small shell script to start and run ur daemon.. This
shell script must be putted in /etc/init.d/ and then soft link
/etc/init.d/<ur-script> to the prefered runlevels in /etc/rc.d/runlevels.

Refer already existing scripts in /etc/init.d for creating an advanced
startup script..


  Anyway I would like to know how do i configure my system such that the
> daemon is started automatically when the system starts...Will i have to edit
> /etc/profile file or is there some other


/etc/profile is used for user-level startup programs (executed after user
logins). As u said, it is a daemon, this may not apply to ur case.

method
>
>   Thanks a lot.
>

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Nov 21 18:12:31 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Nov 21 18:12:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Nor Flash maintaince in Linux 2.6
In-Reply-To: <15C2CAD382CB69409395ED4F159BED701D2076@mail.esntechnologies.co.in>
Message-ID: <982790.89102.qm@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- "Srinivas G." <srinivasg@esntechnologies.co.in>
wrote:
> Before porting Linux, I wanted to know whether any
> tool available on
> Linux for compacting and maintaining optimal life of
> my NOR flash?

That is a hardware limitation. Flash memory has a
finite number of erase-write cycles.

The only thing you can do in software is use
power-management and suspend the card. But, that
doesn't nullify the hardware limitation.

http://lxr.linux.no/source/drivers/mmc/mmc.c?v=2.6.11#L887

SK

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Nov 21 20:04:24 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Nov 21 20:04:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Nor Flash maintaince in Linux 2.6
In-Reply-To: <20061121134646.GA6839@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <453185.82776.qm@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Girish Venkatachalam
<girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> 	Most estimates on life getting over and all 
> that are bogus.

Please don't give incorrect information. 

Most flash memories will fail after 100,000 read/write
cycles.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_memory

Choosing an appropriate flash filesystem that can
handle read/writes effectively can only optimize the
minimum number of read/writes, thereby extending the
use.

"The life of the device depends on the number of erase
cycles guaranteed by the flash vendor, and the
frequency with which each specific group of sectors is
updated."

http://www.mil-embedded.com/articles/authors/spanjer/

> Y wud u have a ramdisk on embedded systems?

If you don't want the user to screw up the flash or
when you don't have secondary storage other than
flash, you want to use a ramdisk mounted in RAM as a
filesystem.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From mohan.tux at gmail.com  Tue Nov 21 20:47:20 2006
From: mohan.tux at gmail.com (Mohan Sundaram)
Date: Tue Nov 21 20:47:37 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Nor Flash maintaince in Linux 2.6
In-Reply-To: <453185.82776.qm@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <453185.82776.qm@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <45631880.8050307@gmail.com>

Shakthi Kannan wrote:

>> Y wud u have a ramdisk on embedded systems?
> 
> If you don't want the user to screw up the flash or
> when you don't have secondary storage other than
> flash, you want to use a ramdisk mounted in RAM as a
> filesystem.
> 
> SK
Very much so. This relieves the flash from being used for writes of 
temporary data (not required across reboots)

This enables the feature of being able to change configs and revert back 
to original by reboot if the config not committed. A very common 
expectation, deliverable and method in embedded systems. If one were to 
do this on flash, complex config rollback systems have to be built.

Mohan

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Nov 21 21:20:58 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Nov 21 21:21:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Nor Flash maintaince in Linux 2.6
In-Reply-To: <20061121153504.GA24058@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <20061121155059.68900.qmail@web50212.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Girish Venkatachalam
<girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> If you choose the right file systems and use flash
> memory it will not fail.

What you are saying is like, even if an ethernet cable
gets cut somewhere in the middle, the TCP/IP packets
will still flow through it. Software depends/runs on
hardware. 

Filesystem is software. Flash memory is hardware.
Irrespective of what filesystem or software you use,
after 100,000 read/write cycles flash memory _will_
fail. Period.

--- "Mohan Sundaram" <mohan.tux@gmail.com> wrote:
> If one were to 
> do this on flash, complex config rollback systems 
> have to be built.

You can use a hardware debugger like Lauterbach to
restore the flash images back to the NOR flash through
JTAG. 

SK

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Tue Nov 21 23:18:03 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Tue Nov 21 23:18:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Nor Flash maintaince in Linux 2.6
In-Reply-To: <15C2CAD382CB69409395ED4F159BED701D2076@mail.esntechnologies.co.in>
References: <15C2CAD382CB69409395ED4F159BED701D2076@mail.esntechnologies.co.in>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310611210948s250c7cc7x7b739ee1f870ae02@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/21/06, Srinivas G. <srinivasg@esntechnologies.co.in> wrote:
> Before porting Linux, I wanted to know whether any tool available on
> Linux for compacting and maintaining optimal life of my NOR flash?

Tools can't improve the life of a flash but there are best practices
you can follow to improve the overall lifetime. All hardwares are
expected to fail one day and for flash with limited number of
write/erase cycle bad planning can cause premature demise of the
product:
- Use file systems specifically designed for flash, like JFFS2 - they
distribute write cycles and manage the available space in a better way
than with other file systems.
- NOR chips are XIP capable and can be mapped to be the boot device,
in which case, the first few sectors are used for bootup making them
critical and should not be often erased - You can implement modular
bootup - have a very small and very robust 0th stage boot loader at
the first few sectors. The only job of this stage will be to bootstrap
the 1st stage loader. you can deploy redundant 1st stage loaders.
- You can partition your flash and have different filesystems on them.
For eg: the firmware can be on cramfs and the configurations on jffs2.

-- 
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/
http://vijairaj.blogspot.com/

> are any other apps running (browser, mail client, any open documents
> etc) besides it, the system will come to a crawl if you frequently
> switch between apps.

I don't remember what I did with eclipse running all alone! All I did
with eclipse was some servlet related work deployed onto tomcat and
occasionally run in a browser to verify if it is all right.  Now this
requires that you have eclipse, tomcat and at least one web browser
running simultaneously.

There are some things you can do. There is a browser that can run from
within eclipse. This browser may not do flash and video but can do all
that a servlet needs to show! In fact now I am running eclipse, laszlo
presentation server and firefox 2.0 all side by side and only now am I
seeing real crawls.

-- 
Regards,

Abishek Goda
http://goda.abishek.googlepages.com
From ajitk at email.com  Wed Nov 22 10:09:06 2006

Hello,

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Wed Nov 22 10:44:00 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Wed Nov 22 10:48:06 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] DeskJet D2360
In-Reply-To: <4563D46A.4020500@email.com>
References: <4563D46A.4020500@email.com>
Message-ID: <4563DC98.20601@gmail.com>

Ajit Natarajan wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> Has anyone successfully printed from Linux to an HP DeskJet D2360, with 
> or without HPLIP?
> 
> In either case, CUPS shows the print job as having completed 
> successfully but the printer doesn't print anything.
> 
> (Printer works fine with Windows, so it is not a printer issue.)
> 
> FC5, kernel 2.6.18, CUPS 1.2.6, HPLIP 1.6.6a.
> 
> For configuration, log files, etc, see my post to the CUPS list:
> http://cups.org/newsgroups.php?s11055+gcups.general+v11061+T0

Checking out with the HP website for Printer Product Overview, the 
product is said to be compatible with Win and Mac. This is the reason 
your printer is said to be working with Win (availability of driver 
support in the corresponding web site).

http://www.shopping.hp.com/webapp/shopping/store_access.do?template_type=product_detail&product_code=C9079A%23B1H&jumpid=oc_R1002_USENC-001_HP%20Deskjet%20D2360%20Printer&lang=en&cc=us

But, am afraid it was the same for printers which I had worked with 
GNU/Linux.

Even my now obsolete 3325 Deskjet doesn't have GNU/Linux driver support 
in the HP web site, but I have no problem in using it in both my Laptop 
(Ubunty Dapper/Edgy) as well as my home system, FC4 and Kubuntu.

You can try with some generic drivers or the closest HP driver available 
in your system. I have run printers satisfactorily with generic drivers, 
especially those printers from TVS. So, HP shouldn't be a problem.

-- 
With Regards

Parthan (TechnoFreak)

.0.

Parthan,

Thank you for your response.

Actually, HP does have printer support for Linux.  Take a look at:

http://h71028.www7.hp.com/enterprise/cache/321119-0-0-0-121.html?jumpid=reg_R1002_USEN

(I hope this URL is persistent.)

HPLIP [1] is sponsored by HP.  And LinuxPrinting.org states that the 
D2300 series is ``mostly supported'' by HPIJS and HPLIP [2].  I presume 
this means that something can be printed from Linux to this printer.

[1] http://hplip.sourceforge.net
[2] http://linuxprinting.org/show_printer.cgi?recnum=HP-DeskJet_D2300

The problem seems to be that the OS and the application think that the 
print job completed successfully, but the printer does nothing.

Ajit
From solar345 at gmail.com  Wed Nov 22 12:55:46 2006
From: solar345 at gmail.com (Antano Solar)
Date: Wed Nov 22 12:55:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Ubuntu installation -min configuration
In-Reply-To: <70106e0b0611211907t311e5a4l2bedc93abe8cb4be@mail.gmail.com>
References: <e24507ef0611202009l53bfb46dw8097667cb9073777@mail.gmail.com>
	<9bdf087b0611202343t5489f397s667c75c50d61a155@mail.gmail.com>
	<70106e0b0611210130v31db06cere56d3d232d35f8bc@mail.gmail.com>
	<9bdf087b0611210639v155bced2m1c350d16bcef6c8@mail.gmail.com>
	<70106e0b0611211907t311e5a4l2bedc93abe8cb4be@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <b2600ec40611212325m62df552cx6e9c07ab646bf42d@mail.gmail.com>

The easiest way to verify if you need more ram or not is to check your
swap usage , with and without the software under testing -- eclipse in
your case -- if more swap space or any at is being used , its
definitely a sign that you need more ram.

And webservers also need to be optimized to uses less ram , I had an
issue where once 25 instances of apache was running , checked using ps
aux | grep apache  ,
and each was taking around 1.4% mem . tweaking the serverfreed a lot of memory.

Genreally rule of thumb is , if swap space used is more than a few
Mb(on regualr desktops) , you need more ram.

my static ip: 61.17.191.15( i configured this ip in router)

my linux box ip

eth1:197.168.1.150(assigned by me)


i am using squid proxy for other client machine, and dansguardian for url
filtering.

everything is working fine, but i want to do one more thing,

my client machine using jboss in 197.168.1.150:8080 , but i want to redirect
this to 61.17.191.15:8080, i tried some port forwarding with iptables but it
wont work properly, if any body knows how to redirect pls guide me.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Nov 22 14:43:30 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

Subject: [Ilugc] port forwarding
In-Reply-To: <89ef002c0611220109v399b0428o9f53c15bfe402531@mail.gmail.com>

Dont set anything outside 10/8, 192.168/16 and 172.16/12 on your LAN

> this to 61.17.191.15:8080, i tried some port forwarding with iptables
> but it
> wont work properly, if any body knows how to redirect pls guide me.

What did you try that doesnt work properly. Please be specific

And renumber your LAN so that the 197.whatever is 10.1.whatever, or
192.168.2.whatever
From mohan.tux at gmail.com  Wed Nov 22 15:43:04 2006
From: mohan.tux at gmail.com (Mohan Sundaram)
Date: Wed Nov 22 15:43:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] port forwarding
In-Reply-To: <89ef002c0611220109v399b0428o9f53c15bfe402531@mail.gmail.com>
References: <89ef002c0611220109v399b0428o9f53c15bfe402531@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <456422B0.3070802@gmail.com>

amal g wrote:
> Hi Friends
> 
> 
> After a long time i am sending this req to lug
> 
> 
> my static ip: 61.17.191.15( i configured this ip in router)
> 
> my linux box ip
> eth0:192.168.1.150(getting from router)
> 
> eth1:197.168.1.150(assigned by me)
> 
> 
> i am using squid proxy for other client machine, and dansguardian for url
> filtering.
> 
> everything is working fine, but i want to do one more thing,
> 
> my client machine using jboss in 197.168.1.150:8080 , but i want to 
> redirect
> this to 61.17.191.15:8080, i tried some port forwarding with iptables 
> but it
> wont work properly, if any body knows how to redirect pls guide me.
> 
Packets that come from router to Linux eth0 will not have 61.17.191.15 
as destination IP. You'll need to do the DNAT on the router and not the 
Linux box. Also the router must have a route to that host if it is not 
in the subnet of te internal interface of the router.

In case you want to retain the flexibility of maintaining it on the 
Linux box, DNAT on router to Linux eth0 IP and on Linux box DNAT to the 
internal LAN m/c IP. Then the route may (if not in the same subnet as 
any of the interfaces) neeeded on the Linux box and not the router.

Mohan

Hi,
About 13 months back I bought a Laptop(Dell Inspiron 6000).
It had been using the cutom installed Windows XP (home edition).
It has the Samsung MP0603H harddisk.

Around 6 months ago, I wanted to experiement with various distributions of
Linux. I had only the single partion(factory made) and therefore I did not
want to lose data/disturb windows. So I used systemRescue CD(dowloaded
from internet) to resize the existing C: and created my own partions and
installed Linux. Things were working fine.

Around 20 days ago, I wanted to resize the partitions So, I used
SystemRescue CD again. While it was deleting a partion(I have chosen to do
it), I accidentally rebooted it. From then on my harddisk is showing bad
sectors and the number of bad sectors grow day by day.

This is shown by chkdsk command in windows.

I am not too technical savvy to identify if it is a software
problem(Unknowingly/for some weired reason it is marking as bad sector) OR
really the disk itself had physically gone bad.

If any one knows any solution to rectify the problem(Removing the bad
sectors - if it is a software problem) please let me know. I do not like
the temporary fix of keep on marking more and more bad sectors and
continue working till it totally crashes one day.

Since the warranty got over just a month ago I dont think Dell will repair
or replace my hard disk. I saw the web site of Samsung for hard disk. It
also shows the warranty is for one year only.

Any suggestion/advice is most welcome.

P.S: It is a technical problem, so please dont say throw up windows Or
start flame wars. I have become allergic to the smoke of these flame
wars nowadays. ;)
Also I dont like to buy a new hard disk if there is some
way to resolve the present harddisk technical problem.

Thanks & Regards,

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Thu Nov 23 07:22:58 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Thu Nov 23 07:23:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] how can i boost up my net connection
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611221303n10a10290x12dee4357d44e40@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611221303n10a10290x12dee4357d44e40@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4564FEFA.9030404@frodo.hserus.net>

Zico wrote:

> 
> I got a broadband connection yesterday. But actually i am not at least
> satisfied with that`s speed. My speed is 10Mbps. How can boost up my
> browsing speed and also download speed? I think there are some hackers here
> in this group.
> 

10 mbps is the speed between your PC's ethernet cable and the broadband
router.

If you get a 256k broadband connection, that's the maximum speed (you'd
get an average 18..20 kbps download speed with that one)

From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Nov 23 09:04:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] - Hard disk - Win - Linux problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0611212112440.24222@chi.spunge.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0611212112440.24222@chi.spunge.org>
Message-ID: <20061123033424.GA14634@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Nov 22, 2006 at 07:08:56AM -0600, carti wrote:
> Hi,
> About 13 months back I bought a Laptop(Dell Inspiron 6000).
> It had been using the cutom installed Windows XP (home edition).
> It has the Samsung MP0603H harddisk.
> 
> Around 6 months ago, I wanted to experiement with various distributions of
> Linux. I had only the single partion(factory made) and therefore I did not
> want to lose data/disturb windows. So I used systemRescue CD(dowloaded
> from internet) to resize the existing C: and created my own partions and
> installed Linux. Things were working fine.
> 
> Around 20 days ago, I wanted to resize the partitions So, I used
> SystemRescue CD again. While it was deleting a partion(I have chosen to do
> it), I accidentally rebooted it. From then on my harddisk is showing bad
> sectors and the number of bad sectors grow day by day.
> 
> This is shown by chkdsk command in windows.
> 
> I am not too technical savvy to identify if it is a software
> problem(Unknowingly/for some weired reason it is marking as bad sector) OR
> really the disk itself had physically gone bad.
> 
> If any one knows any solution to rectify the problem(Removing the bad
> sectors - if it is a software problem) please let me know. I do not like
> the temporary fix of keep on marking more and more bad sectors and
> continue working till it totally crashes one day.
> 
> Since the warranty got over just a month ago I dont think Dell will repair
> or replace my hard disk. I saw the web site of Samsung for hard disk. It
> also shows the warranty is for one year only.
> 
> Any suggestion/advice is most welcome.

Bad sectors mean your hard disk is dying / dead.

There are several ways by which to recover your data but if I were you I will trash the disk and buy a spanking new SATA...

Believe me SATA is really really fast and cool.

Did you know that hard disk performance determines your general responsiveness? 
> 
> P.S: It is a technical problem, so please dont say throw up windows Or
> start flame wars. I have become allergic to the smoke of these flame
> wars nowadays. ;)

Nobody likes that anyway. :)

Don't worry!
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Nov 23 09:08:17 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Nov 23 09:08:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] how can i boost up my net connection
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611221303n10a10290x12dee4357d44e40@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611221303n10a10290x12dee4357d44e40@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061123033817.GB14634@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 23, 2006 at 03:03:49AM +0600, Zico wrote:
> Hi all!
> 
> I got a broadband connection yesterday. But actually i am not at least
> satisfied with that`s speed. My speed is 10Mbps. How can boost up my
> browsing speed and also download speed? I think there are some hackers here
> in this group.

Zico,

	Why are you not satisfied? Your speed is mostly dependent on the quality of your phone line. 

	You can eliminate software bottlenecks but not work around basic laws of physics...

	So first figure out what speed you deserve and see if you are getting it. If not call up the service provider and bug them.

	I am very satisfied with the speed I get, so I have not researched into caching and other forms of web acceleration.

	For me stability of the link is more important.

	ADSL is rock solid. No two ways about it.

	In the recent rains and storm or whatever I had power problem, but never an Internet outage!

	Kudos to BSNL! :)

regards,
Girish

you can always insure your laptop - it is just 2% (when i last  
looked) per year. You can also insure your other equipment once the  
warranty is over. Insurance of hardware is cheap - it is only  
insurance against data loss that is expensive.

further details you can refer the man page of ln.

From ajitk at email.com  Thu Nov 23 13:39:56 2006
From: ajitk at email.com (Ajit Natarajan)
Date: Thu Nov 23 13:40:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: DeskJet D2360
Message-ID: <45655754.7040103@email.com>

Ajit Natarajan wrote:
 > Has anyone successfully printed from Linux to an HP DeskJet D2360,
 > with or without HPLIP?

Sorry for responding to myself, but I thought others would be interested 
in the resolution.

I worked with Aaron Albright of the HPLIP team on this issue.  Turns out 
that the CUPS web interface that I had used to configure the printer 
used a PPD file that did not correspond to the printer.  The correct 
file was missing on my FC5 system.  Not sure why.

I downloaded the correct PPD file from linuxprinting.org, deleted all 
print queues, and used the downloaded PPD file to configure the printer 
using the HPLIP hp-setup utility.  It started working fine after that.

Thanks.

Ajit

I'm not too sure on this, but then tagging the subject with COMMERCIAL 
since Oracle isn't free software[1].

I've installed Oracle 10g Express Edition on my laptop running Ubuntu, 
the installation is pretty straight-forward (sudo dpkg -i).  There are a 
whole bunch of docs on setting up and configuring Oracle on their 
developer web site.

Now for the question that Kenneth asked, any reasons for choosing Oracle 
over PostgreSQL or MySQL 5.x?

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Thu Nov 23 16:38:47 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Thu Nov 23 16:39:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sed pattern match doubt
In-Reply-To: <20061123095822.71965.qmail@web54111.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20061123095822.71965.qmail@web54111.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <4565813F.3000103@gopalarathnam.com>

Ashok Antony wrote:
> hi all
> 
> what this pattern match does ?
> 
> sed -e :a -e '/\\$/N; s/\\\n//; ta' -e '/th width/d' 
> 

Read sed(1)

Basically when it finds backslash (\) at the end of the line, reads the 
next line (the N does that), and deletes the backslash from input.

Also, for any occurrence of "th width" in input, the entire line is deleted.

To be more clear, the following input:

this is line 1 \
this is another line
this is a line containing "th input"

would produce:

this is line 1 this is another line

-- 
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

http://gopalarathnam.com/

prashanth wrote:
> i installed FC5 in a AMD turion compaq laptop, mouse is working good
> but i cant able to see the mouse pointer.

probably some option like swcursor / hwcursor etc?

better try reconfiguring X a bit ..

X -configure > /root/xorg.conf

Compare that with your current xorg.conf and make appropriate changes,
add in higher resolutions that your video card supports etc.

> > satisfied with that`s speed. My speed is 10Mbps. How can boost up my
> > browsing speed and also download speed? I think there are some hackers
> here
> > in this group.
>
> Zico,
>
>         Why are you not satisfied? Your speed is mostly dependent on the
> quality of your phone line.
>
>         You can eliminate software bottlenecks but not work around basic
> laws of physics...
>
>         So first figure out what speed you deserve and see if you are
> getting it. If not call up the service provider and bug them.
>
>         I am very satisfied with the speed I get, so I have not researched
> into caching and other forms of web acceleration.
>
>         For me stability of the link is more important.
>
>         ADSL is rock solid. No two ways about it.
>
>         In the recent rains and storm or whatever I had power problem, but
> never an Internet outage!
>
>         Kudos to BSNL! :)
>
> regards,
> Girish

dictionary.

but some may even convey the meaning better than the English term :-) bear

From brucemathew at gmail.com  Fri Nov 24 09:10:23 2006
From: brucemathew at gmail.com (Bruce Mathew)
Date: Fri Nov 24 09:37:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Conference on FOSS in SCIENCE
In-Reply-To: <1c81e6720611012233w6b0e0318xed6ff5c681fb0cb7@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1c81e6720611012233w6b0e0318xed6ff5c681fb0cb7@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1c81e6720611231940n4d89b35cgfd8c28a78ccc9966@mail.gmail.com>

Dear and Respected Friends

Union Christian College,Alwaye, Kerala in collaboration with SPACE, TVM and
Free Software Foundation of India [ FSFI ]is organising a 3-day Conference
on FOSS in Science which focus on the concept of FOSS and its relevance in
Science Subjects. The college has started a FOSS Cell to make aware about
FOSS and its Potentials to the academia. This is a new venture of our
College.

The Conference on FOSS in SCIENCE covers aspects like
1. Knowledge management & Free Software
2. Scientific Computing and Data Visualisation using Python
3. Advanced Modelling
4. Experimental Physics with Phoenix
5. Scientific Research with LaTex
6. Free Software Tools
7. Colloborative development, Social Networking and Informal education
8. Colloborative development with CVS
9. Free Software for Mathematics.


Eminent Resource Persons like Dr Nagarjuna [ TIFR, Mumbai ], Dr.
Prabhu Ramachandran [ IIT Bombay], Dr. Manoj Warrier [ Institute of
Plasma Research, Gandhinagar] Dr. E Krishnan [ Kerala University ],
Dr. V Sasikumar [ CESS ]
etc has confirmed their participation.

Prof. C N Krishnan [ Director , NRCFOSS ] will deliver the  key note
address.

Those interested to participate in this workshop, please feel free to
go thorugh the Workshop website www.space-kerala.org/fsc.
Hope this will be a succesfull venture

--
Mr. Bruce Mathew
Lecturer - Placement Officer
MCA Dept.
Union Christian College
Aluva 683102
www.mcaucc.org

From ganeshpulsars at gmail.com  Fri Nov 24 12:30:25 2006
From: ganeshpulsars at gmail.com (M.Ganesh)
Date: Fri Nov 24 12:37:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Internet through TATA Indicom dial-up
Message-ID: <001d01c70f96$4255d1a0$4400a8c0@ganesh>

Hi All,

I am relatively new to Linux

I am unable to browse using tata-indicom dial-up connection in my linux box

I am on debian 3.1 and using LG LSP 340E handset with serial interface cable
connected to /dev/ttyS0. I am logged in as root.

Initially tried the following script for connecting
------------8><--------------------
#!/bin/bash
echo "user internet password internet" > $HOME/.ppprc
pppd /dev/ttyS0 115200 debug usepeerdns defaultroute noauth connect
'/usr/sbin/chat -v "" at+crm=1 OK "atdt#777" CONNECT' mtu 264
------------8><--------------------

and this for disconnecting :

------------8><--------------------
#!/bin/bash
killall -9 pppd
------------8><--------------------

The connection goes through as can be seen on the phone display (Tx-9.6
Rx-9.6 etc), but the browsers (Firefox 2.0 and konqueror) say page not found
for any page I try to access. Disconnection script works.

I harvested the DNS entries from my windows box (203.197.12.30 and
202.54.6.50) and entered them in /etc/resolv.conf. However when the
connection goes through the values get overwritten with 203.197.12.30 and
202.54.1.18

ifconfig -a gives the following (apart from entries for eth0 and loopback)

------------8><--------------------
ppp0      Link encap:Point-to-Point Protocol
          inet addr:219.64.64.25  P-t-P:172.23.128.87  Mask:255.255.255.255
          UP POINTOPOINT RUNNING NOARP MULTICAST  MTU:264  Metric:1
          RX packets:7 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:6 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0
          RX bytes:164 (164.0 b)  TX bytes:107 (107.0 b)
------------8><--------------------

Then I installed wvdial and invoked it after adding the following section in
/etc/wvdial.conf
------------8><--------------------
[Dialer tata]
Modem = /dev/ttyS0
Baud = 115200
SetVolume=0
Dial Command = ATDT
Init1 = ATZ
Init2 = AT+CRM=1L3
FlowControl = Hardware (CRTSCTS)
ISDN = 0
Phone = #777
Username = internet
Password = internet
Stupid Mode = 1
------------8><--------------------

Then even the connection is not going through

Kindly help.

P.S : Sorry for the looooooooong post.

Regards Ganesh

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Nov 24 13:13:32 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Nov 24 13:13:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] how can i boost up my net connection
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611221303n10a10290x12dee4357d44e40@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611221303n10a10290x12dee4357d44e40@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611232343q1db3796an3c0f0092752b465b@mail.gmail.com>

On 22/11/06, Zico <mailzico@gmail.com> wrote:
> I got a broadband connection yesterday. But actually i am not at least
> satisfied with that`s speed. My speed is 10Mbps. How can boost up my
> browsing speed and also download speed?

Your speed is 10Mbps between your PC and the broadband router, but
beyond the router it is only what you have signed up for (64kbps? 128
kbps? whatever).

If you are using Firefox, I can suggest two extensions that will
improve your online experience considerably:

- Fasterfox. Tunes certain Firefox configuration settings to improve downloading
- Adblock. Lets you selectively disable portions of websites (mainly
for ads, especially flash ads etc.). It will take time to  build your
own block list, but there are several pre-built block lists available.

Binand
From carti at chi.spunge.org  Fri Nov 24 13:14:26 2006
From: carti at chi.spunge.org (carti)
Date: Fri Nov 24 13:14:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Solved - [OT] - Hard disk - Win - Linux problem
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0611240139500.4787@chi.spunge.org>

Hi all,
thank you very much for the suggestions given.

I somehow resolved the bad sector problem.

What I did was,
I used the same SystemRescue CD and deleted all the partitions(ntfs,
fat32 and ext3). Then created the ntfs partitions and linux partitions
using the SystemRescue CD. Then formatted those partitions using the same
SystemRecue CD. Then installed the Windows XP and the Ubuntu linux 5.10
(Dual boot).

Now the SamSung MP0603H 60 GB Harddisk seems to work fine. When I
installed Windows, and when it ran scandisk I guess it thoroughly checked
for bad sectors. It did not report to have any bad sectors. Same is the
case with Linux. It also did not report any bad sectors.

So Hopefully those were not really bad sectors and only a software
problem/mis-understanding of windows of what SystemRescue did when I
accidentally rebooted when systemRescue was working.

Hope this helps some one at sometime.

Thanks & regards
carti

From ramanraj.k at gmail.com  Sat Nov 25 06:06:34 2006
From: ramanraj.k at gmail.com (Bhuvaneswari)
Date: Sat Nov 25 06:05:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] A few bits on corruption ...
Message-ID: <45679012.80801@gmail.com>

I have been a long time fan of John Walker's http://fourmilab.ch site. 
When I recently checked it, a few new pages had come up:
[1] The funniest thing I have read in recent times is about this source 
of "corruption":
http://www.fourmilab.ch/documents/corrupted_downloads/
[2] John Walker has released the source code for the "Home Planet"  
program (VC++).  This program is in the public domain, and if anyone 
could release a suitable Gnu/Linux version of it, that would be nice.  
The windows binaries of Home Planet  released and found at the site 
could be used with wine. More info at http://www.fourmilab.ch/homeplanet/

-Ramanraj K

On 25/11/06, Sivanandhan, P. <apsivam@gmail.com> wrote:
> do you claim companies like Yahoo!, HP, Deutsche Bank, Lucent
> Technologies are not interested in security?

Providing names of four PHP-using companies doesn't prove anything. I
can list several thousand companies out there which don't use PHP for
each name you throw in (at least, not in an obvious way). What does it
prove? Nothing.

And yes, it can be argued that these companies are not interested in
security. Or that they all have invested in sufficient manpower and
technology to offset the risks of using PHP. In either case, the
investment required to support a secure environment running PHP code
doesn't justify using the language for web application development.

Binand

On 25-Nov-06, at 2:56 PM, Sivanandhan, P. wrote:

>> investment required to support a secure environment running PHP code
>> doesn't justify using the language for web application development.
>>
>> Binand
>
> If you argue this way I can argue nothing in computers or even life is
> secure, *do nothing and be safe*.

it is a fact that to write a fairly secure web application with php  
you need an exceptionaly skilled programmer - and if you want proof  
of that, look at the websites of any php application and count the  
number of security alerts/patches. Compare with python applications -  
django, for example, does not have a security page at all and has had  
*one* minor security alert in the past 4 years. And this alert only  
affected about three svn revisions and not the released code, nor the  
svn trunk.

On 25/11/06, Sivanandhan, P. <apsivam@gmail.com> wrote:
> Come on Binand I expect more from you not just a vulnerability list.
> Linux kernel has bugs Mozilla Firefox has bugs Perl has, Java has...
>
> The link you provided *mostly* lists vulnerabilities of web
> application developed using PHP. Technically they belongs to those web
> application not PHP.

I did mention the link was a starting point. For comparison, PHP has
1943 matches, Perl has 101, Python 18 and Ruby 10.

Why is it that the vast majority of PHP applications have
vulnerabilities? For example, scan the PHP list - see how many "remote
file inclusion" vulnerabilities are there? Can you find any in Perl
programs? The reason for this is the vastly overdesigned PHP fopen()
function/allow_url_fopen. Or the myriad of problems associated with
register_globals. I can go on about this.

Binand

On 11/25/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 25/11/06, Sivanandhan, P. <apsivam@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Come on Binand I expect more from you not just a vulnerability list.
> > Linux kernel has bugs Mozilla Firefox has bugs Perl has, Java has...
> >
> > The link you provided *mostly* lists vulnerabilities of web
> > application developed using PHP. Technically they belongs to those web
> > application not PHP.
>
> I did mention the link was a starting point. For comparison, PHP has
> 1943 matches, Perl has 101, Python 18 and Ruby 10.
>
> Why is it that the vast majority of PHP applications have
> vulnerabilities? For example, scan the PHP list - see how many "remote
> file inclusion" vulnerabilities are there? Can you find any in Perl
> programs? The reason for this is the vastly overdesigned PHP fopen()
> function/allow_url_fopen. Or the myriad of problems associated with
> register_globals. I can go on about this.
>
> Binand

They are all depends on how you develop your web application. Most
modern PHP web applications are designed to work with register_globals
off Joomla warns the user if he have register_globals on now. I won't
claim all PHP web applications are safe and secure but they are
evolving like any other language or software. Numbers cannot always
tell the truth the keywork Linux fetches 759 vulnerability and Windows
fetch 781 so is Linux as vulnerable as Windows, as the difference is
not big?

> to this PC, it takes 30 seconds for connection. This is same for each file
> transfer also. How to increase the speed.
> In RH or Fedora it is very fast.

Quite likely a reverse lookup issue:

http://www.proftpd.org/localsite/Userguide/linked/config_ref_UseReverseDNS.html

Binand

On 25/11/06, Sivanandhan, P. <apsivam@gmail.com> wrote:
> They are all depends on how you develop your web application. Most
> modern PHP web applications are designed to work with register_globals
> off Joomla warns the user if he have register_globals on now. I won't

Which is precisely my point. PHP as a language makes it easy for a run
of the mill programmer to write insecure applications. The language
has design features that encourages insecure programming - like
register_globals on, allow_url_fopen on etc.

> claim all PHP web applications are safe and secure but they are
> evolving like any other language or software. Numbers cannot always

It took close to 12 years to get PHP where it is now - with more than
its share of insecurities still present, and after overwhelming
criticism from various developer and security communities.

> tell the truth the keywork Linux fetches 759 vulnerability and Windows
> fetch 781 so is Linux as vulnerable as Windows, as the difference is
> not big?

You might be right there. I won't claim Linux is very secure. My
Redhat-provided kernel include close to 400 patches - several of which
are security fixes. Try OpenBSD.

Binand

> known as an oxymoron
Really. Well maybe programming and security should be a oxymoron that
better explains it. You can create totally insecure webpages with most
other languages as well.

I am using most because there are quite a few languages about which I
have no clue. So you could come with some thing like lisp and say it
is secure. I can't comment.

It all depends on how well (or unwell) your container is configured.
After all PHP is a bunch of C code. (I know it because I ve written my
module for PHP). The main sources of insecurity is because of the way
we have chosen to program using PHP, and I guess is not a
_characteristic_ of PHP itself.

From prashmohan at gmail.com  Sat Nov 25 20:26:00 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)
Date: Sat Nov 25 20:26:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] DNS server problem
In-Reply-To: <9acfbb0b0611250634j27c989b6j5331f423bb111b6@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9acfbb0b0611250634j27c989b6j5331f423bb111b6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45685980.1080705@gmail.com>

Adithya Narayanan wrote:
> Guys,
> I'm using Dataone Internet in Chennai and using ubuntu as OS.
> Everytime the system is idle, the DNS Ip changes back to 192.168.1.1

try removing resolvconf (sudo apt-get remove resolvconf) and then adding
`nameserver 4.2.2.1
nameserver 4.2.2.2' (without quotes) to /etc/resolv.conf and try.

Best of Luck :-)
-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Sat Nov 25 21:42:05 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sat Nov 25 21:42:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good organization for open source dev for newbies?
In-Reply-To: <20061125151943.83102.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061125151943.83102.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061125161205.GA3080@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sat, Nov 25, 2006 at 07:19:43AM -0800, Amit Dey wrote:
> I want to start open source development but I am still confused about what to do...

First you sit and learn patiently...

Then you will automatically start finding deficiencies in existing programs which the author missed and you can start.

I appreciate your enthusiasm. You should convert this into something useful by combination enthusiasm with patience. 

Coming to brass tacks I don't know what you asked but it should be easy to identify which domain or technology interests you.

You can take ubuntu or whichever you find lying around.

google for it and keep reading and browsing.

And thinking about it.

Then read the manual pages and if you feel like the source code of the programs related to that technology.

This will keep you occupied and perhaps make you wonder that you are wasting time.

But all will be well soon. :)

If you try to short circuit this process then it may lead to duplication of effort and perhaps rejection.

Of course this is no hard and fast rule, just my thought, that is all.

All the best!

regards,
Girish

PS :-

I always pass on good advice to others. It is never any use to oneself. 
 - Oscar Wilde 

 Ha ha!

hi

On 11/25/06, Amit Dey <eamitdey@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I want to start open source development but I am still confused about what to do...

Good that you want to start open source development
Bad that  u got confused about what to do

>   Can u guys suggest some organizations where newbies ( like me ) can start to open source develop.

Open Source is not specific to organizations. its about the
individuals interest.

>   How good is submitting packages to fedora-extras and ubuntu ?

It is good if you submit.

>   Is there any  way to know what currently are the requirements of the users ?

As a linux user, think of urself what is missing in using linux or any
open source tool for your daily activities. Find the missing stuff.
add that. enhance. contribute.

Thats it

From kums at gmx.net  Sun Nov 26 02:33:12 2006
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Sun Nov 26 02:33:30 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] cannot connect to internet
Message-ID: <4568AF90.2000204@gmx.net>

Hi,

> Hello again,
> 
> I cannot connect to internet from debian. I tried to configure it by
> "networking" from System Menu. But, when i select my network card, the
> window become stall and cannot go further.
> 
> But, the main thing is, my isp gave me these information:
> 
> IP: 192.168.10.205 Port: 88
> Submask: 255.255.255.0
> Default gateway: 192.168.10.1
> 
> Zico


You can directly edit the file
/etc/network/interfaces

to add something like ...

     iface eth0 inet static
     address 192.168.10.205
     netmask 255.255.255.0
     gateway 192.168.10.1
     auto eth0


After that do

     /etc/init.d/networking restart


then check whether

     ifconfig eth0

shows up correctly and check whether you
are able to ping your gateway.

BTW, who is your ISP?


Regards
Kumaraguru
--
From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Sun Nov 26 09:28:02 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Sun Nov 26 09:19:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good organization for open source dev for newbies?
In-Reply-To: <20061125151943.83102.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061125151943.83102.qmail@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <990ABDA8-B70E-4850-AEE0-37222ED7217C@thenilgiris.com>


On 25-Nov-06, at 8:49 PM, Amit Dey wrote:

> I want to start open source development but I am still confused  
> about what to do...

do:
1. go to sourceforge.net
2. check the help wanted page
3. choose 2 or 3 projects
4. download, install and check them out - see if you are interested  
in joining the team
5. lurk on their mailing lists
6. write some code, patches, documentation
7. submit that
and, if you work hard, you may make the team

dont:
1. start talking on the mailing list the moment you join
2. demand commit rights before you submit anything
3. tell people that they chose the wrong language or the wrong  
development model

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

Message-ID: <45694AC7.8010804@frodo.hserus.net>

Adithya Narayanan wrote:
> I'm using Dataone Internet in Chennai and using ubuntu as OS.
> Everytime the system is idle, the DNS Ip changes back to 192.168.1.1
> I tried to manually set the DNS, but even then the problem is not solved.
> I changed the permission of resolv.conf file to readonly. Same result. The
> problem still persists.

Log in to your dsl modem and set the correct dns server settings there

Or failing that .. look at /etc/network/interfaces, set this there

dns-nameservers 127.0.0.1 206.117.161.70 204.74.78.12

From solar345 at gmail.com  Sun Nov 26 19:47:34 2006
From: solar345 at gmail.com (Antano Solar)
Date: Sun Nov 26 19:47:44 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: ilugc Digest, Vol 30, Issue 111
In-Reply-To: <c021e3c90611260456t34915d51q9c8b6d38822fd82b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061125143507.A583C1DB2E4@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<c021e3c90611260456t34915d51q9c8b6d38822fd82b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <b2600ec40611260617o661c341coea19768e591ed9cb@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/26/06, Ambuj Thacker <ambuj.mbp@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hello every one..My name is Ambuj..By mistake i did rm -rf in my SUSE
> system.. now all the rc.d scripts..How can  get my system back?? I am also
> not able to login as root..I also want to know why /etc directory was
> targeted at first in deletion procedure..This happened to my RedHat9 {I
> didnt try to find out hte reason then :( }
>


If you are using ext3 (by default i guess its ext3) , you cannot recover
deleted files.
If its ext2 , you can  try undelete , but
with rm -rf , dont even think about it .

A article i read about rm -rf
http://www.justpasha.org/folk/rm.html


Thats why the open source guys always say , never log in as root unless you
really have to :)

have fun
Antano Solar John
From siva.ilugc at gmail.com  Sun Nov 26 22:07:09 2006
From: siva.ilugc at gmail.com (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Sun Nov 26 22:07:21 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Foss.in 2006 concluded today...
Message-ID: <a8f990120611260837l709d4a5bq1a076ee6196dd480@mail.gmail.com>

...with a brilliant closing keynote by Tim Pritlove of the
legendary Chaos Computer Club, Berlin. He's invited
everybody who attended the keynote to the annual CCC
convention in Berlin from Dec. 27th to 30th. A bunch of
members from CCC were also in attendance at Foss.in as
observers.

Other notable talks/demos were by Suparna Bhattacharya
of IBM, Harald Welte, Sudhakar Chandra "Thaths" of Google
and numerous others.

-Siva

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Nov 26 22:34:47 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Nov 26 22:35:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] linux kernel - deb
In-Reply-To: <20061126164508.96903.qmail@web8909.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <277272.15119.qm@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- satheesh kumar <m_sathyz@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> can i be abl to upgrade my kernel 
> where can i get the kernel in Deb format..

Always use your distro package manager to
install/update software, unless you know what you are
doing. From the command-line:

 apt-get update
 apt-cache search kernel

For GUI, you can use Synaptic Package Manager to do
the above.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From gilbertraja at gmail.com  Mon Nov 27 10:49:53 2006
From: gilbertraja at gmail.com (Gilbert Raja)
Date: Mon Nov 27 10:50:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] DNS server problem
In-Reply-To: <45694AC7.8010804@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <9acfbb0b0611250634j27c989b6j5331f423bb111b6@mail.gmail.com>
	<45694AC7.8010804@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <5be12c660611262119ne62dbf7nce658e2a5d715e85@mail.gmail.com>

Hai,

      try to edit your interface file ppp0 or ppp1 and change the value
peerdns=yes to Peerdns=no and check.
Actually  what was happening it was tried to get auto DNS from the modem. If
you want you can disable this by changing the above value and set your
static DNS entries in your resolv.conf file.
-- 
Gilbert Raja

From benjaminrtz at gmail.com  Mon Nov 27 17:26:49 2006
From: benjaminrtz at gmail.com (benjamin )
Date: Mon Nov 27 17:27:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT]Emacs Xrayed with DTrace
Message-ID: <ddd4b0590611270356m70c322c4h1efcba8ca03886a4@mail.gmail.com>

<quote>
The saviour (as always) was DTrace. We took the "One Universal
Application" - emacs, and did some basic Dtracing. We found that Emacs
tries to open the ~/.emacs configuration file once. *Even* if this
call fails, it proceeds to do *twenty* stat64() on *each of* .emacs,
.emacs.el, emacs.el.gz, .emacs.elc, .emacs.elc.gz ? That is 100
useless stat64() calls on a non existent file. Just imagine this when
your home directory is mounted over NFS! We then found the call stacks
calling the redundant stat functions. Alas, they don't ship Linux with
the useful CTF/Symbol Table Data that Solaris does. But then we
temproarily worked around the "problem" by touching ~/.emacs. DTrace
then showed that the one hundred stat64() calls were reduced to 3.

Wow ! 3 Minutes and 4 D-Scripts later, we had found that the most
popular Free/Open Source Software in the world wasn't written that
smartly. Just imagine the layers and layers of linux code written by
less able programmers and those seen by lesser eyes.
</quote>

http://blogs.sun.com/ananth/

-- 
benjamin rualthanzauva

I think you know what I am going to say. :)

OpenBSD is one of the most excellently supported operating system on laptops.

Its speed and performance will baffle you.

But it has no 3D, no non redistributable binary blobs and few other luxuries.

I have zero exposure to laptops but I hear this from multiple quarters.

If you can bring the laptop to my home I will get it up and running. :)

With the fish of course...

regards,
Girish

Bluetooth is not built in but I use a cheat dongle (bought in ritchie
st. for Rs. 250) which worked fine for me to sync Evolution with my
Nokia 6021. Wifi worked well with WEP & WPA. Widescreen resolution
works after installing 915resolution package. I also have beryl
running fine in this laptop. I'll add complete details on
www.linux-on-laptops.com some time.

From joe_steeve at gmx.net  Tue Nov 28 11:36:50 2006
From: joe_steeve at gmx.net (Joe Steeve)
Date: Tue Nov 28 11:40:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT]Emacs Xrayed with DTrace
In-Reply-To: <ddd4b0590611270356m70c322c4h1efcba8ca03886a4@mail.gmail.com>
References: <ddd4b0590611270356m70c322c4h1efcba8ca03886a4@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <456BD1FA.2010909@gmx.net>

benjamin wrote:
> tries to open the ~/.emacs configuration file once. *Even* if this
> call fails, it proceeds to do *twenty* stat64() on *each of* .emacs,
> .emacs.el, emacs.el.gz, .emacs.elc, .emacs.elc.gz ? That is 100
> useless stat64() calls on a non existent file. Just imagine this when
> your home directory is mounted over NFS! We then found the call stacks

Well., obviously because GNU Emacs tries to find a 'startup file' which
might be either just elisp., or compiled elisp., or gzipped elisp.,
etc., which can be in different locations and not just in the root of
your home folder. Different people want to arrange their configuration
files in different ways.

DTrace is surely a good tool for profiling and instrumentation., but
that does not mean an application should cut down its features just
because it is resource expensive to have them.

> http://blogs.sun.com/ananth/

:)

-- 
.o. I'm a Free man. I use GNU/Linux.
..o
ooo [W] http://www.joesteeve.org/

From mahabubbasha at gmail.com  Tue Nov 28 11:51:35 2006
From: mahabubbasha at gmail.com (Mahabub Basha)
Date: Tue Nov 28 11:51:44 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reducing lib/python2.4 bloat
Message-ID: <ef7327bc0611272221j17ddc307u2239868aea6b8a64@mail.gmail.com>

Hi

I have written several python scripts that need to
run on small hardware.  My "batteries included" python
2.4 installation occupies too much space:

[basha@castlerock /usr/lib]$ du -sh python2.4
 36M    python2.4

There are several standard python modules that I don't
require at all.  Eg. lib-tk, curses, logging, test (which
I use during development but not for release).  The "test"
folder alone occupies 11MB.

Removing the extra stuff by hand is laborious and error
prone.  I'm looking for a convenient way to identify
dependencies and remove the extra modules/folders.

Further more, in my final python distribution I don't want
any .py/.pyo files, I only want the .pyc files.

I don't want to build standalone executables that
py2app/py2exe produces, but instead I just want to trim
my lib/python2.4.

Can someone please suggest some python magic that I can
use to reduce my lib/python2.4 bloat?

Thanks in advance for any suggestions and help!

- Mahabub Basha.S

From sudharsh at gmail.com  Tue Nov 28 18:01:32 2006
From: sudharsh at gmail.com (Sudharshan S)
Date: Tue Nov 28 12:15:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reducing lib/python2.4 bloat
Message-ID: <456C2C24.2040902@gmail.com>

IMO, the installation size wont really slow down your scripts since you
are not importing all the modules into your scripts.

> Removing the extra stuff by hand is laborious and error
> prone.  I'm looking for a convenient way to identify
> dependencies and remove the extra modules/folders.

One way, to minimalize 'bloat' is to install "python-minimal" package,
if you are using debian or one of "*.deb" distros. Your distribution
should have a similar package. Another way is to compile python from
source..Features you dont want can be disabled during the './configure'
stage with appropriate flags.

With gentoo you could set USE flags while emerging the system

> Further more, in my final python distribution I don't want
> any .py/.pyo files, I only want the .pyc files.
Although you can do away with .pyo, I have never seen any python app
that has excluded .py..

Regards
Sudharshan S



From joe_steeve at gmx.net  Tue Nov 28 12:13:04 2006
From: joe_steeve at gmx.net (Joe Steeve)
Date: Tue Nov 28 12:16:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] cannot connect to internet
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611250906v1a3de8fcj5ecc592fe773a600@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611250906v1a3de8fcj5ecc592fe773a600@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <456BDA78.4090004@gmx.net>

Zico wrote:
> But, the main thing is, my isp gave me these information:

> IP: 192.168.10.205 Port: 88
> Submask: 255.255.255.0
> Default gateway: 192.168.10.1

They assigned you a port number? Or is that an ip:port of a proxy server?

> What they did in Windows, is,
> they ping in this number:
> 192.168.10.2

Boot into Windows, go to network settings (I dont know exactly what it
is called) and see whether something called DHCP is turned on. Else.,
note down the ip-address, mask, gateway, DNS numbers there and use them
on GNU/Linux.

From binand at gmail.com  Tue Nov 28 12:21:27 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Tue Nov 28 12:21:37 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] cannot connect to internet
In-Reply-To: <456BDA78.4090004@gmx.net>
References: <69621d830611250906v1a3de8fcj5ecc592fe773a600@mail.gmail.com>
	<456BDA78.4090004@gmx.net>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610611272251u3aed84dx4186c1b29f870a00@mail.gmail.com>

On 28/11/06, Joe Steeve <joe_steeve@gmx.net> wrote:
> Boot into Windows, go to network settings (I dont know exactly what it
> is called) and see whether something called DHCP is turned on. Else.,
> note down the ip-address, mask, gateway, DNS numbers there and use them
> on GNU/Linux.

In XP:

Start Menu->Connect To->Show All Connections->Highlight your
connection->Right click->Properties->General Tab->"This connection
uses the following items"->TCP/IP->Properties->"Obtain an IP address
automatically"/"Obtain DNS server address automatically"

Binand

From prashmohan at gmail.com  Tue Nov 28 12:46:54 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)
Date: Tue Nov 28 12:47:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Foss.in 2006 concluded today...
In-Reply-To: <456BDA4E.7000905@gmail.com>
References: <a8f990120611260837l709d4a5bq1a076ee6196dd480@mail.gmail.com>
	<456BDA4E.7000905@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <456BE266.6010902@gmail.com>

Vamsee Kanakala wrote:
> YouTube expects - well over 100MB. I wanna reduce the resolution of the
> .avi files and make them much smaller. Any tools you guys would recommend?

I _think_ Google Video supports arbitrary sized files.
You can use ffmpeg to reduce the resolution of your video. Something like:
./ffmpeg -vcodec mpeg4 -b 1000 -r 10 -g 300 -i ~/test.avi -s 800?600
~/test-800-600.avi
[Source:
http://ubuntu.wordpress.com/2006/06/08/how-to-create-a-screencast-in-ubuntu/]

I personally like the ffmpeg2theora package (much simpler to use than
ffmpeg directly)
-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

Hi All,
Thanks for all the suggestions regarding using linux on a P III with
64 MB RAM. Since open office was a compulsory requirement I upgraded
the RAM to 192MB and installed SUSE 10.1. I played with different
window managers and settled with blackbox. Then disabled daemons like
ftp, ssh etc. The system works like a charm. Open office works
comfortably, so does firefox.

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Nov 28 20:39:40 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Nov 28 20:39:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] TCP internals
Message-ID: <20061128150940.GA13237@lakshmi.susmita.org>

Check out 

http://www.us.nishida.org/soi1/index.html

I hope to emulate his brilliant use of block diagrams and protocol flow sequences.

But I am sure I cannot beat him at least as far as TCP goes.

I strongly urge you to take a look at his slides. It will help clarify at least some details about the ocean of TCP...

I regret not having used enough pictures in my slides.

I will try my level best to include as many as I can.

I recently diddled around with metapost and other TeX tools like xfig and tgif.

Amazing stuff!

If you want to help me in this endeavor send me personal mail.

Thanks.

regards,
Girish

From srsy70 at gmail.com  Wed Nov 29 08:20:35 2006
From: srsy70 at gmail.com (S.Ramaswamy)
Date: Wed Nov 29 08:20:44 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reducing lib/python2.4 bloat
In-Reply-To: <ef7327bc0611272221j17ddc307u2239868aea6b8a64@mail.gmail.com>
References: <ef7327bc0611272221j17ddc307u2239868aea6b8a64@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d60e5b0f0611281850l2fcfc6d0q175b924e27b4b850@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/28/06, Mahabub Basha <mahabubbasha@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi
>
> I have written several python scripts that need to
> run on small hardware.  My "batteries included" python
> 2.4 installation occupies too much space:
>
> [basha@castlerock /usr/lib]$ du -sh python2.4
>  36M    python2.4
>
> There are several standard python modules that I don't
> require at all.  Eg. lib-tk, curses, logging, test (which
> I use during development but not for release).  The "test"
> folder alone occupies 11MB.
>
> Removing the extra stuff by hand is laborious and error
> prone.  I'm looking for a convenient way to identify
> dependencies and remove the extra modules/folders.
>
> Further more, in my final python distribution I don't want
> any .py/.pyo files, I only want the .pyc files.
>

(1) Producing a .pyc distribution
----------------------------------
You can produce a '.pyc' only distribution using the compiler module

http://docs.python.org/lib/compiler.html

(2) Finding dependencies
------------------------

Check modulefinder http://docs.python.org/lib/module-modulefinder.html

IIRC, py2exe uses this module. Looking at the py2exe code might be useful.

(3) Compressing Modules
-----------------------
Finally you can put your modules in a zip file and import them. That
helps to save space.

http://docs.python.org/lib/module-zipfile.html

Finally what is the 2.4 bloat you are talking about ?   Try lifting a
car battery  it's pretty heavy ;-)

Ramaswamy
From citizenofgnu at gmail.com  Wed Nov 29 08:49:02 2006
From: citizenofgnu at gmail.com (Thyagu rajan)
Date: Wed Nov 29 08:49:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ASP.NET vs. PHP5
In-Reply-To: <456B377B.7070704@gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611271037v6062d37bh604763c01e95b06@mail.gmail.com>
	<456B377B.7070704@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <ed2d3c000611281919u2582dafaxda22cf9b89965fa7@mail.gmail.com>

hi,

Asking  which one is better of ? ASP.NET or PHP5

My Vote is for PHP

It is free, No one is blind to buy Visual studio.net package.

PHP runs on apache as well as on IIS though Apache wins the war, one another
reason why free softwares are powerful.

If you want your application to be light weight .

Learning curve is simple

Learning PHP will give you idea about the strong fundamental concepts, large
Samples of asp.net programmers couldnt say what you mean by running at
"server" and "client", IMHO, may be sampling error too.

Php has to be learnt by linear programming style (as a scripting language),
MVC coding style such as symfony or php cake.

Unlike ASP.NET , PHP is not idiot friendly , you do have to put some time to
avoid dragging and dropping elements.

Learning PHP with MVC coding style gives Smooth transition in adapting any
high powered framework as Rails, Django or Turbo gears

Any way , deciding software is a horses of courses, my suggestion to you is,
Have good time with (P)redominant (H)ealthy (P)ractice instead of dozing
with (AS)lee(P).net

Cheers

Thyagarajan shanmugham
From mahabubbasha at gmail.com  Wed Nov 29 10:48:32 2006
From: mahabubbasha at gmail.com (Mahabub Basha)

Subject: [Ilugc] reducing lib/python2.4 bloat [SOLVED!]

On 11/28/06, Sudharshan S <sudharsh@gmail.com> wrote:
> IMO, the installation size wont really slow down your scripts since you
> are not importing all the modules into your scripts.

I think I did not make myself clear in my original post.
I'm trying to reduce the disk usage only (my flash disk
size is very limited).

> > Removing the extra stuff by hand is laborious and error
> > prone.  I'm looking for a convenient way to identify
> > dependencies and remove the extra modules/folders.
>
> One way, to minimalize 'bloat' is to install "python-minimal" package,
...
> With gentoo you could set USE flags while emerging the system

Thanks for suggesting the python-minimal package.  As the name
suggests it's minimal, and does not even include the xml parsing
routines!  None of my scripts worked using the minimal package.

Further, my problem is that I don't know what modules my scripts
require.  I would not know which ones to leave out.

Anyway, I solved the problem by using "modulefinder". It did not
do a 100% job, and I had to add about a dozen or so files
manually.

Thanks for all the help and guidance provided!

empty files count :(

I think for the moment, I'll live with .py and .pyc files in my
disk.  I'm happy that I've reduced my lib/python2.4 from 36MB to
under 4MB.  Beyond this, I'm reaching the point of diminishing
returns :-)

Thanks for the tip!  This offers a further reduction of disk

by python.

usage or create uncompressed files in /tmp.

I'll just settle with what I've accomplished so far and let
zipping wait for another day.

From carti at chi.spunge.org  Wed Nov 29 18:42:19 2006
From: carti at chi.spunge.org (carti)
Date: Wed Nov 29 18:42:29 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] sudo - help
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0611290709430.18140@chi.spunge.org>

Hi,
Is there a way to give the password through some file instead of typing it
manually everytime I sudo.

Presently I have to sudo to run a perl script and everytime I need to type
in the password. I want to give the password through some file so that I
need not type everytime.

Leaving the security problems aside, is there a way to accomplish my need.

Thanks.
carti
From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Nov 29 18:54:18 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Wed Nov 29 18:55:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] sudo - help
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0611290709430.18140@chi.spunge.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0611290709430.18140@chi.spunge.org>
Message-ID: <456D8A02.7020503@frodo.hserus.net>

passwordless ssh key. or passwordless sudo

But your admin will have to give your username NOPASSWD privileges for
whatever script it is you want to run.

svnowner ALL = NOPASSWD:/usr/bin/svn update /var/www

carti wrote:
> Hi,
> Is there a way to give the password through some file instead of typing it
> manually everytime I sudo.

> in the password. I want to give the password through some file so that I
> need not type everytime.

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Nov 29 18:55:21 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Nov 29 18:55:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] heavy traffic websites using linux
In-Reply-To: <456D7DC6.8040001@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <5d8c3fec0611290426k202dd160o71834dd64fdf4661@mail.gmail.com>
	<456D7DC6.8040001@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <20061129132521.GA29926@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Nov 29, 2006 at 06:02:06PM +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
> anantha narasimhan wrote:
> 
> > 
> > how many heavy traffic servers these days use a Linux based OS.
> > googling for  it i didn't get an impressive bunch of them. i was not
> > able to find any of them in the likes of google, amazon, yahoo.
> > 
> > ofcource wiki is a classic example of Linux usage, I'm looking for
> > sites commonly used by all. are there any of them using  Linux as
> > their base kernel.
> > 
> 
> 
> We've got something like 40 million users across our systems, and we use
> linux.

linux+apache is a killer combo and many many sites run that.

You can easily get stats by querying the Apache cgi interface...

google's server farm used to be completely based on RedHat but I am not sure if they changed it. Last time I heard they had more than 8000 machines.

Amazon,eBay and Yahoo! run FreeBSD if I am not mistaken. Not sure.

Yahoo! does run Solaris also I think. But they are a big FreeBSD shop.

Server grade hardware used to run Solaris in the olden days but now I think linux and BSDs have taken over.

The recent stats effort by Marc Fournier of FreeBSD showed OpenBSD as the highest used system in the US but many people doubt its validity.

People just  want to claim they run OpenBSD bcoz they think it is cool to do so!

Yes, statistics don't mean much.

But this much is sure. Linux is big business. No two ways about it.

regards,
Girish

<user-name> = ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL

The point is, if you decide to be careless, nobody can stop u :p And I
dont think putting a password helps much from a social engineering
perspective... This less painful technique is atleast useful in
coaxing linux newbies to use sudo rather than logging into X as root
(believe me, those straight out of windows have a huge tendency to do
this, and then screw up their system, and crib that Linux is as bad as
Windows when it comes to security :) ). I guess you will have a hard
time convincing them if you ask them to enter a password each time :)

it moves on...

From sudharsh at gmail.com  Thu Nov 30 01:04:07 2006
From: sudharsh at gmail.com (Sudharshan S)
Date: Wed Nov 29 19:24:52 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need ebook for Glade/Gnome
Message-ID: <456DE0AF.7030400@gmail.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

> I need to do some GUI programming using Glade Interface Designer . I found some online tutorials but they are too basic.I need a complete e-book

http://people.debian.org/~rleigh/gtk/ogcalc/ogcalc.pdf
The above ebook will do the job..

You might want to take a look at gtk as well..
ftp://ftp.gtk.org/pub/gtk/tutorial/

Just a suggestion if you dont know already, Whatever you do do not use
the code generation feature of glade2..Its a big no no..I had nightmares
with that. Code the callbacks manually..Instead use libglade to load the
 glade xml during runtime. This way you dont need to compile the project
each and everytime you make changes to the UI. FYI, Glade3 has this code
generation "feature" completely removed. Additionally you might want to
install documentation regarding libglade, gtk2.0 through your package
manage system so that you may access them through devhelp.


Regards
Sudharshan S

From turnmeout at gmail.com  Wed Nov 29 17:14:09 2006
From: turnmeout at gmail.com (Santhosh)
Date: Wed Nov 29 20:06:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Pthread Priority
Message-ID: <5ef7b30a0611290344x70eea1c2ocae6e888c8dbff64@mail.gmail.com>

Hai ,
          I have a problem in PTHREAD -> priority.
          I used various scheduling algorithm for it like
SCHED_OTHER,SCHED_FIFO,SCHED_RR.

          Some are saying that we cant able to change the kernel[scheduler].
I tried it with superuser permission also. Its not working...
          This is the sample program that i cant able to set priority :
Eg:

#include<pthread.h>
#include<stdio.h>

void *
multiply (int *a)
{
  int i;
  int cancel_mul_state;
  for (i = 0; i < 4; i++)
    {
      printf ("this is thread_multiply : %d\n",*a=(*a * *a));
      sleep (1);
    }
  printf ("I am thread_multiply\n");
  printf ("This is Multiply thread_id : %d\n", pthread_self ());
}

void *
add (int *a)
{
  int i;
  for (i = 0; i < 4; i++)
    {
      printf ("this is thread_add : %d\n",*a=(*a + *a));
      sleep (1);
    }
  printf ("I am thread_add\n");
  printf ("This is Add thread_id : %d\n", pthread_self ());
}


int
main ()
{
  pthread_t thread_id_multiply, thread_id_add,thread_id_divide;

  pthread_attr_t t_attr1,t_attr2;
  struct sched_param para1,para2;
  int a = 1;

  pthread_attr_init(&t_attr1);
  pthread_attr_init(&t_attr2);

  pthread_attr_setinheritsched(&t_attr1,PTHREAD_EXPLICIT_SCHED);
  pthread_attr_setinheritsched(&t_attr2,PTHREAD_EXPLICIT_SCHED);

  pthread_attr_setscope(&t_attr1,PTHREAD_SCOPE_SYSTEM);
  pthread_attr_setscope(&t_attr2,PTHREAD_SCOPE_SYSTEM);

  pthread_attr_setschedpolicy(&t_attr1,SCHED_RR);
  pthread_attr_setschedpolicy(&t_attr1,SCHED_RR);

  para1.sched_priority=22;
  pthread_attr_setschedparam(&t_attr1,&para1);

  para2.sched_priority=11;
  pthread_attr_setschedparam(&t_attr2,&para2);

  printf ("This is Main thread : %d\n", pthread_self ());


  pthread_create (&thread_id_add, &t_attr1,(void *) &add, &a);
  pthread_create (&thread_id_multiply, &t_attr2,(void *) &multiply, &a);

  pthread_join (thread_id_add, NULL);
  pthread_join (thread_id_multiply, NULL);

  return 0;
}





by,
Santhosh.

On Wed, Nov 29, 2006 at 07:12:19AM -0600, carti wrote:
> Hi,
> Is there a way to give the password through some file instead of typing it
> manually everytime I sudo.
> 
> Presently I have to sudo to run a perl script and everytime I need to type
> in the password. I want to give the password through some file so that I

There is something wrong in your fundamental goal and assumptions.

Rethink your design. That is all I can say.

You should never have to invoke a perl script supposed to be run by root as normal user...

It is easy to solve your problem if you think a little differently.
