From eamitdey at yahoo.com  Wed Nov 29 23:38:10 2006
From: eamitdey at yahoo.com (Amit Dey)
Date: Wed Nov 29 23:38:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Re: Need ebook for Glade/Gnome
Message-ID: <20061129180810.32431.qmail@web36804.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Well Sudarshan..thanks for the book.

And I do understand your concern about the code-generation tool. I was always a little uncomfortable with it. Anyway It's great to hear that it's been removed for glade 3.0


Sudarshan S Wrote :
> I need to do some GUI programming using Glade Interface Designer . I found some online tutorials but they are too basic.I need a complete e-book

http://people.debian.org/~rleigh/gtk/ogcalc/ogcalc.pdf
The above ebook will do the job..

You might want to take a look at gtk as well..
ftp://ftp.gtk.org/pub/gtk/tutorial/

Just a suggestion if you dont know already, Whatever you do do not use
the code generation feature of glade2..Its a big no no..I had nightmares
with that. Code the callbacks manually..Instead use libglade to load the
glade xml during runtime. This way you dont need to compile the project
each and everytime you make changes to the UI. FYI, Glade3 has this code
generation "feature" completely removed. Additionally you might want to
install documentation regarding libglade, gtk2.0 through your package
manage system so that you may access them through devhelp.


Regards
Sudharshan S

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Thu Nov 30 07:06:17 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Thu Nov 30 06:58:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need ebook for Glade/Gnome
In-Reply-To: <456DE0AF.7030400@gmail.com>
References: <456DE0AF.7030400@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <B99987BF-EF81-4736-B654-628ABC828FF5@thenilgiris.com>


On 30-Nov-06, at 1:04 AM, Sudharshan S wrote:

> Just a suggestion if you dont know already, Whatever you do do not use
> the code generation feature of glade2..Its a big no no..I had  
> nightmares
> with that. Code the callbacks manually..Instead use libglade to  
> load the
>  glade xml during runtime. This way you dont need to compile the  
> project
> each and everytime you make changes to the UI. FYI, Glade3 has this  
> code
> generation "feature" completely removed. Additionally you might  
> want to
> install documentation regarding libglade, gtk2.0 through your package
> manage system so that you may access them through devhelp.

as the guy who gave sudharshan this advice i would like to add:  
Glade, or any other GUI screen builder is *not* a substitute for  
knowledge on how to build screens. If you know how to do it manually,  
then glade *may* help you do it faster. If you dont know how to do it  
manually - you are going to wind up in the soup using glade. A rule  
of thumb is to use the GUI for a quick and dirty general layout and  
then fine-tune manually. (this also holds true for wxGlade or Boa  
Constructor - or, for that matter, in a different context, Pgadmin or  
phppgadmin wrt sql)

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/


From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Thu Nov 30 07:31:25 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Thu Nov 30 07:23:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Fun] I will use google before asking dumb Linux question
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0611290634t6343507bk21d9e8373190ee52@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0611290634t6343507bk21d9e8373190ee52@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <49AADE22-2B5C-4D38-A3FF-3FF7C957E19F@thenilgiris.com>


On 29-Nov-06, at 8:04 PM, Shrinivasan T wrote:

> very interesting
>
> http://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/humor-i-will-use-google-before-asking- 
> dumb-linux-question.html

actualy this is misleading - even google will not help if you ask a  
dumb question. The key to google, or the key to getting an answer/ 
solution, is to ask smart questions. Often, in the very process of  
formulating the question, the answer becomes obvious. Again and again  
I have seen this - one person searches google for hours and doesnt  
find an answer. The next person gets the answer on the first try  
itself. And the key to asking smart questions is hard work and hard  
thinking. The so-called 'dumb' questions resolve into two kinds. One  
is 'n00b' question, where the person is totally new to the field and  
has no idea where to *start* looking for the answer. This is not a  
dumb question - the person should not be flamed and should be pointed  
to the pathway to the solution. The second type of dumb question is  
the 'lazy' question - the person asking is too lazy to think for  
himself and expects to be spoonfed. Incidently the askers of both  
these types of dumb questions are unlikely to get answers from google  
as the first has no clue as to what keywords to put and the second is  
too lazy to think about this.

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

Thyagu rajan wrote:
> The question to the thread is asking for the better software product?
> ASP.net or  PHP, i vouched for php .
>
> when my friend shared the programming apects of  python, i was zapped, 
> then
> understood php stuff as a pretty trivial stuff. but if i would have been
> introduced to python up front, i have a doubt that whether i would have
> learnt the basics?. so learning php and keep moving atleast helped me in
> understanding the stuff effectively. IMHO
There is a python vs. php comparison at:
http://wiki.python.org/moin/PythonVsPhp

http://phpsec.org/ has a number of pages on handling security with php.  
If there is a security issue with php that you have newly discovered, 
write about it at:  http://bugs.php.net/report.php

It is not as if only php has security issues and makes such requests. 
Postgresql also requests users to report about any vulnerability at 
http://www.postgresql.org/support/security.html Most free software 
projects do take security threats seriously, and deal with them quickly. 

Some statistics on how popular php and others are at:
http://www.securityspace.com/s_survey/data/man.200610/apachemods.html

Btw, there is an interesting performance benchmarking (php vs perl vs 
python) at:
http://dealnews.com/developers/memcached.html

Kenneth,

	You should read Paul Graham. In the high tech biz your advertising is thro' word of mouth and other channels on the Internet.

	If a techie is down to earth, willing to face truth and criticism he needs no MBA guy at all....

	Give me two years time. I will prove it. :)

	Also elderly people are another crowd to be avoided like the plague.

	They are far less expeditious, they are die hard naysayers and deliberate too much though they are generally more mature.

	But I have seen so many naysayers in ILUGC who are in their early twenties. It is a matter of shame. 

	Youth should be a period of confidence, energy and courage.

	Instead I find many youngsters in India thinking,"Oh, that has already been done. How do I start? The West is better than me."

	This is defeatist thinking I tell you. 

	If everyone thought like that we would not be having 5 text mode browsers, so many graphical mail  clients and so on.

	Variety is the spice of life and the world is large enough to accommodate everyone.

	Another time someone in ILUGC discourages someone I am going to blow my top.

regards,
Girish

On Thu, Nov 30, 2006 at 08:53:24AM +0530, Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
 > then they will be secure - but will they make money?
> 
> Kenneth,
> 
> 	You should read Paul Graham. In the high tech biz your advertising is thro' word of mouth and other channels on the Internet.
> 
> 	If a techie is down to earth, willing to face truth and criticism he needs no MBA guy at all....
> 
> 	Give me two years time. I will prove it. :)
> 
> 	Also elderly people are another crowd to be avoided like the plague.
> 
> 	They are far less expeditious, they are die hard naysayers and deliberate too much though they are generally more mature.
> 
> 	But I have seen so many naysayers in ILUGC who are in their early twenties. It is a matter of shame. 
> 
> 	Youth should be a period of confidence, energy and courage.
> 
> 	Instead I find many youngsters in India thinking,"Oh, that has already been done. How do I start? The West is better than me."
> 
> 	This is defeatist thinking I tell you. 
> 
> 	If everyone thought like that we would not be having 5 text mode browsers, so many graphical mail  clients and so on.
> 
> 	Variety is the spice of life and the world is large enough to accommodate everyone.
> 
> 	Another time someone in ILUGC discourages someone I am going to blow my top.

I feel that I have not been clear enough.

It is extremely easy for techies to dupe the management.

Always genuine talent resorts to straight forward methods and phoney people resort to tricks to impress the management.

It is very very easy for the management to get taken in and the real techie suffers. Yes, I am talking from experience.

I can imagine these things happening in nearly every company in India.

I hear that Intel which pays like mad has plenty of dirty politics going on in the name of competing teams doing the same thing better.

Indians I think are the worst managers on earth. And couple this with the fact that the managers are not able to make out between wheat and chaff...

Hence my reasoning.

We have been enslaved for 3000 years.

What is the characteristic of slaves? Jealousy.

We cannot tolerate the prosperity of our friends and people around us.

It need not be prosperity, it can even be technical brilliance.

I find extremely well placed highly respected people suffering from this psychosis.

At the same time I observe that Chennai culture is far better in this respect than Bangalore. Here people are somewhat idiosyncratic but at least much more sensible than Bangalore.

I don't have a solution to the problem but at least I am open about the problem. I think once we identify the problem and accept it in true earnest the solution can be found in due course.

Sorry for sounding harsh. Sometimes we just have to bite the bullet...

Sorry for spoiling your mood and offending you.

regards,
Girish

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> Hence my reasoning.
> 
> We have been enslaved for 3000 years.
> 
> What is the characteristic of slaves? Jealousy.
> 
> We cannot tolerate the prosperity of our friends and people around us.
> 

urgh, you mean jealousy was brought into indian minds just because of 
some D/E/F/P enslaving us ?

* Indians were fighting with one another far before Westerners started 
their occupation in India.

* There were very small small kingdoms fighting with one another, while 
big big kingdoms were fighting on the other side.

What was the reason ? Jealousy ?!

* If these Indians have not been jealous, then there wouldn't have been 
any occupation/enslavement for the 3000 years as you mentioned.

More than this, the same is true for every nation, even the enslavers 
themselves.

Jealousy is humans' instinct property; but its jealousy in some form 
drives competitiveness, provided its within self-controllable limits.

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> 
> Which is why I keep insisting that tech companies should be headed by techies , not MBA fools...
> 

At the risk of taking it more off-topic, though I'm not an MBA myself, I
find that remark offensive and misinformed. You're generalizing too
much, and those "fool MBAs" are very important for running big
companies. As some one who got to work with many MBAs and see their work
first-hand, I am far less cynical about their abilities. Their
contributions are real, and you're deluding yourself if you think
they're not useful.


V.

On 11/30/06, Joe Steeve <joe_steeve@gmx.net> wrote:
> M$ uses 'akamai' for caching services. Probably 'akamai' uses gnu/linux
> for their services.

Lots of people use Akamai for many things including DNS load
balancing, Static resources Caching, Static partial caching (ie.,. if
a particular aspect of the web content your service returns is static,
like say, a menu bar or a long piece of text, that can be cached).
Another interesting thing people could do is to use Akamai to deliver
geography specific content/ads. Not sure how many people do this now.

cheers,

  -Suraj

holding up under heavy traffic in the real world.

On 30-Nov-06, at 1:40 PM, S.Ramaswamy wrote:

> Does anyone know if any of these companies or any other,use virtual
> machines (Xen, UML, etc) to host their heavy-traffic sites ? I know
> Amazon is using Xen for their EC2 service and lots of hosting
> providers abroad give you an UML instance - but these sites may not be
> getting  a lot of traffic. Just curious to hear examples of  VM's
> holding up under heavy traffic in the real world.

i have had quite a lot of experience using vps instances. Problem is  
memory, service providers in price wars - some guy with a vps on the  
same machine as yours suddenly hogs all the memory and you are in the  
soup. Ok for low traffic sites - otherwise avoid them, get your own  
box. And a lot of vps providers are going bankrupt.

> > ASP.NET or PHP5
>
> Lol. The devil and the deep sea?

Incidentally, Rasmus appeared to be slightly upset with all the
criticism that PHP is getting these days, during his presentation at
FOSS.in 2006. He pointed out that lots of folks who write blog posts
critical of PHP weren't probably aware that Wordpress itself is
written in PHP. I don't think this is a good response. But it just
shows how much criticism  - lots of valid ones, and most of it
uninformed is floating around.

As he himself put it, 'PHP is for the weekend warrior' - that's a good
thumb rule for deciding whether you want to invest time in PHP.

Ramaswamy

changed... so once this one time job is over, updating has been fairly

> > thumb rule for deciding whether you want to invest time in PHP.
>
> he said that? jokingly or seriously?
>

Seriously. I don't think he has ever pretended that it's perfect.
Explaining his attitude he said that he finds programming to be boring
and tedious, and that his main interest was in solving problems. It's
the religious crowd that you find around any piece of OSS that has
made it sound like it's the solution to everything. I remember in an
earlier FOSS talk (iirc, 2000) he admitted that when he wrote PHP
first, he wasn't even aware of how to write parsers.

> two off perhaps... I wrote a script which automates the updation part
> of version controlled software, including finding out which modules
> have changed, making them, and installing them if anything's
> changed... so once this one time job is over, updating has been fairly
> automatic for me...
This might be of some interest for people who arent fortunate enough to
run debian ;P
The script does a similar job like the one above..
http://omicron.homeip.net/projects/#easy_e17.sh

It downloads all the packages from the E17 CVS. The script wont work
unless you have automake1.9 (no..not 1.10) and autoconf 2.60..Skip the
package called etk_server since it freezes when compiling..

Oh and theres a distribution called elive which is essentially etch with
E17 as the default desktop instead of GNOME, it  uses etch repositories
for the packages..Its a worth a try too
http://elivecd.org

Regards
Sudharshan S

Message-ID: <20061130122416.GA16119@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Nov 30, 2006 at 11:53:23AM +0530, Vamsee Kanakala wrote:
> At the risk of taking it more off-topic, though I'm not an MBA myself, I
> find that remark offensive and misinformed. You're generalizing too
> much, and those "fool MBAs" are very important for running big
> companies. As some one who got to work with many MBAs and see their work
> first-hand, I am far less cynical about their abilities. Their
> contributions are real, and you're deluding yourself if you think
> they're not useful.

Thanks. I realize that comment was somewhat offensive though I meant it.

One of the main problems faced by my country today is that of technical people going the MBA track. I want to put my foot down and say 

"This is not done."

Business is to be learnt by experience and entrepreneurship is to be learnt by failures. MBA schools may be teaching useful things but I am very cynical about the utility. They are creating more snobs with fat pay packages and hugely exaggerated capabilities.

It is not true that an MBA degree can substitute for real world biz experience.

As of now there is very little credence and importance given to technical capability in India which I think is a side effect of the place where India is operating on the technology value chain.

And the attention that MBA institutions are receiving is also misplaced. I am not saying that they are unnecessary or evil but that in real technology companies they don't have a place.

And again let us come back to anecdotes.

Bill Gates, Narayana Murthy, Premji, Dell, Shiv Nadar all of them were eithe engineers or not even that. Why?

Entrepreneurship is built by technical talent and confidence and real world experience. No Harvard MBA or classroom theory can give you that.

MBA people may make money but they always work for companies...

The fact that there are no real hi tech companies in India have led people to believe that MBA degrees can give them access to better lifestyles.

Perhaps true but I don't want potential technical people killed by this mentality.


regards,
Girish

From srsy70 at gmail.com  Thu Nov 30 19:04:37 2006
From: srsy70 at gmail.com (S.Ramaswamy)
Date: Thu Nov 30 19:04:52 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] heavy traffic websites using linux
In-Reply-To: <AA633DE7-9E79-46A8-99E2-F7877B6DCAB4@thenilgiris.com>

	<20061129132521.GA29926@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<bc5cb460611290548s405e135ucacf6657e7fad608@mail.gmail.com>
	<d60e5b0f0611300010u7d5a06b4xe7b779c51e63b87@mail.gmail.com>
	<AA633DE7-9E79-46A8-99E2-F7877B6DCAB4@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <d60e5b0f0611300534k3ad829bm1bb854fd8022daca@mail.gmail.com>

>
> i have had quite a lot of experience using vps instances. Problem is
> memory, service providers in price wars - some guy with a vps on the
> same machine as yours suddenly hogs all the memory and you are in the
> soup. Ok for low traffic sites - otherwise avoid them, get your own
> box. And a lot of vps providers are going bankrupt.
>

I agree that the host OS can get cranky when you have  a whole bunch
of VMs running, but with Xen's ability to migrate VMs between hosts,
an intelligently designed hosting setup might just be able to handle
the load. I am surprised to hear that with most ISPs,  VMs are allowed
to hog resources affecting the performance of other VMs. I am not sure
how you ensure resource hogging does not happen with Xen, but
Microsoft's Virtual server allows you to prioritize VMs on the fly -
pretty neat and their API is just awesome. Performance is slightly
worser than other proprietary and open source VM managers.  Wait, I
just praised Microsoft on this list .... /me scrams

Ramaswamy

From karthick.ramachandran at gmail.com  Thu Nov 30 20:40:03 2006
From: karthick.ramachandran at gmail.com (Karthick R)
Date: Thu Nov 30 20:40:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ASP.NET vs. PHP5
In-Reply-To: <69621d830611271037v6062d37bh604763c01e95b06@mail.gmail.com>
References: <69621d830611271037v6062d37bh604763c01e95b06@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7e0d5bce0611300710l50434adau4a8fdffb9f221839@mail.gmail.com>

On 11/28/06, Zico <mailzico@gmail.com> wrote:
> Which one is the best?
>
> ASP.NET or PHP5


We can argue on this for millions of years, without coming to any
conclusion. I personally believe this it all boils down on what you
really want to do. Both are tools. Use it at the appropriate place.

I love PHP, I draw pleasure programming in it.  I enjoy working in
wordpress and looking at other cool discussion boards, which
completely run in PHP. The simplicity and the ease at which one could
write programs is amazing. The sense of satisfaction is incomparable.
If I am going to develop a portal, with some 10 really enthusiastic
people, with very good knowledge on OO concepts, I will choose PHP.

On the other hand, When I am this big corporate and looking for a RAD
framework, where some 50 people with decent programming skills can
work on this mammoth web application where deadline is the key, Well,
I will go for ASP.Net.  Coupled with Visual Studio.Net, it sure is an
awesome framework to work on. The level of debugging and the event
driven layer to web development, inbuilt webcontrols, all make things
simpler for programmers and let them write less code and hence lesser
bugs.

"Hang on, Visual Studio is not free."
I don't care. Getting a license is more easier and simple than
hiring(and sometimes managing) very good programmers.

"But the employees loose their sense of satisfaction when working with
ASP.Net, as things are so easy and ready made."
who cares.? Client is happy @ EOD.

There is no one answer to your question. There are a whole lot of
parameters which define the most appropriate platform for building an
application. I dont think it is very wise to generalize stuff and get
into this debate of which is the best?


-- 
Karthick R
http://puggy.symonds.net/~charisma
From mailzico at gmail.com  Thu Nov 30 22:22:17 2006

That`s right. A long conversation has been going on one topic. But, it
really giving me various types of knowledge on both PHP and ASP.NET. This
has been very knowledgable, really and also nice to learn.

Thanks anyway.

Zico


On 11/30/06, Karthick R <karthick.ramachandran@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On 11/28/06, Zico <mailzico@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Which one is the best?
> >
> > ASP.NET or PHP5
>
>
> We can argue on this for millions of years, without coming to any
> conclusion. I personally believe this it all boils down on what you
> really want to do. Both are tools. Use it at the appropriate place.
>
> I love PHP, I draw pleasure programming in it.  I enjoy working in
> wordpress and looking at other cool discussion boards, which
> completely run in PHP. The simplicity and the ease at which one could
> write programs is amazing. The sense of satisfaction is incomparable.
> If I am going to develop a portal, with some 10 really enthusiastic
> people, with very good knowledge on OO concepts, I will choose PHP.
>
> On the other hand, When I am this big corporate and looking for a RAD
> framework, where some 50 people with decent programming skills can
> work on this mammoth web application where deadline is the key, Well,
> I will go for ASP.Net.  Coupled with Visual Studio.Net, it sure is an
> awesome framework to work on. The level of debugging and the event
> driven layer to web development, inbuilt webcontrols, all make things
> simpler for programmers and let them write less code and hence lesser
> bugs.
>
> "Hang on, Visual Studio is not free."
> I don't care. Getting a license is more easier and simple than
> hiring(and sometimes managing) very good programmers.
>
> "But the employees loose their sense of satisfaction when working with
> ASP.Net, as things are so easy and ready made."
> who cares.? Client is happy @ EOD.
>
> There is no one answer to your question. There are a whole lot of
> parameters which define the most appropriate platform for building an
> application. I dont think it is very wise to generalize stuff and get
> into this debate of which is the best?
>
>
> --
